This suit was institute by attachment, in the Ranolph Circuit Court. The writ was irecte to the constable of Demeen Township, in Ranolph county, to be by him execute an returne. At the return term the plaintiff move to have the writ amene, so as to show accoring to the facts, that the reason why it was so irecte, was that the offices both of sheriff an' coroner of that county, were vacant at the time of its issuance; an at the same time, upon the groun of the omission of any such reason, the efenant move to quash the writ. The court overrule the motion to amen, an sustaine .the motion to quash.
The act of December 21st, 1846, provies that where the offices of sheriff an coroner of any county are both vacant, an so where there is no coroner, an the sheriff is intereste in the suit, it shall be the uty of any constable of the county, to whom process may be irecte, to execute an return it in the same manner as sheriffs an coroners are require by law to o.
This statute was esigne to facilitate the remey, by substituting another class of executive officers in the place of the sheriff or coroner, whose appropriate uty it is to execute process of the Circuit Courts, in particular cases when those offices are vacant, or the officers themselves are isqualifie; seeing that such vacancies or contingencies may happen, against which the laws cannot provie. The statute is not objectionable as tening to ispense with the office of sheriff or coroner, which the legislature coul not o, but is rather to be commene as an effort on the part of the legislature to guar against any possible failure of justice, for want of the means appointe by law to attain that en.
On the other han, the averse party to be affecte by process issuing from the Circuit Court in civil cases, has the right to insist that such process shall be execute by its proper officer; because he is presume to be a man of substance, personally responsible for his tortious acts, is uner the immeiate control of the court, an whose official bon, in cases where the securities are liable for his acts of commission or omission, furnishes ample inemnity against any abuse of the powers confie to him. An as the authority of the constable to act in the stea of the sheriff, is a special one an limite to the particular case, resting solely on the groun that there is no sheriff or coroner in commission, or none qualifie to act, the fact of such vacancy, or isqualification ought to be suggeste an recite in the writ, which then becomes the officer’s warrant, an a notification to the efenant of his authorityJ;o execute it; an it may well be pleae in abatement of the process that such suggestion or recital is untrue in fact.
But the omission of such recital oes not make voi the writ, which is, in legal contemplation, issue out of the court, presume to know who are its officers; an whenever the power to issue such special process is concee, no goo reason is perceive why it oes not come within the beneficial operation of the statute of amenments. We cannot suppose that the allowance of the amenment, propose to be mae in this case, accoring to the truth of the matter, coul operate to the surprise or injury of the efenant, or eprive him of any substantial right affecting the merits of the suit. On the contrary, its allowance woul conuce to the furtherance of justice. It is fair to presume that if the efenant is injure, it is by the want of authority in the constable to act, an not by means of the omission of the evience of that authority. Accoring to the opinion in Mitchell vs. Conley, at January term, 1853, we conclue that the iscretion of the court in refusing to allow the amenment was not rightly exercise, an for that reason the jugment ought to be reverse, an the cause remane for further proceeings, accoring to law an not inconsistent with this opinion.

case_name: Adams ad. of Spears vs. Taylor; Taylor vs. Adams ad. of Spears
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
In February, 1845, the intestate, Spears, exhibite his bill against Taylor, alleging that in the year 1834, they forme a partnership in a saw mill, an that in the year 1836, they also entere into a mercantile partnership in Jefferson county. That the partnership in the mill was issolve some time in the summer of 1837, an that the mercantile partnership was continue until about the month of January, 1839. That profits were realize from both the concerns, which were woun up by Taylor, who ha charge of the books an receive the avails. The bill praye iscovery an account, an a ecree for the balance ascertaine to be ue to the complainant.
Taylor answere, that there was a partnership in two saw mills, one in a water mill commencing in 1834, an the other in a steam mill. That the steam mill was put into operation about the first of January, 1836, an some time uring the spring of the same year the water mill was washe away. That there was also a partnership in a store, which continue from some time in the year 1836 until August, 1837. That no profits were realize from either business, of which he exhibite accounts. That he ha pai ebts of the concerns beyon what assets he ha receive. That he was always reay an willing to settle, but complainant ha left the State, an it was his own fault that there ha been no settlement. He set up by way of answer the statute of limitations of three years as a bar to the relief.
Subsequently, Taylor file a cross bill re-asserting his answer with an enlarge statement of the business of the several partnerships, an of other transactionsbetween Spears anhimself, claiming a balance ue to him by Spears, on a full settlement, praying an account an ecree. Among the unsettle matters between them, he represente that, as the agent of Spears, who ha left the country, he sol a tract of lan belonging to Spears, an for the procees of which, he ha given him creit on account of what Spears owe him. That Spears, who was insolvent, ha recovere jugment against him on the law sie of the court, for the procees of the lan in question; an he praye that this jugment might be enjoine an brought into the account to be state between them.
Spears answere, amitting the partnerships in the two mills an the store. He again gave his own version of the partnership transactions. He enie that he was insolvent. He insiste that the transaction about the sale of the lan ha no connection with the partnership business. An as to some items charge against him by Taylor, an which he allege were transactions outsie of the partnerships, he relie in his answer on the statute of limitations. He answere, that his action against Taylor to recover the procees of the lan was pening, an no jugment ha then been renere in it.
The two suits being at issue, by replications to the answers, both parties proceee to take epositions! At a subsequent term, the court orere that Spears esist from proceeing to execute the jugment at law, which he ha in the meantime obtaine against Taylor; an the master in chancery was irecte to take an state an account of the matters in ispute between the parties. Aitional epositions were taken before the master, an upon the coming in of his report, it was excepte to by Spears upon various grouns. At a subsequent term the eath of Spears being suggeste, his aministrator was substitute, an the cause was submitte upon the exceptions to the master’s report. The court being of opinion that neither party was entitle to any relief, ismisse the original an cross bill at the costs of the respective complainants, from which ecree both parties appeale.
Such is a brief outline of the voluminous recor of this cause ; the etails of which are not material to the etermination of the question, which we unerstan to be involve in the cause, an the only one upon which we can suppose the ecision of the court below to have turne.
In Tatam vs. Williams, 3 Hare, 347, ecie in 1844, an the latest English case we meet with on this subject, the bill of a surviving partner seeking an account of partnership transactions, brought thirteen years after issolution by eath of one of the partners, was ismisse on the groun of lapse of time. The ¡Yíce Chancellor sai, “ In this court there is irect an very high authority for the proposition that a court of equity will not, after six years acquiescence, unexplaine by circumstances, or countervaile by acknowlegment, ecree an account between a surviving partner, an the estate of a ecease partner,” citing Barber vs. Barber, 18 Vesey 286. Ault vs. Goorich, 4 Russell 430, an Briges vs. Mitchell, Gilbert's Eq. Rep. 224, an those cases were ahere to, notwithstaning the remarks of Lor Brougham an the apparent grouns of the ecision by the House of Lors in the case of Robinson vs. Alexaner, 8 Bligh 352.
It is to be collecte from the case of Ray vs. Bogart, 2 John. Cases 432, that, assuming eleven years as the perio of elay unaccounte for, after issolution of a partnership, a bill seeking an examination an settlement of the accounts will be ismisse where the statute of limitations is not pleae or insiste on in the answer, though Juge Kent, who iffere from a majority of the court of errors, oubte whether the statute of limitations applies where there is a mutual trust as between partners, an if it i, he thought the efence is waive unless insiste on.
The circumstance that the estate of a ecease partner is sought to be charge is one that may often influence a court of chancery in refusing reief, so far as that may epen upon iscretion, because of the suppose inability of the representatives of the ecease partner, to conten on equal terms with the survivor san the statute of the State limiting claims against the estates of ecease persons, unless presente for probate an allowance within two years from the grant of letters, woul no oubt have a material bearing upon cases of that escription, where the statute of limitation has any application in chancery. But the ecisions are not confine to cases where either of the partners ha ecease. Where the statute applies in chancery, the enial of the relief oes not epen on that circumstance. In Diier vs. Davison, 2 Barbour Chy. Rep. 482, this subject was consiere, an upon the strength of the previous ajuge cases in New York, relief was enie on a bill for account, where there ha been no ealings within six years, an the complainant an efenant were in full life. The case there was embarrasse by the exception in the statute of accounts between merchant an merchant. The statute of this State, in force 20th March, 1839, oes not retain this exception, but enacts in lieu of it, that in all cases of mutual ealings, the statute runs from the last item prove; an it seems to be settle in Englan, as well as in this country, that the accounts between partners respecting the profits or transactions of the firm, are not hel to be within the saving in favor of accounts between merchant an merchant, where that exception exists.
In express trusts, where one hols the legal title an another has the beneficial interest, an which, as between the trustee an ■cestui que trust are recognizable only in a court of equity, so long-as the trust create by the ee of the parties or the appointment of law, is recognize to exist, an for any purpose remains to be execute, the statute of limitations, as such, or the analogous bar by lapse of time or staleness of the eman can have no application. But implie trusts often epening on parol proof, which have to be establishe as well as enforce by the ai of a court of equity, an originating in some wrongful an frauulent act of the party sought to be charge as trustee, which is a isavowal oí the relation, o come within the reason an policy of the statute. In such cases the party seeking to establish the trust, is suppose to have some remey, though not an aequate one at law, against the trustee committing the wrongful act or conversion, upon which the law raises the trust by implication; an where the party seeking reress is apprise of his rights, or if they be frauulently conceale from him, whenever the frau is iscovere, or might reasonably have become known, he must assert his rights in equity within the perio limiting the analogous remey at law, unless he come within some saving or exception. Else by merely going into another forum, he coul evae the policy of the statute limiting actions atlaw. Conceing then that there is a quasi trust or confience in the ealings between partners, it is not that kin of technical trust cognizable only in equity, an which exclues the operation of the statute. With equal reason such a claim to exemption from the statute coul be mae in all cases of bailment, agency an the various confiential relations in the transaction of business. Such is recognize to be the law in this country in numerous cases, among which, the leaing one is that of Kane vs. Bloogoo, 7 John. Chy. 89, an the authorities will be foun collecte on the subject in Murray's amr. vs. Mason's amr. 8 Porter 211. See also Baker vs. Bile, Balwin's Rep. 418.
In this case the partnerships were issolve by the abanonment of Spears in 1837. It oes not appear that any settlement was attempte or that either party sought it. No circumstance of accient, frau or concealment is allege, which woul now entitle the parties to the favor of equity. The bills are purely for an account an for iscovery in ai of it. The bulk of the business was transacte ten years before the filing of the bill, an there oes not appear to have been any transaction within eight years. Then recurring to the statute which limits all actions of accounts, assumpsit, or ebt upon contracts not in writing, to three years; actions on promissory notes an contracts in writing not uner seal, to five years; upon writings obligatory an j ugments to ten years; an the statute of non-claim against estates before averte to, the policy which pervaes it is sufficiently inicate; an where the statute applies courts of equity accoring to these rules, as well as courts of law ought to aminister it. The case of McGuire vs. Ramsay, 4 Eng. 518, oes not necessarily conflict with the point actually ecie'here, that the relation between co-partners oes not create such a trust as will exempt a bill for a mere account an settlement, from the operation of the statute, but it maybe oubte whether that case i not go a great way in establishing an implie trust after lapse of time.
For the same reasons that a efenant in chancery is not require in all cases to avail himself of the efence of limitation, by way of answer or by plea, as at law, but may emur where a efence, which the complainant by his allegations has anticipate without avoiing, appears to exist on the face of the bill, the objection that the claim is a stale one may be taken at the hearing, an when the proofs isclose such a case, the court may of its own motion eny relief to parties who have slept upon their rights; because while courts of chancery may have a iscretion to etermine the rights of parties seeking an ajuication, notwithstaning the lapse of time where the facts are not ispute or susceptible of being clearly ascertaine; the reason why they refuse relief in accorance with a statute by which they are not expressly boun, is the fear of oing injustice, an the inability to affor relief, where the sources of testimony have become obscure or lost by lapse of time.
The present case is peculiarly one of that escription. The bar of the statute set up by Taylor in his answer, must be consiere as waive by his cross bill, which eprive Spears of any election to ismiss the bill, an the court was free to settle the controversy between the parties, if the proofs gave assurance that it coul be one with any egree of certainty or safety. But it appears that all the partnerships were mere parol agreements an as to the very terms an stipulations of which at the outset the answers of the parties themselves raically an irreconcilably.- In the two mills an the store, Taylor was in partnership with ifferent persons, an Spears was let in as a sort of sub-partner with Taylor in his half interest in these concerns. No regular books of account were kept, an of such as were kept some are lost. The master i not attempt to take any account of the mercantile transactions. The mill accounts are complicate by the loss of rafts an isputes between the parties concerning receipts for lumber an isbursements for expenses, an for the hire an support of hans; an epening for eluciation upon the uncertain testimony of witnesses, who as they are competent by having no interest in the transactions, ha no motive to unerstan or recollect them with accuracy.
If injustice has been one by turning both parties out of court, it is to be regrette only as the result of their own laches, an for the reason that it cannot be clearly known whether injustice has been one, we conclue that the chancellor in refusing relief to either party, was influence by just views of the law an his uty.
The ecree is affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellant, who was the complainant below, exhibite his bill in chancery against John Waggoner, Emun P. Waggoner, Ewin T. Burr an William Hooper, setting forth that he, being the assignee an owner of an obligation mae by John W., for the payment of money to certain persons to whom he was justly inebte, ate the 1st of January, 1841, an the same remaining ue, an unpai to the complainant, he, on the 3 ay of January, 1844, institute suit to recover the same against John W. on the law sie of the Inepenence Circuit Court, the process being returnable to the ensuing term,holen on the IstMonay in February, an on the 12th of February, 1844, a ay of that term, the complainant recovere jugment in his .action at law, against John W- for the amount of the ebt an amages then in suit: that on the 27th ay of January, 1844, an while the action at law was pening, John W. who was the owner of a certain tract of lan in that county, on which he resie, execute his ee of that ate, conveying absolutely the lan in question to Emun P. for the consieration therein expresse, an acknowlege to have been receive, of $400, which ee was acknowlege by the grantor, an file for recor, on the 30th of the same month. That this conveyance was frauulent an without consieration, an contrive between John W. an Emun P. to hiner, elay an efrau the creitors of John W. an among them the complainant, whose suit was then pening, an at the same time an with the like intent, John W. gave a bill of sale absolute on its face, to Emun P. of all his stock of horses, cattle, farming utensils an househol furniture, for the nominal consieration of four hunre an twelve ollars, no part of which was pai. That these conveyances were frauulent an voi as against the complainant, an that the jugment at law, obtaine by him, became an continue to be a lien upon the lan in question as the property of John W.
That on the 24th of October, 1844, the efenant, Burr, procure a conveyance to him for the lan in controversy, from Emun P. for the consieration expresse, of six hunre ollars pai to him by Burr, which ee was acknowlege by Emun P. an file for recor on the ay of its ate. That before Burr obtaine this ee, the complainant notifie him of the jugment he ha obtaine against John W., which was a lien upon the lan in question by reason of the frauulent conveyance from John W. to Emun P., an that he. intene to have the lan sol uner his jugment as the property of John W., an that Burr, in other ways, ha notice that the conveyance from John W. to Emun P. was frauulent an without consieration. That if Burr pai, or agree to pay any thing as the consieration for the conveyance from Emun P. to him, it was solely for the benefit of John W., an that in obtaining such ee he ha collue with the other efenants to enable John W. to hiner an elay his creitors. That the jugment at law in the complainant’s favor remaining unsatisfie, on the 19th ay of June, 1845, he cause execution to be issue thereon, returnable to August term following, which was levie upon the lan in question as the property of the efenant, John W., which being uly avertise was expose to sale by the sheriff uner such execution, an the complainant became the purchaser, an the same was uly conveye to him by sheriff’s ee, ate, acknowlege, an recore on the 19th of August, 1845. That, afterwars, the complainant obtaine peaceable possession of the lan in controversy, an the efenant, Hooper, acting uner the authority of Burr, intrue himself into the possession, an withhel it from the complainant. A transcript of the jugment at law, execution an return, the ee from the sheriff to complainant, an copies of the ee an bill of sale from John W. to Emun P., an of the ee from Emun P. to the efenant, Burr, are mae exhibits to the bill, which prays that the conveyances from John W. to Emun P. an from him to Burr, be cancele as frauulent, that the possession of the lan be restore to the complainant, an his title thereto establishe an quiete, an for an account of the rents an profits against Burr an Hooper. A ecree pro confesso was taken against the Waggoners an Hooper, an the cause was hear on the bill an exhibits, the answer of Burr, replication an the epositions on file. The court below being of opinion that the complainant ha faile to show himself entitle to "the relief praye, ismisse the bill.
Upon the facts prove, the frauulent character of the conveyance from John W. to Emun P. becomes transparent. The grantor was a man of family, involve in ebt beyon his means, ha been sue in a number of cases ; the grantee was his son, a young man without property, or creit, unless to a very limite extent, who was then living with his father, as a member of his family, an continue to live with him while he remaine in the country; the ee was absolute, but no apparent change of ownership took place in the property, an John W. continue in possession as before, from the time of the conveyance to his son, until he abanone the place subsequent to the purchase of it by Ringgol, uner execution. No money was pai, either for the lan or personal property, but it seems to have been the unerstaning that the sales were mae to Emun P. for the purpose of paying the ebts of John W. The ebts were not specifie; an it oes not appear that the grantee ever pai a cent. The ee for the lan acknowlege the receipt of the consieration* when it ha not been pai, an the grantor took no note or obligation for its payment. Besies these unmistakable bages of frau, which, before a court of chancery passing upon the facts proven, are conclusive as to the frauulent intent, there is proof of other circumstances, the cotemporaneous acts an eclarations of the parties to these conveyances, all conucing to show that their intention was to prevent the creitors of John W. from taking his property in execution ; an the inevitable effect of the whole transaction was to hiner an elay his creitors.
Such being the conclusion of fact, it follows that the conveyance from John W. to Emun P. as against the complainant, was voi, an the jugment, subsequently obtaine by him, became a lien upon the lan as the property an estate of the frauulent grantor, an the complainant, by his purchase of the lan uner execution, acquire a vali title to it as against the parties to the frauulent conveyance!
The only question in the case is whether the efenant, Burr, is entitle to be protecte as an innocent purchaser. Although the efence is informally set up, yet taking all the allegations of the answer together an in orer to arrive at what appears to be the merits of the cause, we shall make no question here whether the answer is sufficient to let in proof of every substantial fact necessary to- constitute Burr an innocent purchaser. But there are some other statements in the answer that are to be consiere in connection with the proof. Burr amits that after his purchase, an after the ee from Emun P. to him ha been file for recor, the complainant, Ringgol, notifie him that he ha a jugment against John W., which was a lien upon the lan in question, an he intene to have it sol uner it, an that the sale from John W. to Emun P. was frauulent an without consieration, &c., an he goes on to state that supposing what the complainant sai was true, an that the jugment spoken of was a lien, he tol the complainant that if such was the case, he woul not conten for the lan, an woul o nothing the law i not sustain him in. That in a ay or two afterwars, he saw Emun P. an informe him of what the complainant ha sai, when Emun P. earnestly enie all attempts or esign, to efrau the complainant, an gave a narrative of the transaction, which, it woul seem from the answer, was the first information Burr ha of it, an was, in substance, that the conveyances from his father to him were fair, an that he was to pay the ebts of his father as the consieration for them, that his father wishe to prefer other creitors to the complainant, whom he i not acknowlege as a creitor, an i not inten to pay him unless compelle to o so, because that ebt, or a large portion of it ha been pai, for which no creits ha been given! Burr states that he then took legal avice, an upon investigation became satisfie that the conveyance from John W. to Emun P. was fair, that the complainant’s jugment was not a lien, an etermine that ho woul eneavor to hol the lan uner his purchase from Emun P., an immeiately notifie the complainant that such was his intention. It must be inferre from the answer that the efenant means to say that all the information he ha of the character of the conveyance from John W. to Emun P., that the former was inebte, an that the latter ha no means, was obtaine after his purchase from Emun P. was complete. He states further, that he pai, as part of the consieration a ebt of Emun P. to the State Bank, at Batesville, of about $400 an to Emun P. about $280, an also transferre to him an account against his father for $60.
Numerous epositions on behalf of both parties were rea in the cause, an excluing all the evience that might have been objectionable, an regaring it in the most favorable light for the efenant, Burr, it oes incontestibly prove the following facts : That Burr mae two istinct contracts for the lan in question an took two conveyances for it from Emun P., within a few ays of each other. That the first contract an conveyance were cancele, an at Burr’s solicitation the money, about $40, which he ha pai to Emun P. on the purchase, was refune to him! That the reason why the first contract was so cancele was, that Bürr ha hear of Ringgol’s jugment against John W. an his claim upon the lan in consequence of the allege fraq, an ha become issatisfie with the purchase. That before he purchase ho was informe of Ringgol’s claim to the lan. That Emun P. ha not pai or assume any ebt for John W. in the ‘Bank: that Burr pai Emun P. $100 an not exceeing that sum; that he unertook to paya part of .the consieration by substituting his note in Bank for the inebteness of John W., an as the resiue of the consieration Emun P. took up the inebteness of John W. to Burr, amounting to about $300. That John W. was, an ha been for some time previous, notoriously insolvent; an that Emun P. was estitute of means, that John W. was all the while in possession of the lan an personal property, using it at his own; that all the parties live in the same vicinity, an that Burr ha full opportunity for being-apprise of all the circumstances material for him to know.
Leaving out of view the positive proof of notice brought home to Burr, by at least two witnesses, we shoul be force to the conclusion, from other circumstances in proof, that he ha sufficient notice to have put him upon enquiry as a man of orinary pruence an experience in business transactions; an when the means of information are affore to a party, he will not be allowe to protect himself by the want of notice, because he i not choose to be informe.
In a case involving no oubtful questions of law, an upon proofs apparently so plain we cannot hesitate to ecie that the ecree here appeale from is erroneous. The jugment of this court will be that the ecree be reverse, an the cause remane, with instructions to the Circuit Court to ecree in favor of the complainant, that the conveyance for the lan in controversy from John W. to Emun P. Waggoner, an the conveyance for the same from him to the efenant, Burr, are voi as against the complainant, an that the same be cancele; that the efenants surrener the posssession of the lan to the complainant, an that his title thereto be as against them confirme an quiete; that the efenants, Burr an Hooper, pay the complainant the value of the rents an profits of the lan from the time it is shown to be in their possession at any time after the complainant’s purchase of the same uner execution; an that the Circuit Court irect an account to be taken of such rents an profits, unless satisfie to ecree the same upon the proofs alreay taken.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinon of the court.
The estate of Daniel L. Jackson ecease, of which the appellant is aministrator, appears to be of the value of the aggregate sum. of about two thousan four hunre an seventy ollars, consisting of personal property, part of which has been sol, an the resiue elivere to the wiow, at the appraise value, as part of her ower — ebts ue the estate by bons an promissory notes, ebts ue by open account an some county scrip of the county of Monroe.
In an account current renere to the probate'court of that county, the aministrator charge himself with these several varieties of assets, an besies taking creit for expenitures, for which he prouce vouchers, eucte also a sum equal to ten per centum upon the entire actual value of the estate that came into his hans. The Probate court, upon examining the account an passing upon it, correcte it so far as to strike out the ten per centum as eucte an to allow five per centum. To that action of the court, the aministrator excepte by his bill an appeale regularly to the Circuit Court of Monroe county, where the oings of the Probate court in the premises were affirme, an he has now brought his case into this court by appeal.
The appellant contens that the statute regulating the allowance of commissions to aministrators, by way of compensation for their risk an trouble, (Dig. chap. 4 sec. 108,p. 130) is applicable only to the collection of claims in favor of an estate, whether they be ue by bon, note, bill or open account, an is therefore but an effort of the Legislature to fix the respective rates of commission for the collection of each particular claim that may be severally of a sum uner one thousan ollars, of a sum between one thousan an five thousan, an of a sum above five thousan ollars.
If this proposition were true, it coul in no way benefit the appellant in this case, as it appears in this transcript, but the contrary. It cannot, however, be maintaine as true, either by the letter or by the obvious spirit of the statute. The letter of the statute is express that the commissions to be allowe the aministrator are, “for his risk an trouble in attening to the settlement of such estate,” not his risk an trouble in collecting any one eman, or even of all emans in favor of an estate. An it is obvious that the Legislature esigne to regulate the whole matter of an aministrator’s compensation, an not so much of his compensation only as ha relation to his service in collecting claims in favor of an estate; because the mischief esigne to be remeie must have been at least equal, if not greater, flowing from the exercise of the iscretion of the probate court in making compensation for services an risks of an aministrator, other than those relating to the collection of claims in favor of an estate.
The statute, when thus unerstoo as to the extent of its operation, oes not take away the iscretion of the probate court in fixing the compensation of aministrators; but only fixes a limit beyon which the allowance for compensation shall not go: the language of the statute is, that the court “ shall allow such executor or aministrator any sum not exceeing ten per centum,” &c.....“for his risk an trouble in attening to the settlement of such estate.” The probate court may therefore properly, in the exercise of a soun iscretion, fix the compensation at a rate of commission less than the maximum allowe by law, while in another case, it might with equal propriety allow the maximum of ten per centum commission for the first one thousan ollars of the true value of the estate,'five per centum on the next four thousan ollars of that value, an three per centum for so much of that value as was beyon five thousan ollars.
There is nothing in this recor to show to us, that the probate court of Monroe county abuse its iscretion, thus limite by statute, in refusing to allow the appellant the maximum of ten per centum on the first thousan ollars of the aggregate value of the estate of his intestate, an in fixing his compensation for settling up the estate at five per centum on the aggregate value; an we therefore fin no error in the jugment of the Circuit Court, which must be affirme, with costs against the appellant.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was action of replevin in the etinet. There was but one count, an in this it was allege in the usual form, that the efenant ha receive the plaintiff’s horse, an although often requeste ha not elivere him, but unlawfully etaine him. It was commence against Malay in his lifetime, who having been afterwars kille by Dalson, his aministrator, Phelan, interpose three pleas: first, non etinet', an in the other two, setting up property an the right of possession in ecease, Malay. Upon these pleas issues were joine, an submitte to a jury, who foun for Dalson, an jugment was renere accoringly. A new trial was move on the part of the aministrator, upon the groun of allege exclusion of competent testimony an of misirection of the jury. This motion was refuse an the cause was brought here by appeal upon a bill of exceptions.
From this, it appears that the line of efence relie upon an attempte to be establishe, was that the unqualifie ownership in the horse in question, of the ecease Malay in his lifetime, was in no egree affecte by the allege purchase of Dalson; because that originate in frau, an was consummate by the felonious act of knowingly paying the purchase money in counterfeit gol coin. To this en, the aministrator, after proving by a witness, that in February, 1852, Dalson came to the house of the ecease an offere him ninety ollars in gol for the horse; that he then left the house of the ecease, taking the horse along with him, accompanie by the ecease; that the ecease returne home after a short time, an forthwith hane over to the witness ninety ollars in gol pieces, which the witness then unerstoo from the ecease, that he ha receive from Dalson in payment for the horse, then offere to prove by the same witness the following aitional facts : That the ecease, Malay, ha no other money in his house at that time : that he owe two ebts in the neighborhoo, one of fifty ollars an the other of forty-five ollars ; that about that time he pai these two ebts with five ollar gol pieces : that the persons to whom these two several payments were mae, ascertaine that the gol pieces pai over to them by Malay were counterfeit gol coin, an immeiately returne them to Malay, then in life: that soon'after these facts transpire, Dalson left the country, an took with him the horse in question: that he was pursue an arreste on a charge of passing feloniously, ninety ollars of counterfeit gol coin on the ecease, Malay, was brought back to the county where the allege offence was committe, an there, after an examination by a competent court, was require to enter into a recognizance for his appearance before the Circuit Court of that county to answer that charge: that immeiately afterwars Dalsonkille Malay; an that certain eighteen pieces of counterfeit five ollar gol coin, then reay to be prouce to the jury, were the same that ha been pai over by Malay to the two persons before mentione, to whom he owe the ebts respectively. But the Circuit Court refuse to permit any of these facts to be proven to the jury, because, as is state in the bill of exceptions, “ that there was no proof nor offer on the part of the efenant to prove that the gol pieces allege to be counterfeit, were the same pai by Dalson to the ecease.”
It is true, that in this offer to prouce testimony to the jury there was no offer to prouce irect proof to establish the allege fact that the counterfeit gol coin prouce, were the same that were pai over by Dalson to Malay for the pui’chase money of the horse, but there was certainly an offer to prove a chain of facts an circumstances from which, although a conclusion to this effect woul not necessarily follow, it might have been arrive at by the jury within their just province. Even in criminal cases of the highest grae, that kin of circumstantial evience, classe by the elementary writers as uncertain, is amissible. But in such cases, “because of the more serious an irreparable nature of the consequences of a wrong ecision, the jurors are require to be satisfie beyon any reasonable oubt of the guilt of the accuse, or it is their uty to acquit him; the charge not being prove by that higher egree of evience which the law emans. In civil cases it is sufficient if the evience on the whole agrees with an supports the hypothesis which it is auce to prove; but in criminal cases it must exclue every other hypothesis, but that of the guilt of the party. In both cases a verict may be well foune on circumstances alone; an these often lea to a conclusion far more satisfactory than irect evience can prouce. (1 Greenl. Ev., 3 E. sec. 13, p. 74.
The court below therefore erre in refusing to permit proof of the facts, an circumstances offere to be shown in evience. Of their relevancy there coul be no question, as it is clear that where property has been, obtaine from the owner by a felonious act, his unqualifie ownership is not in the least change, an he may peaceably take it, in whose hans soever he may fin it. (Long on Sales, page 166, 7, 8, an cases there cite.
The ruling of the court in reference to instructions to the jury was substantially correct. But for the error touching the exclusion of evience, the jugment must be reverse an the cause remane to be proceee with.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
On the 24th March, 1851, Brown sue Hutchings before a justice of the peace, on a note for $31 15, payable the llth ay of April, 1845, with interest at the rate of 10 per centum per'annum, from the 8th of September, 1841, an obtaine a jugment. Hutchings appeale to the Circuit Court of Pulaski county, an upon aerial e novo jugment was renere for Hutchings, an Brown appeale to this court, having taken a bill of exceptions to the ruling of the Circuit Court in excluing certain testimony, an for allege improper instructions to the jury.
In the latter court, as well as in the former, non assumpsit an the statute of limitations were interpose, an upon the trial of the issues forme in short by consent, Brown, after having rea in evience the note sue on, propose, in the language of his bill of exceptions, torea to the jury an- enorsement on the back thereof, in these wors : “Rec’ two ollars, 59 cents on this note, in recoring, &c., in 1848;” an to prove aliune that sai enorsement was mae on the note by the plaintiff before it was barre by the statute of limitation; but the court refuse to amit such evience, eciing that an actual part payment must be prove, an rejecting sai enorsement, an the testimony propose by the plaintiff to show that it was mae before the note was barre: an upon this ecision plaintiff close his case, excepting to the ecision of the court in so excluing such evience. An thereupon, the efenant offering no evience, the court tol the jury to take the case an fin from the face of the note whether it was barre or not, an that they ha nothing to o with the enorsement thereon. To all of which the plaintiff excepte.”
The enorsement, accompanie with the propose evience aliune, was competent; because it conuce to establish the fact of the allege part payment. Not that the enorsement of a ereit in any case of itself removes the statute bar; it has no such effect, but it is merely evience to be consiere by the jury among the circumstances going to show an actual part payment. An when proven to have been actually mae by the lawful holer of the note, within the statute bar, it is amissible in evience upon the general groun that at the time it was mae, it was against the interest of such holer to make it. Its effect, when so amitte, as has been several times holen in this court, (Woo vs. Wyl, 6 Eng. R. 758. State Bank vs. Wooy et al, 5 Eng. R. 641) is to make aprima facie case for the plaintiff in the absence of other evience to repel the presumption raise thereby. If other facts an circumstances shown in evience repel these presumptions, the plaintiff must necessarily make further proof of the allege part payment; otherwise he must fail.
In the case of The State Bank vs. Woy et al, those presumptions were repelle, an the prima facie case, which woul have been otherwise for the Bank, was overset by the aitional testimony, w’hich was introuce in her behalf.
So, in any case, if circumstances tening to show that the enorsement was not mae Iona fie, appear in the_ evience auce on either sie, they shoul always be consiere by the jury in coming to their conclusion whether or not an actual part payment was in fact mae, as allege an attempte to be proven by the enorsement, as a meium of evience. If, for instance, a very small creit enorse, was proven to have been mae the ay before the bar was complete on a large ebt, this circumstance woul be worthy of some consieration by the jury. Like any other fact, it is the especial province of the jury to etermine from the evience auce before them, whether in such a case the part payment allege was actually mae. If they fin that it was mae, then in the absence of facts an circumstances in proof to the contrary, they woul be authorize to fin that it was appropriate by the ebtor to the part payment of the ebt upon which they ha foun it was pai. An on this founation woul be authorize to fin a promise by the ebtor to pay the balance of that ebt, which promise, by force of the law removes the statute bar interpose as a efence.
In the case at bar we have sai that the enorsement in question, accompanie by the evience aliune offere, was amissible in evience, because it conuce to prove the allege part payment. This is certainly true in the case of a creit enorse generally, or enorse as pai in money, an we can conceive of no soun reason why the rule shoul not apply as well when the payment is enorse as having been in labor an services, as in property, or in a note of an account, which woul otherwise be matter of set off. Because, in either case, to enter a creit within the statute bar woul be equally against the interest of the creitor, an it is manifest that, in all these cases, greater facility woul be affore the efenant to repel by proof the prima facie case mae against him, as in this case, that Brown i not owe him the amount creite, or that he ha never consente to such án appropriation of it, than when the enorsement might merely purport to be a creit generally, or one because of the payment of money.
We think therefore that the court erre both in excluing the testimony an in giving instructions to the jury.
Let the jugment be reverse, an the cause be remane to be proceee with.

case_name: Byers as ad. vs. Fowler as ad. d. b. n. et al.
text_content:
Mri Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This cause was brought up by appeal from the chancery sie of Inepenence Circuit Court. It appears from the transcript sent up, in connection with what has been since certifie into this court in obeience to its process, that on the 17th ay of May, 1834, Nathaniel Cox, in accorance with the Territorial statute of that ay, file his petition in the Inepenence Circuit Court against James Boswell, aministrator of I-Iartvvell Boswell, ecease, Frances Ann Boswell, his wiow, an Elvira D. Boswell, a minor, their only chil, to foreclose a mortgage on certain lans. He set out a copy of the mortgage in the petition, amitte that the aministrator ha pai the sum of $592 34, on the 16th ay of April, 1833, an $1,000 on the 19thMaróh, 1834, on the mortgage ebt, an praye for a foreclosure for the resiue of the original, ebt of five thousan.ollars. At the November term 1834, Fowler, having in the meantime marrie the minor aughter, appeare an was mae a efenant also, an the cause was continue by consent. In the May term 1835, the aministrator an the wiow severally answere that they believe the allegations of the petition to be true, but knew nothing of their own knowlege. The aministrator set up the two partial payments mentione in the petition, an the wiow her claim of ower in the mortgage lans, an the cause was continue by consent. From this time until the Decemberterm 1841 inclusive, the cause was'regularly continue. On the 24th ay of Aug., 1842, in vacation, James Lawson, jr., file a sworn suggestion of the eath of Cox, an grant of letters testamentary upon his estate to him by the Probate Court of Pulaski county, of the eath of Frances Ann, the wiow, an of the eath of James Boswell, aministrator of Hartwell, an of the grant of aministration e bonis non, on the estate of the latter to Absalom Fowler, an cause a subpoena in the nature of a scire facias to be issue against Fowler an his wife, to show cause why the cause shoul not progress in the name of Lawson, aministrator of Cox,.
At the December term 1842, Fowler, without entering his appearance, move the court to quash the return on the scire facias, which was one, an the cause continue. From this time until the May term 1848, Lawson, at each term mae various efforts to progress with the cause, but was always repulse, until finally, uring that term, to wit: On the 6th June, 1848, he was overthrown, it having been consiere by the court, that the suit as to him shoul abate, that he shoul pay all costs that ha accrue as to him, an be allowe to withraw his exhibits theretofore file.
On the same ay, to wit: the 6th of June, 1848, Byers suggeste in open court, that Cox ha ie intestate, that aministration of his rights, creits an estate in Arkansas, ha been regularly grante to him; that James Bosw’ell, the former aministrator, an Frances Boswell, the wiow of Hartwell Boswell, was also ea; that aministration e bonis non on the estate of the latter, ha been grante to Absalom Fowler, an praye that the suit shoul be revive an procee in his name as aministrator of Cox against Fowler as a., an in his own right, an that a subpoena in the nature of a scire facias issue against him, to show cause why it shoul not, an also against Joseph H. Egner as trustee for Fowler, an against John Ruell. An thereupon Byers as aministrator of Cox file in court his amene an supplemental bill, an Fowler then, in proper person, appeare an waive process of subpoena, both for himself an as attorney for Egner an Ruell, an leave of court having been grante to plea, answer, or emur at the next term, the cause was continue.
In this bill he first alleges the grant of aministration to Mm on CosCs estate in Arkansas, the eath of the other persons heretofore mentione as having ie, an the grant of aministration on Boswell’s estate to F°wler, an prays that the cause may be revive, an then by way of amenment an supplement alleges that F°wler an wife, in January, 1842, by ee, conveye a portion of the njortgage lans to John Ruell, who took the same, with notice of the mortgage an of this suit. That in September, 3842, Fowler an wife conveye to 'YYm. F, Denton the resiue of the mortgage lans in trust, to sell them, an out of the procees pay, first, all incumbrances upon the lans conveye an pay the resiue to Fowler, or in case Fowler shoul pay off the incumbrances himself, to convey the lans to him on eman, an alleging that the incumbrance contemplate was that of the mortgage of Cox. That after the conveyance to Dentonin trust, Mrs. Fowler ha eparte this life without issue, an that Den-ton, the trustee, ha also ie, an that since his eath, Egner ha been substitute as trustee by the chancellor; an charging, upon belief, that the bill of exchange for $5,000 secure by the mortgage, was ate on the 3 ay of May, 1832, an payable on the first ay of April thereafter, but was in fact an in truth rawn of the 16th ay of April, an payable 12 months after ate, as recite in the mortgage ee, an alleging that there never was but one bill for $5,000 rawn on an in favor of the same parties, an that the bill of exchange in question was then on file in the Probate Court of Inepenence county. That it was accepte an pai by Cox in his lifetime. That he i not know where the original mortgage ee was; an pi’aying that if he shoul afterwars fin it, he might be allowe to use it in the progress an at the hearing of the cause : that the bill of exchange upon ue presentment ha been allowe against the estate of Hartwell Boswell, ecease, by James Boswell, aministrator in his lifetime. An praying that this his amenment an supplement to the original bill of Cox be taken an mae a part of the same: that Egner, Ruell an Fowler answer the whole. That the resiue of sai mortgage ebt, with interest be ecree to him as aministrator of Cox, an that the equity of reemption of all the efenants, an all other persons in the mortgage lans an tenements be foreclose, an that they be sol to satisfy the amount foun to be unpai, with interest an costs, an that the efenants be require to o whatever may be neeful to vest a complete title to the lans in the purchaser thereof.
It oes not appear that any process went out against the efenants; on the contrary, they entere their appearance, as we .have before state; an at the March term 1849, they file their several answers.
In several particulars the answers of Egner an Fowler maybe state together. They show a further sale an conveyance of a part of the mortgage lans in May, 1846, to one James Mull, for the sum of $400, its full value. The fact that he i the latter an that he kept such funs in a separate rawer from his own, is in exact accorance with his uty as aministrator, an with the exemplary character an accurate business habits of the man, as shown on the part of the efence; an therefore affor no presumption of the appropriation of the money to the payment of the mortgage ebt as woul have arisen, ha it been shown that he was in the general habit of mixing his private funs with those of the estate, using but one common purse.
Giving then, again, to the efence the utmost force of all that remains of the testimony, conucing to prove facts from which any further payments may be presume than those we have foun respectively, it amounts to but the establishment of the fact, an that by the testimony of Thompson, mainly, that James Boswell, in his character of aministrator, ha some uncertain amount of money in his hans, an upon this fact, in connection with the aitional facts, that he was an agent of the representatives of Cox, to collect the money from himself as aministrator of Hartwell Boswell, an was a man of accurate, cautious, an pains taking business habits, almost always consulting with the witnesses, Ringgol an Egner, in progressing with his matters of business, we are calle upon to presume aitional payments. There are several ifficulties in our way in making such a presumption ; some of which are insurmountable.
We have seen that the law will not presume a transmutation of the funs from Boswell, aministrator, to Boswell, agent, as it woul o, if all proper ifficulties were remove, between Boswell, aministrator, an Boswell, guarian, for instance, because the latter capacities are so incompatible that there coul be no remey by suit, an therefore the law steps in an affors the remey by way of retainer; whereas, in this case the orinary impeiments to retainer in a proper case are not remove by the evience — as by showing that there was no other possible use for the funs but to pay the mortgage ebt: an in this case, where Cox’s representatives coul have sue Boswell, aministrator, although the same Boswell was the agent of Cox, the law oes not step in an affor a remey by way of retainer, until it be first shown, as it has not been, that Boswell, the aministrator an agent, by some open act electe .to transmute the funs. An it is not probable that any court of competent jurisiction woul allow an aministrator the amount of a payment claime as having been mae to himself, as agent, unless istinctly shown, an until after the most thorough scrutiny, if at all. An so far from the proof of the business habits of James Boswell, an of his habitual free communications with his friens, Ringgol an Egner, afforing us ai in malting the esire presumption of payment, even if the links in the testimony, which we have inicate, were not wanting, they ten strongly to the contrary, an we can but feel that they militate against the verity of Thompson’s statements, as to his having seen the “peck of silver money;” which, on the other han, might be sustaine by some circumstances that woul allow'of his having seen some few hunre, which his inexperience eyes might have cause his imagination to magnify. For it can but seem remarkable that, upon the part of the efence, some trace of the outgoings of so much money shoul not have been shown by the evience of these witnesses, which is so full an explicit that there was no money on han at the eath of James Boswell. If it ha been pai out in Bates-ville, a man of James Boswell’s business habits an free intercourse with Ringgol an Egner, as shown by the testimony, woul scarcely havegacte without leaving some trace in the knowlege of these witnesses; nor is the probability less, if he ha remitte it by mail, as to some fact connecte with the remittance being within their knowlege.
An having now first foun that the complainant ha mae out his case, an that towars the satisfaction of the mortgage ebt certain partial payments have been from time to time mae, of the sums an as of the ates that we have specifie respectively ; an lastly that no further payments have been mae, or can be presume for the efenants, we eem it totally unnecessary to go further into the testimony, either to strengthen the complainant’s case, or to weaken the probabilities that any further payments have been mae than those that we have foun, although there are several facts an circumstances, other than those we have notice, which ten to both ens, an to fortify our conclusions, both as to the complainant’s equity in the matter of the mortgage ebt, an as to the total want of efenant’s equity on account of partial payments towars its satisfaction, beyon what we have allowe. Having, as we conceive, sai enough for the founation of our jugment, that the complainant shoul have a ecree for the resiue of the mortgage ebt.
The claims of Ruell an Egner, an that set up on behalf of Mull, that they were purchasers for a valuable consieration without-notice, are totally inamissible. They were all purchasers, not only with notice by the registry of the mortgage ee, but were purchasers penente lite. It is a mistake to suppose that there was any chasm in the proceeings, or, at any rate, any such chasm as woul let these parties out from being purchasers penente lite. It is true there is no express orer of court making Lawson a party complainant, but the court allowe process to go out in his name, allowe him to file an amene bill, an other pleaings, an in various ways treate him as a party complainant, an finally renere a jugment against him for costs, when uner an erroneous iea of its power to reverse the proceeings of the Pi’obate Court of Pulaski county, it orere the suit to abate as to him. We have, therefore the most abunant groun upon which to presume that a formal orer of court was mae, amitting him to become a party complainant, when he first went into court as a suitor. An when the suit was after-wars abate as to Lawson, it was forthwith revive in the name of Byers, aministrator, in whose name it progresse to the final ecree.
We think, therefore, that the lans in controversy are clearly subject to the mortgage ebt; that the equity of reemption in them shoul be foreclose ; that they shoul be sol, an the procees applie towars its satisfaction, an the efenants shoul be ecree to o whatever may be neeful to perfect title in the purchasers.
The cross equity set up by Ruell, is concee by Fowler an Egner, an they concur in his prayer for the relief base upon it. Byers, as aministrator of Cox, however, insists upon his rights, an concees nothing. To the extpnt that the prayer of Ruell (thus concurre in by Fowler an Egner) craves relief by a ecree that certain lans, not inclue in the mortgage to Cox, (but conveye by Fowler an wife, along with a portion of the mortgage lan to Denton, as trustee, for this purpose,) shall be first sol, an then that the mortgage lans shall be sol, may be well grante, without militating against the right of Byers, as aministrator of Cox. An relief to that extent shoul therefore be ecree for Ruell; an then further effort for his relief may be safely mae by irecting that next afterwars, such of the mortgage lans as were not sol to Ruell, shall be then sol, an in the last place, thatthe resiue of the mortgage lans, being those sol by Fowler to Ruell, shall be sol. The relief sought for Mull, is inamissible.
In orer to ascertain the resiue of the mortgage ebt, for which the ecree shall be renere in favor of Byers, aministrator of Cox, against the efenants, interest must be compute at the rate of five per centum per annum, from the first ay of April, A. D. 1833, upon the sum of five thousan ollars, up to the 16th of May, of that year, an ae to the principal sum, an from that aggregate, the first payment, which we have specifie, must be eucte; then interest at the same rate must be compute on the balance foun from the 16th of May, 1833, up to the 17th of March, A. D. 1834, when the payment of one thousan ollars was mae, an so on until the last payment shall have been eucte, an then the ecree shall be renere for the balance thus foun ue, together with costs, with interest at the same rate until pai by a sale of the lans or otherwise.
An this ecree must be so restricte as to exten only in its effects against the lans in controversy, specifie in the bill an cross bill, although in terms against the efenants, there being no grouns of relief lai in the bill beyon such as may be ha by a sale of the lans in question.
The ecree of the Circuit Court of Inepenence county, must therefore be reverse, an the cause remane to that court, with instructions to enter up a ecree in accorance with this opinion, an to execute it accoringly.
