R. 67), of requiring that the evience shoul, in every case, be brought upon the recor, only after the overruling of a, motion for a new trial. On the contrary, we think that if it may have been brought regularly upon the recor before, an the recor shows istinctly that all the evience was so regularly of recor; as might well be one in exceptions that might be taken by bill to the giving or refusing to give instructions to the jury in orer to show the application or misapplication of the law to the facts, there woul be no more necessity in such case of reproucing such evience in the last bill of exceptions to the overruling of the motion for a new trial than there woul be to reconstruct any other part of the re-» cor. Because the waiver which is the result of a motion for a new trial, is no mutilation of the recor, proucing thereby any necessity for its reprouction in the last bill of exceptions, but simply a waiver of the right to insist upon exceptions taken uring the trial, as mere errors in law,” unless preserve by exceptions taken to the overruling of the motion for a new trial.
In the case at bar, all the evience prouce on the trial, an that which the court woul not allow to be prouce to the jury, as well as all the instructions given an refuse, are upon the recor regularly, an so is the motion for a new trial, an the exception of the appellant to the ecision of the court overruling his motion for a new trial. A bill of exceptions coul have therefore brought nothing more upon the recor than was alreay there; an that istinguishes this case from that of For vs. Clark, (7 Eng. R. 99), an several other cases.
Watkins, C. J., not sitting in this case.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was an action of ebt on a promissory note, ue on the 30th of September, 1839. The efenant interpose several pleas, upon which issues were joine, an also that the plaintiff’s cause of action ha not accrue within three years next before the commencement of the suit. To this plea the plaintiff replie first, to the effect that his intestate ha institute suit on the note in question, in the Johnson Circuit Court, on the 14th of February, 1840, against the efenant an his co-promissor, John Howell, pening which suit plaintiff eparte this life, an at the December term of sai court, in the year 1840, his eath was suggeste, an that such further proceeings were ha afterwars in that suit; that at the September term of sai court, in the year 1845, it was orere to be revive, an progress in the name of the plaintiff as aministrator, at which term the efenant an sai John pleae to the action, an on the 2 ay of September 1846, in that court, the plaintiff recovere jugment in that suit, for the amount of sai pote with amages an costs of suit. That sai jugment was remove by writ of error to the Supreme Court, where it was ajuge an ecie that the jugment of the Johnson Circuit Court was null an voi, an that the writ of error be ismisse: whereby the jugment an, proceeings ha in the Johnson Circuit Court became, an were arreste; an that the plaintiff, on the 8th of December, 1849, an within one year after such ajuication an ecision of the Supreme Court, commence the present suit against the efenant. The secon replication is to the effect that the efenant an his co-promissor, John Howell, were partners in trae, an mae the note in question on account of their partnership concerns, an that John Howell, on the first ay of March, 1847, an within five years next before the commencement of this suit, mae a certain payment to the plaintiff upon the note in question.
The facts intene to be set up in the replication are state so as to give the plaintiff in error the full benefit of them without regar to any efect of form. Upon emurrer sustaine to the replications, final jugment went against the plaintiff in error.-
The questions of law presente upon this recor may be briefly ispose of. The first replication is no avoiance of the bar setup in the plea, because regaring the ecision of this court, whatever it was, to be the law of the case, there was no jugment of the Johnson Circuit Court to be arreste or reverse on error; an the plaintiff fails to bring himself within the savings of the 24th section of the statute of limitations. The secon replication ie ba, because, accoring to the repeate ecisions of this court, the act of December 14th, 1844, being prospective, oes not apply to causes of action accruing prior to its passage, which are-governe by the then existing laws, as to the limitation of actions, which was three years upon promissory notes, so that the part payment allege to have been mae in 1847, i not have the legal effect of exteningthe right of action for five years from that perio. But uner the ecision in Biscoe vs. Jenkins, (5 Eng. R. 108,) another objection is fatal to this replication. The first payment by John Howell having been after the note in suit-was barre, woul have the effect to revive the ebt as against him, but woul not revive it against his co-promissor.
The jugment of the court below must be affirme with costs.
Hon. G. O. Watkins, Chief Justice, an Hon. Davi Walker, Justice not sitting. »

Hon. S. H. Hempstea, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the court.
This case was before this court at a previous term, (5 Eng. 309,) an was reverse. The evience on the secon trial, if not ientically, is at least substantially the same as reporte. It has become the settle law of this court, that a refusal to grant a new trial, on the general groun that the verict is contrary to law an evience, will not be reviewe, unless there is a total lack of evience upon one or more points necessary to the maintainance of the action, or making out the efence. Where the question simply is as to the weight or sufficiency of the evience, this court will not isturb either the fining of the court sitting as a jury, or the verict of the jury. Drennen vs. Brown, 5 Eng. 140. Sparks vs. Beaver, 6 Eng. 630. State Bank vs. Conway ante, Mitchell vs. State Bank, ante.
These rules we are ispose to ahere to; but averse as we are, to isturbing the verict of a jury, yet there are cases in which it is necessary to the attainment of justice, an to ecline that uty altogether, woul imply, that we regare jurors as infallible, which is far from being the fact. We woul not invae their constitutional authority, but at the samé time we woul not have it unerstoo that they are final arbiters of life, liberty an property.
In the case now before the court, the verict is without evience to sustain it, an falls within the rule above lai own, an the jugment must be reverse.
Watiuns, O. J., not sitting.

case_name: Rawdon, Wright & Hatch vs. Rapley et al.
text_content:
S. H. Hempstea, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was an action of ebt brought by the plaintiffs against the efenants, on a recognizance conitione in substance, that the Real Estate Bank shoul prosecute with effect, a writ of error which she ha sue out in the case of herself against the present plaintiffs, an on which she ha obtaine a superseeas, an pay the money that might be ajuge against her by the Supreme Court, or otherwise abie the ecision of that court therein.
It appears that the jugment in that case was reverse on the 22 August, 1842, an the case orere to be remane for further proceeings. On the 27th August the efenants in error in that suit, file a motion for reconsieration, an obtaine leave to submit a written argument, on or before the first ay of the next term, to which term the case was continue. The opinion of the court was not recalle, nor the jugment set asie, nor suspene. On the 10th January, 1843, at the succeeing term, the petition for reconsieration was file, an taken uner avisement, an on the 7th July, 1843, at the following term, the cause was orere to stan for rehearing, the jugment to be set asie, an it was then taken uner avisement. On the 7th August, 1844, the orer of 7th July, 1843, was annulle, the petition for reconsieration refuse, an the jugment of 1842, orere to stan as the jugment of the court. On the 9th August, 1844, this last orer was set asie, an the cause was again submitte to the court an was argue by counsel, an on consieration, whereof the jugment of the Circuit Court was reverse an orere to relate back to an take effect as of the first ay of the term.
This seems to be the present attitue of the suit, an certainly no examples coul more forcibly emonstrate the evils which must result from attempts to isturb the jugments an ecrees of courts of recor, after the term at which they were pronounce, has passe. It seems at one time to have been regare as a question of practice in this court resting upon the soun iscretion of the juges. But ifficulties of such a formiable character sprung out of the practice, as to inuce the juges to pause an investigate the question of power, an it was then announce, as a true principle, that uner our system of jurispruence, courts of recor o not possess the power an authority to vacate, annul, reverse, or suspen their jugments an ecrees after the term has passe. Ashley vs. Hye & Goorich, 1 Eng. 100. An it was sai in that case, that “upon principle an preceent when the Supreme Court once ajuicates a question, pronounces its opinion, reners jugment thereon, an the term el apses, leaving the jugment in full force, the case passes forever beyon the jurisiction of the court; except it again be brought up by appeal or otherwise, after another trial in the inferior tribunal.”
After a careful examination, we entirely approve of the octrine in that case, an hol it to be the settle law of this court. So far inee from being issatisfie with it, we cannot conceive on what possible grouns a ifferent octrine coul be maintaine, without converting courts of recor into courts of original an appellate jurisiction, an allowing them to pronounce jugments at one term an reverse them at another, an thereby exercise a power, neither inherent in or elegate to them. As to this question, this court is not ifferent from other courts. Inee, as there is no tribunal to revise our acts, it is our imperative uty, in all cases, to avoi the exercise of all oubtful powers.
It cannot be enie that there is a right inherent in the nature an organization of every court of recor, to amen jugments an process at any time, in orer to attain the ens of justice an perfect the proceeings accoring to the truth, as it existe at the time. An this right has its origin in the general power of the court to o justice, rather than in any statute of jeofails. Mara vs. Quinn, 6 Term Rep. 8. Dillon vs. The Mayor of Grampon, 7 Term Rep. 699. King vs. The State Bank. 4 Eng. 188.
But this is quite a ifferent question from setting asie or vacating a jugment after the term has passe. The one is intene to perfect the proceeings an maintain the jurisiction of the court, the other to estroy — the one is to uphol, the other to overturn.
The jugment of reversal renere in the case of The Real Estate Bank vs. Rawon, Wright & Hatch, (5 Ark. 559,) at the July term 1842, was not set asie nor recalle at that term. The leave to file a motion for reconsieration, an a written argument at the next term, an the continuauce of the cause coul notin our opinion have that effect. Nor was the jugment ever regare by this court as having been set asie or suspene, because, on the. 7th July, 1843, a reconsieration was grante, an the jugment for the first time orere to be set asie; an although this orer was irregular, yet it serves to show that, up to that time the jugment was consiere as in full force.
In Ashley vs. Hye & Goorich, 1 Eng. 92, it was hel that the filing of a motion for leave to present a petition for rehearing' or granting that leave by the court, or actually filing such petition coul not have the effect of suspening the jugment of the court. This we regar as a ecisive authority on the present question: because, although a continuance was orere in the case of The Real Estate Bank vs. Rawon, Wright Hatch, an none in the case just quote, yet it will reaily occur to any one that that is an immaterial circumstance, an cannot affect the principle ecie. The two cases are similar, an ientical in substance, because, to grant leave to file a petition for rehearing at a future term, woul seem to be equivalent to a continuance of the cause to that term, for otherwise the leave coul not be mae available. That the court might have intene to set asie or suspen the jugment renere in 1842, may be amitte,but that it was one either irectly or inirectly, or that any act equivalent to it was performe at that term, is a proposition which cannot in our opinion be maintaine.
We are compelle by preceent an principle to eclare that the jugment of the Supreme Court in the case of The Real Estate Bank against Rawon, Wright & Hatch, renere the 22 August, 1842, was a vali an bining jugment, not reverse, vacate nor suspene, an that all the action, an orers, an proceeings of the Supreme Court with regar thereto subsequent to the term at which the jugment was pronounce, were nullities, possessing no juicial sanction, the jurisiction over the subject matter being exhauste at that term, as was hel by this court in the late case of Cossitt vs. Biscoe, 7 Eng. 95.
It may not be amiss to remark that we cannot' perceive any groun for a reconsieration, an if the jugment of the Circuit Court was now irectly before us for revision, we shoul have no hesitation in reversing it, as i the ol court, because it is clear enough from all the facts that the present,plaintiffs in error gave creit to, an looke to Williamson the agent for payment, oubtless preferring his responsibility to that of the Bank; an their remey was not against the Bank, but Williamson, iniviually. Real Estate Bank vs. Rawon et al., 5 Ark. 558.
It only remains for us to say that, as the jugment of 1842, was vali bining an unreverse,itfollows as a necessary consequence that the writ of error was prosecute with effect, an the conition of the recognizance performe. While the efenants in error as sureties are to be hel to their engagements, yet their liability is not to be extene by implication; an as it appears on the merits that they are not liable, the court correctly foun for them, an ischarge them by its jugment.
Other questions iscusse by counsel with great ability, we o not eem it necessary to investigate or ecie on the present occasion, contenting ourselves with affirming the jugment of the Circuit Court, as on the whole recor we consier it to be right.
Affirme.
Watkins, C. J., not sitting.

S. H. Hempstea, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was an action of assumpsit, brought by Patrick against Holleville, an in which there was a trial by jury on the general issue, an a verict an jugment for Patrick, to review which this writ of error has been sue out by Holleville.
The eclaration contains two counts, similar to each other, but on two ifferent causes of action; an it may be remarke, that a eclaration coul harly be more inartificially rawn, an if we felt ispose to countenance technical objections, there woul be no ifficulty in fining them in it. The case stans in this court on the eclaration alone; because the bons an assignments therein escribe have not been mae a part of the recor by oyer, bill of exceptions or otherwise, an cannot be notice for any purpose whatever, although copie into the transcript.
The eclaration avers the writings obligatory to have been mae by William Strong an payable to Holleville on the 1st January, 1841; that they were before payment, assigne by him to Patrick, “to wit, on the 10th ay of July, 1841:” that when they became ue, they were presente fpr payment, an payment require “accoring to the tenor an effect thereof;” but that neither Strong nor Holleville pai the same; an it is then averre that “of all which sai premises the sai Holleville afterwars, to wit: on the 10th ay of July, 1841, ha notice.”
As a general rule, it is not to be enie, that a party is always boun by his own pleaings, an can make no proof in contravention of them. But it is equally as well establishe, as an exception, that it is not essential to state the real or precise time unless it constitutes a material part of the contract; nor in criminal proceeings, except where time forms an ingreient of the offence. An although a certain ay is state, yet neither in civil nor criminal cases, nee the ay be prove as lai, but an entirely ifferent ay may be prove, an it will be well enough. 1 Chitty's Pl. 288, 289. 1 Chitty's Cr. L. 224.
In assumpsit on a contract, whether express or implie, the plaintiff is at liberty to prove that it was mae at any other time than that allege. 2 Stra. 806. So, in an action against the acceptor of a bill payable after sight, an allegation that it was accepte on the ay of the ate will be prove, though it appear it was accepte on a subsequent ay. 1 Chitty's Pl. 288.
It was neither necessary nor usual to aver in the eclaration the precise time when the assignments were mae, or when payment was require, or notice of non-payment given. These were all matters of evience, which, for the sake of preserving brevity an perspicuity in pleaing, are never to be state. 1 Chitty's Pl. 258. Those ates were state uner a vielicet, an we are of opinion, might have been rejecte as surplusage, an which will not vitiate after verict. Chapman vs. Smith 13 John. 80. Hyslop vs. Jones, 3 McLean, 96. The case of Jackson vs. Henerson, 3 Leigh, 210, 217, is an express authority to the point, that if the eclaration avers that a bill was presente, an payment emane when the same became ue an payable, an then uner a scilicet, states a precise ay on which it was one, that ay is immaterial, nee not be prove, an may be rejecte as surplusage. To the same effect is the case of Bynner vs. Russell, 1 Bingham 23. S. C. 7 Moore 266, on the authority of which the case in Virginia was ecie.
It cannot amit of serious oubt, that it was competent for either party on the trial, to have prove that the assignments ha been mae, or that payment ha been emane, or notice of non-payment given at ifferent perios from those averre in the eclaration. Neitherparty was boun by those piecise ates, an might, as we have seen, have treate them as surplusage, an for aught we can know, such proof might have been actually-mae as above inicate.
This case was trie by a jury on the general issue. No exceptions were taken uring the trial, nor was any motion mae for a new trial, or in arrest of jugment. It stans on error, an consequently if the eclaration iscloses a cause of action the jugment must be affirme. The octrine on this subject is that when a eclaration or other pleaing sets forth a goo title or groun of action in a efective manner, the imperfection will be cure by verict, but a want of title is not aie. 1 Saun. 227, 2 Soun. 319, a, b. c. 10 Bac. Abr. Verict (X) 335.
An this court in Sevier vs. Holliay, 2 Ark. 571, approve an lai own the same principle, namely, that “where there is any efect, imperfection or omission in any pleaing, whether in substance or in form, which woul have been a fatal objection on emurrer, yet if the issue joine be such as necessarily requires on the trial, proof of the faots so efectively or imperfectly state, or omitte, an without which it is not to be presume that either the juge woul irect the jury to give, or the jury woul have given the verict, such efect, imperfection or omission is cure by the verict at common law.” Now no one can rea the eclaration without perceiving that it iscloses a right or cause of action, although partially obscure by the want of technical skill an precision in the pleaer. The imperfections in it are precisely of that character which a verict was intene, uner the rule above lai own, to cure. An it is the more essential that it shoul be so, because, inepenent of the general presumption of correctness which attaches to jugments of inferior courts until the contrary is mae to appear, we may well suppose that on the trial, such facts were prove as establishe the liability of the plaintiff in error, holing it clear that this might have been one uner the eclaration, an on the issue that was forme.
The case of Ruston vs. Aspinall, Dougl. 653, relie on by th© counsel for the plaintiff in error, is not applicable, because, the eclaration faile to allege a eman an refusal by the acceptor; but in this eclaration, eman, refusal an notice are allege. Consiering that the eclaration in this case iscloses a cause of action, an that the imperfections in it'are cure by the verict, an we affirm the jugment.
Watkins, C. J. not sitting.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This suit is brought against Ruell alone, on the joint obligation of Moore an himself. The bon was barre by the statute of limitations, unless the bar was remove by part payment-The efenant pleae the statute of limitations, to which the plaintiff replie generally. Uner this issue, the plaintiff offere evience of such part payment, but the efenant objecte to the evience upon two grouns, first, that the evience offere was-incompetent an inamissible to prove part payment; an secon, that if amissible as evience in other respects, it u as inamissible uner the issue forme. The court overrule his objections an permitte the evience to be given uner the issue, to which the efenant excepte. The same question was again-presente upon a motion for a new trial; an upon exception to-the opinion of the court in refusing, to grant a new trial, the case* is brought here by appeal.
Uner the issue forme it evolve upon the plaintiff to prove-that the cause of action ha accrue within five years next before-the commencement of the suit, which ates from-the filing of the bon, which, uner the statute, is in effect a eclaration, an the issuing of the writ thereon, an the time- when the bon fell ue ; facts to be establishe by the terms of the contract, an the recor evience of the commencement of the suit. If the plaintiff shoul seek to avoi the force an effect of this evience,by show-in§,a new promise, or a new an ifferent point from which the-statute bar commence to run, it is an affirmative matter, the truth of which he must show, an he must also necessarily confess the time at which the bar, by the terms of the contract, commence running. It is then necessarily like matter in confession an avoiance, an shoul be so replie.
Chitty, in his work on pleaing, vol. 1, page 583, says that, when the plea is that the cause of action i not accrue within, &c., the plaintiff coul prove a promise or acknowlegment within.that time, an that the replication might, in such case, be general; but if the time of issuing the first writ in the action were material, it must have been replie specially : an as, that a special replication is, in general, avisable. An upon this istinction as to whether the plea oes, or oes not put the time of issuing the writ in issue, rest all the cases to which the plaintiff has referre, except the cases ecie in Massachusetts Reports, which, upon quite a ifferent state of case, give preference to the proceeing by special replication, an in case the time of issuing the writ is putin issue, make it inispensably necessary to plea specially. Greenleaf, in his work on Evience, vol. 2, sec. 440, page 416, says, “ that if the plaintiff woul avoi the bar by proof of an acknowlegment of the claim, he can only o it uner a special replication of a new promise within the time limite.” An so, also, the exceptions in favor of merchant an merchant, an other exceptions must be replie specially. I. sec. 447-448.
In the case of Trustees vs. Hartfiel, 5 Ark. Rep. 557, the precise question as to whether part payment coul or not be given in evience uner the general replication, was not iscusse; but the court in passing upon the sufficiency of the special replication, hel, that part payment might be given uner the general replication, or might be replie specially.
In Walker vs. Bank Mississippi, 2 Eng. Rep. 504, although the question was not irectly before the court, an for that reason cannot be hel as overruling in express terms the case of Trustees vs. Hartfiel, the court hel that an avoiance of the statute bár by limitation, uner any of the exceptions of the statute, shoul be specially replie. An in Ringgol & Hynson vs. Dunn, 3 Eng. 497, the same rule was hel, when more fully presente, an in still stronger terms. In McClellan vs. The Bank, 7 Eng. 141, where a general replication was file to a plea of the statute of limitation, the recor of a former suit brought on the same cause of action was offere in evience, to bring the case within the exception of the 24th section, Dig. chap. 99, which allows the plaintiff to renew his action within one year next after a jugment of non-suit, it was hel that in orer to let in evience of such former suit, the plaintiff shoul have file a special replication setting up such facts in avoiance of the statute bar.
An in the case of Woos vs. State Bank, 7 Eng. 697, an also in a case still more recently ecie, Bank vs. Conway, January term, 1853, it was hel the safer an more regular practice to require part payment, when relie upon to remove the statute bar, to be specially replie. So that it is not now an open question of practice, but one sactione an approve by this court, both upon soun principles of pleaing an authority: an being, in our opinion, best calculate to present the efinite matter in issue isencumbere from the other facts which might arise uner the general replication, an to limit the proof to it, we o not feel at liberty to epart from it.
Evience of part payment was, therefore, inamissible uner the issue as forme, an shoul have been exclue by the court, inepenent of all consieration of its sufficiency otherwise, which we will next procee to consier.
There were several creits upon the bon, all of which, except one, purporte to be payments mae by Moore, the obligor, not sue. The first payment appears to have been mae by Moore, an, if proven to have been mae at the time it bore ate, woul have remove the statute bar. To prove this the plaintifF offere in evience the following instrument, to-wit: “All of the above creits were mae by me, except the three ollars, an the ates of the creits are correct. Decir. 2, 1850. (signe) Wm. Moore.” An after proving the execution thereof, offere the same, together with the first enorsement of a payment (which purporte to have been mae by Moore) as evience, an the same, against the objections of the efenant, were amitte as evience to the jury.
In orer to prove part payment, as against a co-obligor, it must be shown that such payment was mae at a time when its legal effect woul be to remove the statute bar. Bank vs. Wooy, 5 Eng. 643. Woo vs. Wyls, 6 Eng. 759. The mere enorsement of a creit, as of a ate to effect this, isjnot of itself sufficient: but it must be shown that the enorsement of payment was in fact mae within such time. But where the enorsement is mae by the obligors, or one of them, then proof of that fact will be sufficient evience to permit the enorsement to be rea as evience, as well of the ate as the fact of payment.
After the statute bar has attache no act or amission of one •co-obligor will bin another. Trustees vs. Jenkins, et al. 5 Eng. 108. Such acts an amissions are alone bining upon the party making them. Moore’s amissions, therefore, at the time when they were mae, whether wiitten or verbal, were inamissible as evience against Ruell, an shoul have been exclue. He was not sue, an was clearly a competent witness to prove the fact of such payment, as well as the time when it was mae, whether mae by Ruell or himself.
Let the jugment be reverse, an the cause remane, with leave to the plaintiff to file a special replication.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the court.
This was a suit in chancery, to enjoin a jugment at law. The grouns for equitable relief are: that the complainant was security for one Whitfiel, upon a elivery bon. That after the bon was forfeite an before the renition of tlie jugment thereon, Arrington, the creitor, without the knowlege or consent of the complainant, mae a new contract with Whitfiel, the principal in the bon, by which he postpone the payment of the ebt to a further ay. An also, upon the further groun, that after the bon ha been returne forfeite, an before suit upon it, the creitor sue out an alias execution upon the original jugment against Whitfiel, the principal in the bon, an cause the same to be levie upon the personal property of Whitfiel, of value sufficient to pay the ebt, an that after such levy, by the orer of the creitor, the execution was returne without sale or isposition of the property.
It becomes unnecessary to ecie upon the merits of the equitable efence here set up, or whether it is sustaine by proof, until we ispose of a preliminary question, as to whether the efence, conceing it to be sufficient, shoul not have been mae upon the trial of the case at law.
It has been settle by the previous ecisions of this court, that this is a matter of efence over which the common law an the chancery courts have concurrent jurisiction. Hempstea & Conway vs. Watkins, a. 1 Eng. 317 It is a complete legal efence? an may be.pleae as such, Calwell vs. McVicar, 4 Eng. 418, an the efenant may elect to efen in a court of law, or shoul he ecline to efen there, he may set up such efence in chancery. Hempstea & Conway vs. Watkins. But shoul he elect to efen in a court of law, an fail in his efence, ho is hel to his election, an cannot again present his efence in a court of chancery, unless there is an express averment of frau, surprise, accient, or the like, which may in some instances entitle the party to relief in chancery, notwithstaning his efence at law. Garvin et al. vs. Squires, 4 Eng. 533. When the efenant submits himself *to the jurisiction of the court of law, by offering any efence whatever, it matters not whether by emurrer to the eclaration, plea in abatement, or in bar, it amounts to an election of jurisiction, an having mae such election, he must make efence there, an whatever efence is not mae, will be consiere as having been waive. Le Guen vs. Gouverneur, 1 John. Cases, 505.
In truth, from the moment he comes into the court of common law to efen, his election is fixe, an he stans in all respects, as if it was a efence over which the common law court ha exclusive jurisiction, an his excuse for a failui’e to make a full an successful efence must be the same as if no such concurrent jurisiction ha ever existe.
In this case the parties were all before the court. The efenant emurre to the plaintiff’s eclaration, upon which issue was joine, an a jugment renere. This is a efence, a submission to the jurisiction of the court, an an election to efen there. The nature of the efenceitself is not so important. The true enquiry is, has the court power to hear the efence, an has the efenant electe to be hear in that coui’t. If so, he must abie his election. Courts of chancei’y abhor multiplicity of act mis, an require vigilance at the hans of its favore suitors. Such vigilance was cleaxy not shown in this case, nor is any reason assigne for eclining to follow up his efence in a court that ha thus acquire jurisiction of the parties, an where an issue was tenere, upon which that court ha fall power to affor the same relief that is sought in this court. It must be remembere too, that before the case of Hempstea of Conway vs. Watkins, settle the practice ifferently, it was rather the favore opinion that when the plaintiff tenere to the efenant an issue in a court of law, upon which the efence was full an complete in that court, such efenant was boun to make such efence, or shoul he suffer a efault, he shoul not be hear thereafter in a court of chancery, even though such court ha concurrent jurisiction with the court of law to hear an etermine the same. An there is certainly not wanting both goo reason an authority for this ; for, amitting that the courts have concurrent jurisiction, an are in all respects equally competent to hear the efence, that which first gets jurisiction of the parties, an in which the issue is first tenere, woul seem to have preceent right to ajuicate an finally settle the matter litigate.
We are not to be unerstoo by these remarks as issenting from the correctness of the ecision in the case of Hempstea & Conway vs. Watkins, but simply as intening to show that the rule shoul not be extene further. In that case there was no efence whatever : in this, there was a efence, an election to appear an efen. An in the absence of any sufficient excuse for not having followe up that efence, the efenant will not be hear to complain in this court. Because from the time such election was mae, it cease to be a matter of concurrent jurisiction, an became a matter exclusively within the jurisiction of the common law court. The efenant was not eprive of his right to select in which court he woul make his efence, but i elect, an having one so must abie by it.
As therefore the court of chancery ha no jurisiction of this case it becomes unnecessary to enquire whether the facts sustain the equitable efence set up or not.
The ecree of the Jefferson Circuit Court must therefore be reverse with instructions to assess amages ujrnn the issolution of the injunction an to ismiss the bill.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The first groun of exception in this case is as to the correctness of the ecision of the Circuit Court in sustaining the plaintiffs emurrei'jto the efenants plea in abatement. The matter pleae in abatement was a varíen ce between the writ of summons an a copy of the summons serve upon the efenant. This was no groun for abating the action; at most it was an inirect attack upon the sheriff’s return. If the sheriff ha not, in fact, serve the efenant with a true copy of the writ, an ha falsely returne a vali service, it might become the subject of inquiry upon a irect proceeing against him for a false return, but was no groun whatever for abating the writ. Hughes vs. Martin, 1 Ark. Rep. 386. The plea shoul have been stricken out! There was no necessity for emurring to it, but the objection by emurrer was also goo. An issue-upon it, if tenere, woul, in fact, have settle nothing beyon a question of service.
The secon groun is that after a jugment by efault an upon inquiry of amages before the jury, the efenant was ene the privilege of cross-examining the witnesses introuce to establish the amount of amages sustaine.
In this we think there was error. By failing to appear an. efen, or after having appeare an pleae in abatement, the failure of the efenant to plea in bar, was a confession of the plaintiff’s right to recover amages, an although after such efault or failure to plea, the efenant coul not be hear to eny that some amages were recoverable, still, it was not an amission of any particular amount of amages. If so, there woul be no necessity for a writ of inquiry of amages; an although we have not foun any ajuicate case settling the practice in such cases, we can see no goo reason why the efenant shoul be eprive of his right to cross-examine the witnesses introuce by the plaintiff upon the trial of the inquiry of amages, in orer to show truly what amages ha been sustaine.
In this case we o not know what the question intene to be aske was, nor o we know the range of enquiry inulge upon the examination in chief. The opinion of the court woul seem to eny all cross-examination, irrespective of the nature or extent of the enquiry. Without, therefore, knowing what the particular state of case was, or intening to be unerstoo as eciing that any an all evience, which, uner proper issues forme, woul ten to lessen the amount of amages, may be offere by the efenant upon an inquiry of amages, uner the state of case pre sente we think the Circuit Court erre in refusing the efenant permission to cross-examine the plaintiff’s witnesses. An for this error the jugment of the Circuit Court must be reverse, an the cause remane.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This is a proceeing by attachment against Ellis, a non-resient efenant. A eclaration in ebt for $1,450 32, a bon for costs, an affiavit for $671 86, an attachment bon for $1500, all in ue form, having been file, the clerk of tbe Circuit Court of Phillips county issue a writ, which is not questione otherwise than we shall presently state, commaning the sheriff “to attach George W. Ellis, by all an singular his goos an chattels, bons an tenements, creits an effects, or so much thereof as shall be sufficient to secure the sum of six hunre an seventy-one ollars an eighty-six cents, with interest thereon at the rate of 6 per cent, per annum, from the 23 ay of April, A. D. 1851, together with the costs of this suit. An you are also commane to summon the sai George W. Ellis, if he be foun in your county, to be an appear before the juge of our Circuit Court, at the court house, in an for sai county of Phillips, on the 4th Monay in May next, A. D. 1852, it being.the 24th ay of sai month, then an there to ant wer, Freerick H. Cossitt, James M. Howar an Ira M. Hill, merchants, an partners, traing an oing business uner their firm, name an style of Cossitt, Howar & Hill, the plaintiffs in this suit, in the premises, *as set forth an sworn to. An you are further commane, <^c.”
To this writ two pleas in abatement were file, praying that it might be quashe; first, because the sai writ wants these wors “ in an action of ebt for the sum of fourteen hunre an fifty ollars an thirty-two cents, ebt, an two hunre ollars amages secon, he says that the sai writ of attachment wants these wors “ as sworn to.” To the first plea the plaintiffs interpose a emurrer, an replie to the secon. An the issues in law an fact, severally, having been foun for the plaintiffs’ below, an the efenant taking exceptions an eclining to answer further, final jugment w7as renere against him an he appeale to this court.
Upon the authority of the cases of Renner vs. Ree, (3 Ark. R. 339) an of Chilress vs. Fowler, (4 Eng. R. 159) it is contene that the writ ought to have been quashe on the first objection.
Allowing that the remey by attachment, both in process an pleaing, in all matters beyon the scope of the statutory provision setting it on foot, is to be governe by the general provisions of law applicable to other law suits, an that these statutory provisions themselves are to be construe in reference to our entire system of laws; an recognizing the compoun nature of the process of attachment, in combining a proceeing in rent with a proceeing in personam, as inculcate in the case of Chilress vs. Fowler, nevertheless this writ woul be goo uner the reasoning an spirit of the case of Renner vs. Ree, because upon the face of it, the efenant is not only avise of the nature of the complaint in its being exhibite as a money eman, but he is avise of the precise amount sworn to by the plaintiffs, an has, therefore, a much more accurate ata upon which to prepare a efence, than the face of an orinary writ woul give. So far as facilities for efence are concerne — an this is the groun Upon which the jugment in Renner vs. Ree was base — when the efenant is avise that he is proceee against for a money eman, specific in amount an sworn to, an in a proceeing by attachment for service by seizure of property, we think it a sufficient notification to him of the nature of the complaint,‘to apprise him of the cause of action, an enable him to prepare his efence: more especially in view of our system of practice, which requires, that before any original writ shall issue, a eclaration shall be first file in the clerk’s office, there to remain, subject to the inspection of all parties. (Dig. Pr. Law sec 3.) An if the ecision in Renner vs. Ree unavoiably le to the consequence of holing the writ ba in this case, upon the objection taken, which it oes not, as we have seen, we woul be more incline to epart from that case an return to what we conceive to be the true spirit of the statute than to be governe by it.
We think there is nothing in the other point mae.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was a suit upon a bon given by the plaintiff in an action of forcible entry an etainer uner the statute, an the other efenants in error, who were his securities. The bon was given, payable to the efenant in the action of forcible entry an etainer, an who is the present plaintiff, but it is conitione strictly in accorance with the statute. The eclaration makes profert of a true copy of the bon, alleging that the original is on file in the office of the clerk of the Circuit Court to which the writ of forcible entry an etainer was returnable, an not within the power or control of the plaintiff: an after setting out the bon an conition assigns for breach, that upon the execution of the bon, the sheriff proceee to execute the writ by turning the.present plaintiff out, an putting the efenant, Gibson, in possession of the premises in question, an that such further proceeings were ha in the action of forcible entry an etainer, that afterwars, to wit, &c., “sai Gibson ismisse his sai suit an abanone an refuse further to prosecute the same, whereupon by the consieration an jugment of the sai court there,[a. jugment for costs was renere in favor of sai plaintiff herein against the sai Gibson, an a writ of restitution aware by sai court, which costs amount to a large sum, to wit, the sum of --- ollars,” all of which woul appear from the recor thereof remaining, &c., an avers that the sai efenant Gibson i not restore to the plaintiff the possession of the premises escribe, an i not, nor woul pay the sai plaintiff all such sums of money as were ajuge against him in sai action, an so the conition of the bon was broken an the same became forfeite, &c.
The plaintiff refusing to amen, after emurrer sustaine to the eclaration, final jugment went against him, from which he has appeale. The question is, as to the sufficiency of the eclaration, to which various causes of emurrer were assigne in the court below, an some of which will be notice.
The statute, Digest, Title, Forcible Entry an Detainer, sec. 7, provies that the writ of possession shall not be execute in any case, unless the plaintiff or some other person in his behalf shall execute a bon to the sheriff or other person, in a sum at least ouble the value of the property specifie in the writ, &c. The “other person” in the statute oes not refer to the efenant in the action, but means that the bon shall be execute to the sheriff or other officer to whom the writ is irecte, an who may be charge with its execution, as for instance, the coroner, or in extreme cases, the constable, where the offices both of sheriff an coroner happen to be vacant. Thompson vs. Bremage, at this term. See Digest, Title, Replevin, sec. 10, from which the section in question was, no oubt, intene to be copie. The efenant in the action of forcible entry an etainer might have ha the bon prouce by a rule upon the sheriff, an woul not be boun to accept it, if essentially informal, variant from the statute, or efective in the conition, an might have obtaine an orer upon the plaintiff to furnish a sufficient bon, on paiii of having his suit ismisse with jugment of restitution.
But the efenant in the action of forcible entry an etainer appears to have acquiesce in the form of the bon, an has signifie his acceptance of it by the present suit. It oes not lie in the mouth of the plaintiff in the action of forcible entry an etainer to question the sufficiency of the bon or its valiity uner the statute, nor ought they to be allowe to escape from it, if it can be uphel as. a common law obligation. It was execute to enable the principal to obtain possession of the property in controversy, an was a conition preceent to the execution of the writ: it was execute voluntarily an not uner any uress, is not contrary to public policy or goo morals, an not forbien by any statute, or calculate to efeat its object. Nunn vs. Goolett, 5 Eng. 89. See authorities collecte in Whitset vs. Womack, 8 Ala. 475.
The allegation that the bon sue upon is on file in the clerk’s office, an which is but inucement for the conclusion that is not within the power or control of the plaintiff, oes not come up to the allegation in Nunn vs. Goolett, that Hie bon was of recor, an though confesse by the emurrer, oes not show any sufficient excuse for not proucing the original. The allegation that a paper is on file oes not necessarily imply that it is so by authority of law, as to make it a recor or a part of the recor of any particular suit, unless from the character of the paper, the court woul have to conclue that it was a matter of recor. But if equivalent, this point was not notice or ecie in Nunn vs. Goolett. The law has provie epositories for official bons, an makes a certifie copy, evience in lieu of the original. So bons for attachment an injunction, being prerequisites to the issuance of the writ, have to be file with the clerk, so that if not technically an for all purposes a part of the recor, of the particular suit or proceeing, they certainly are public recors an in legal custoy. Wilson vs. The State, 5 Ark. 513. So elivery bons are require to be returne with the execution, an become part of- the recor as the founation of ulterior proceeings. In none of those instances woul the legal presumption be that the plaintiff ha the right to the possession of the ee or instrument eclare on; an though he ought to make proferí of an authenticate copy for the ai of the court, an the information of the opposite party, Aams vs. the State, 1 Eng. 504, he is uner no obligation to prouce the original, which remains subject to the inspection of all persons intei’este. '
But the bons in replevin an forcible entry an etainer are not require to be returne an file so as to become in any sense a part of the recor, unless mae so by some proceeing or exception taken uring the progress of the cause. They are taken an hel by the sheriff for the benefit of the efenant, an aré to be assigne to him, if jugment be renere for him in the action. This assignment follows of course, an the court will orer it as a matter of right on the application of the efenant, in case the sheriff shoul refuse. So that when the efenant brings suit on such a bon, it is in legal contemplation in his possession, or uner his control. It may be lost or estroye, or for some unusual cause, beyon his control, but this ought to be shown, an to the extent that profert is necessary, in orinary cases, as an excuse for the omission.
There is nothing in the case of Nunn vs. Goolett which woul ispense with a succinct an accurate statement of the jugment or recovery set forth in any assignment of breaches. Without enquiring as to the proper moe of making the averment which the ecision in Butler vs. Owen, 2 Eng. 373, misapprehening Calwell vs. Bell & Graham, 3 Ark. 423, has left in some confusion, the rules of pleaing require that the plaintiff shoul set forth some certain amount ajuge to him for his costs, or if ajuge generally aver the amount uner a viclicit which woul let in proof of the true amount to which the costs were afterwars taxe. Shelton vs. Clark, 2 Eng. 194. As the property is immovable an the successful efenant can always be restore by-writ of restitution, his costs, an perhaps also the rents an profits accruing after jugment, if he oes not choose to avail him- • self of the writ of restitution, uner the construction given to the statute in Fowler vs. Knight, 5 Eng. 43, constitute the gravamen of the, breach. From so much of that ecision as hols that where the efenant succees he cannot have his amages assesse, but has his remey upon the plaintiff’s bon, we are not now prepare to issent further than to observe that, accoring to the conition of the plaintiff’s bon, it woul seem the efenant can have no remey upon it for any amages consequent upon eviction uner the writ of possession, or the intermeiate rents an profits, or even waste committe before jugment, unless recovere against the plaintiff in that action, so that the security affore by the bon, is a mere elusion an the omission in the statute to provie for the assessment of amages, where the efenant has jugment of restitution, is one caliing for’ prompt remey by the Legislature.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the court.
This was an action upon a proteste bill of exchange. The issue upon the plea of non-assumpsit, was submittte to the court sitting as a jury, an as no question of law was raise on the trial, it woul seem that the uly ascertaine fact in the case isr that the efenant i not unertake or promise as allege in the eclaration. The plaintiff, however, has brought the case here upon exception to the overruling his motion in the court bel.ow for a new trial. The testimony, epositions an exhibits set out in the bill of exceptions, sprea over near thirty pages of the recor, the whole of which might have been conense, on a case mae for this court, so as to present the single question, argue here for the appellant, into the following statement of facts.
Burr, a merchant of Batesville, having funs in the hans of Walton & Sheaffe, of New Orleans, rew a bill on them, which they accepte, an which came to the appellant by enorsement. The bill mature on the 17th May, 1846, which being Sunay,, it was uly presente to the acceptors an proteste for nonpayment on the 16th. The only proof of notice to the rawer is-that containe in the eposition of the notary, who states, “I ghve notice of such protest to the rawer by a letter aresse to him, bearing ate the same ay of the protest, an irecte to him at Batesville, Arkansas, which letter I eposite in the post office, in the city of New Orleans, on the 18th ay of May, 1846, in time to go by the first mail thereafter.” There was no evience as to the usual'times for eparture of the mail. It oes not appear at what hour, or whether any mail left New Orleans on Monay, by which the notice might have gone or at what time of that ay the notice was eposite in the post office.
Apart from the consieration that this court ought not to presume against the verict of a jury, or the court sitting as a jury, but rather in favor of it, so far as it might epen on the weight or creibility of testimony, an regaring iligence as a question of law, an giving the appellant the full benefit of the legal questions, by supposing the evience to be facts state, the question woul be whether the proof comes up to the mark of establishing ue iligence.
Accoring to the rule aopte by this court in Davis vs. Hanly, 7 Eng. 645, the holer was not oblige to eposit the notice in the post office on Monay in time to go by the mail of that ay, if it went out too early to allow notice to be prepare conveniently within .business hours, but he ha until a convenient hour of that ay, for putting the notice into the office, an the first regui ar mail thereafter, though it i not go out until the succeeing or some subsequent ay, woul be the next convenient or practicable mail; an the law woul hol this to be sufficient iligence on the part of the holer to charge the rawer. This is in accorance with the opinions of the court, in Lennox vs. Roberts, 2 Wheaton 373, as qualifie by the Bank of Alexanria vs. Swann, 9 Peters 33, an with that qualification now generally recognize to be the correct rule, that “a eman of payment shoul be mae upon the last ay of grace, an notice of the efault of the maker put into the post office, early enough to be sent by the mail of the succeeing ay,” unless the mail of the succeeing 'ay goes out at an unreasonably early or inconvenient hour.
But the burthen of proof being on the plaintiff to show iligence, it follows as a necessary consequence of that rule that it is incumbent on him to prove such facts as will bring himself within it, Downs vs. The Planters Bank, 1 S. & M. 276, else the result woul be toleration of a ifferent rule, that the holer or intermeiate enorser receiving notice, ha all of the succeeing ay after protest or receipt of notice within which to eposit notice in the post office, so that it woul be sufficient if it went out by the mail of the thir ay, which as we have seen, is not the rule aopte by this court, nor so far as we are aware, generally recognize, either in Englan or by the courts of this country.
Diligence oes not epen alone upon the fact of putting the notice in the post office in time to go by the mail of the ay succeeing the protest, because, if no mail leaves on that ay for the place to which the notice is irecte, it woul be sufficient to prove that it was eposite in the office on any subsequent ay, in time to’ go by the first regular mail which left after the ay of the protest. An uner the qualifie rule before state an a here to by this court, the test of ue iligence on the part of the holer is not merely the putting of the notice in the post office on the ay succeeing the protest, unless couple with the further proof that it was eposite in time to go by the mail of that ay, if one left uring convenient business hours, an if no mail left uring those hours, then the presumption woul follow, of course, in favor of iligence, that it was in time to go by the next regular mail after that ay. But in the absence of any such proof in the power of the holer to make, the presumption woul be against the exercise of ue iligence unless eparting from the rule, we aopt a ifferent one, i.e., that the notice is sufficient if put into the office in time to go by the first mail which leaves on the secon ay after the protest. The like presumption to be inulge against the party whose uty it was to make out a case in proof, woul have warrante the court below in inferring from the statement of the notary that he eposite the notice in the post office in time to go by the first mail that left after Monay, an not the first mail that left on Monay after the hour of putting the notice into the office; but upon the groun on which our ecision rests, all such critical construction of his statement becomes unnecessary. The proof is insufficient, because it fails to show irectly or by any fair inference that the notice was eposite in the post office in time to go by the first convenient mail, if any, which went out on Monay.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court!
It appears from the recor in this case that Pope, the intestate, execute his note to the appellant, which became ue on the 1st ay of July, 1844. That Pope ie on the 20th ay of July, 1845, an aministration of his estate was grante to the appellee on the 15th ay of August following. The claim having been probate, was exhibite to the aministrator oil the 29th ay of April, 1847, an rejecte by him. The plaintiff file the claim in the Probate Court on the 6th of July, 1847, an on the next ay, as shown by the recor entry in the Probate Court, the parties appeare, an by consent it was orere by the court, that the cause be continue until the next term. The cause was, at several subsequent terms, continue at the instance of the Bank, an upon her motion, successive writs of summons were sue out against the aministrator, one of which was returne serve on the 30th of July, 1849, an at the October Term, 1849, the parties appeare an the efenant entere his plea of the statate of limitations, to which the plaintiff joine issue, all in short by consent upon the recor, an the court sitting as a jury, allowe the claim, an classe it in the 5th class, to which the efenant excepte, an on his appeal to the Circuit Court, the jugment was hel to be erroneous, an atrial e novo aware, in which on the same state of fact, the court foun for the efenant on the issue between the parties an gave jugment accoringly, to which the appellant excepte.
As heretofore hel by this court, the appearance of the efenant, an his consenting to a continuance is a substantive act, ispensing with the service of process. Rogers vs. Conway, 4 Ark. 70. The efenant must therefore be consiere as having notice of the application for allowance to the Probate Court, an as being in court for all the purposes of the suit from that time forwar.
In the case of Etter vs. Finn, 7 Eng. 634, it was the opinion of the court, that, though as a general rule, where a statute commences running, it continues to run until the bar becomes complete, such general rule ha been qualifie by this court upon the authority of the ecisions in the courts of Marylan, Tennessee, North Carolina, Mississippi, an Alabama, as woulbe seen by reference to the case of Aikin vs. Bailey, 5 Eng. 584, where the eath of aparty has been hel to prouce a temporary suspension of the operation of the statute, for then there are no parties competent to be sue. As for instance, if the payer of a note shoul ie after the statute ha commence running, but before the statute bar ha mature, the time between the eath of such party, an the substitution of a new party, executor or aministrator, woul not be estimate in computing the time of the statute bar.
If, therefore, we are to regar the plea of the statute of limitations interpose, in short, by the aministrator’, as being the general statute of three years, the exceptions to the ecision of the Circuit Court must be consiere as well taken, because upon the facts proven, if the time between the eath of the intestate an the grant of aministration be exclue, three years ha not elapse from the accrual of the cause of action, until the institution of the suit ]oy the voluntary appearance of the aministrator in the Probate Court, an in this view of the case, the jugment of the Circuit Court is erroneous.
But the efenant coul have the benefit of the general statute of limitations as a plea thus informally interpose, only on the supposition that the claim was barre by that statute before the eath of his intestate. Because, although we have consiere the case with reference to the ecision in Etter vs. Finn, which was that upon the eath of the ebtor, the statute is suspene until the grant of letters, an then resumes its course, an have conclue that, even if governe by that ecision, the efence is not sustaine, yet in our opinion that case oes not furnish the rule of ecision.
During the present term, in the case of Walker a. vs. Byers, after a thorough examination of the subject, an a review of the previous ecisions of this court touching the point, we have solemnly hel that the two years statute of non-claim, gives the rule as to claims against the estates of ecease persons, an not the general statute of limitations; that is to say, that uner our a-, ministration system, as regulate by statute, when, a party ies, all subsisting claims against him, not then barre, are put on the same footing, an may be presente an allowe against his estate, at any time within two years from the grant of letters, an if not presente within that time are barre, without any saving or exception in favor of isabilities, an without reference to the length of time such claims might have ha to run as against living persons uner the general statute.
When we apply this rule to the facts of this case, it is beyon question that the claim was not barre; because the aministrator appeare in the Probate Court on the 7th of July, 1847, an within two years from the grant of letters, to resist the allowance an classification; he having rejecte the claim when it was presente to him uly authenticate on the 29th of April following.
The jugment of the Circuit Court must therefore be reverse, an the cause remane with instructions to affirm the jugment of the Probate Court.
Walker, J., not sitting.

case_name: Beirne & Burnside vs. Imboden et al. admr.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
It appears from,, the transcript that at the July term, 1851, of the Probate Court of Ranolph county, this cause originally came on to be hear “ in the matter of the presentation to the court by Beirne an Burnsie, of a claim for allowance an classification against” the efenants, as aministrators of the estate of Thomas O. Man*, ecease: An that, when the claimants offere to rea in evience the promissory note on which the claim for allowance was foune, the efenants objecte, an move the court to enter a jugment of non-suit against the claimants, because the claim in question ha not been properly authenticate an presente for allowance, which motion the court grante, an ajuge costs against the claimants.
The claimants took a bill of exceptions, an appeale to the Circuit Court for Ranolph county, an at the May term, 1852, the latter court, the cause having been hear on this bill of exceptions, an an assignment of the suppose error of the Probate-Court, the jugment was affirme with costs; an the cause has been brought here by writ of error.
It appears from the bill of exceptions that the note offere in evience was as follows, to-wit:
“ $872 64.
New Orleans, December 20th, 1848.
Six months after ate, we, or either of us, promise to pay to the orer of Beirne & Burnsie, eight hunre an seventy-two ollars an sixty-four cents, for value receive.
J. M. SHEPPERD,
THOS. O. MARR.”
An attache to it was an affiavit in the following wors,,to-wit :
STATE OF ARKANSAS,)
County of Ranolph. )
I, Thomas M. Cory, o solemnly swear that nothing has been-pai or elivere towars the satisfaction of the above eman,, except what has been creite thereon, an that the sum of eight hunre an seventy-two ollars an sixty-four cents, principal, an seventy-five ollars an sixty-one cents interest, above emane is justly ue.
THOMAS M. CORY.
Sworn to an subscribe before me, J. W. James, an acting Justice of the Peace, this 18th ay of July, 1850.
J. W. JAMES, J. P.
Upon which affiavit an note were the following enorsements, to-wit:
Presente, examine an rejecte this 15th of August, 1850.
J. H. IMBODEN,
one of the amlrs of the estate of Thos. O. Marr, ecease.

The statute of non-claim is like the statute of limitations that existe in early times in Englan; before the first general or prospective statute, in being temporary, an in running off from a fixe point of time; as from the first laning of 'King Richar, the 1st, an not unlike our earlier pre-emption laws.
