As a mere statute of limitations then, giving a rule of limitation which rums, not from the accrual of the cause of action, but from the granting of the letters, if the general statute still operate there woul be two limitations operating at the same time upon the same eman, one of which was foune on policy, which ha been itself entirely isplace by the substitution of a new system, esigne by irect means to effect at once the very object that the policy overthrown sought to achieve, by means of stimulating, merely, speey settlement between ebtor an cre^ itor.
This system, assuming to make all such settlements at once upon the eath of any ecease person, an forthwith taking the custoy of all available assets, calls for the exhibition of all subsisting claims, upon pain that all such shall be forever barre, if not exhibite by the expiration of the two years from the granting of the letters, an staying all process in the courts, except such as shall be neeful for the exhibition of emans. In effect regaring the whole perio, from the time of the eath to the expiration of the two yeai’s from the granting of letters, as a single point of time, for purposes of exhibition of claims subsisting at the time of the eath, or which may come into existence at any time before the expiration of the two years.
Uner such circumstances, to suppose there was any place left for the operation of the general statute of limitations, woul be to suppose that a rule base upon a particular reason coul properly have operation in a case without the reason, or coul exist where the reasons on which it reste ha no longer existence.An if this was not so, all that policy of our aministration system,which looks to the speey settlement of estates, that istributees an legatees may, as soon as practicable, be place in the enjoyment of their rights in the resiue, woul, in general, be entirely overthrown. We therefore think-this court was correct in coming to the conclusion, in the case of Erwin, use vs. Turner, surviving amr. (1 Eng. R. 14), that the general statute of limitations was esigne to operate upon the rights of parties while living, an was not esigne to apply after eath to claims against the estates of ecease persons, the statute of non-claim, as to such estates, giving the rule of limitation, an was wrong in holing the contrary, in the case of Etter vs. Finn, as amr., 7th English R. 632. Although the principle, for which the case of Aiken vs. Baily (5 Eng. R. 584), was cite as authority in that case, is unoubtely soun, an is applicable not only to the general statute of limitation, but also to the statute of non-claim, in a proper case, as where the first aministrator might ie, or resign within the two years, an some time might elapse before a secon aministrator shoul be appointe, the time uring which there was actually no aministrator, woul not be compute as a part of the two years.
We think that this court was also wrong in holing, in the cases of Burton, amr. vs. Lockhert, executor, 4 Eng R. 412, an in Allen vs. Byers, amr. (7 Eng. R. 593), that the statute of non-claim runs from the accrual of the cause of action upon the claims respectively. In the first case the claim sprung into existence from a ormant an contingent state, some time after the expiration of the two years from the grant of letters, an was therefore brre forever, as against an executor or aministrator, an coul only have been asserte, as against the heir or istributee, to be satisfie out of any resiue of estate escene or istribute. The secon case was where a security ha pai a ebt after the expiration of the two years, an was consequently a claim of the same escription.
If, however, he ha pai the ebt an exhibite his claim before the expiration of the two years, it woul have been entitle to share against the estate as other claims exhibite in ue time. The authorities, upon which the latter ecision was base, were from States whose aministration systems iffer from ours in taking the assets of an estate into the custoy of the law, only in cases where the.estate is insolvent, an where the statute of non-claim is not construe as isplacing the general statute of limitations as to claims not arrive at maturity.
In the light of these views then, it is clear that the ecree in this case cannot be sustaine upon the cross bill of Byers, because there is no pretence either that the cross bill was sworn to, or that it was file, until long after the expiration of two years from the grant of letters of aministration to Walker.
This first view of the case at bar having mae it necessary that we shoul examine the octrines iscusse in orer to etermine the two points settle, we will remark before proceeing to the next view, as they are questions of some importance, that we have examine them with care, an have not etermine them until after consiering their probable consequences. An in these we see no probable evils at all to be weighe against the manifest goo to be achieve by stimulating the speey settlement of estates, in accorance with the unmistakable spirit of our aministration system, palpably manifest.
In the next place, Byers insists, that as his answer to the original bill of Manning against himself an Walker, as aministrator, was uly sworn to; was file before the en of the two years from the granting of the letters, containe all the material matters subsequently set up in the cross bill, an was sustaine by' the proofs, that therefore the ecree in his favor against his co-efenant, Walker, can well rest upon these pleaings an proof,, irrespective of the cross bill, uner the rule, which uner certain-circumstances, allows of ecrees over between co-efenants, or of cross ecrees between them, foune upon the justice an: equity of the whole case. Such a practice is allowable when such cross ecrees can rest upon the matters state in the bill, an amitte by the efenant, sought to be change by his' co-efenant, either by suffering the bill to be taken as confesse, or by irect amissions in his answer."
But no case is cite that goes the length of allowing a ecree in favor of a efenant against his co-efenant, on matters state in the answer of the efenant, in whose favor the ecree is renere, which the efenant ecree against, ha no opportunity to respon to by pleaing an evience, as he woul have ha if thosfe matters ha been state in the original bill. An this is precisely the state of the case before us, an although Byers was entitle to a ecree against the plaintiff, Manning, for any balance foun in his favor, upon the settlement of the accounts which he ha emane by his bill, because by this eman of a settlement of accounts, he thereby gave a plege that he woul submit to a ecree for any balance foun against him. (Hoo & Wife vs. Lee, 5 Monroe's R. at p. 66). There was no-such plege, either express or implie, between Walker, as aministrator, an Byers, an Walker ha no opportunity to respon to any other than the matters state in the bill, while the-ecree against him is foune upon the matters state in the answer of Byers, to which he ha no opportunity to respons The general rule is istinctly state to be (Daniel's Ch. Pr. 3 vol. p. 1743), that “ one efenant cannot have a ecree against a co-efenant without a cross bill, with proper prayer an process, or answer, as in an original suit,” an a efenant can, in general, pray for nothing in his answer but to be ismisse the court. If he has any relief to pray for, he must o so by a bill of his own, or by answer in the nature of a cross bill, uner the provisions of the statute, Calhoun vs. Erwin, 4 Ala. R. 452. Cummins’ heirs vs. Gill’s heirs, 6th Ala. R. 562; Morehea vs. Prater an Smiley, 1 Bibbs R. 316; Shelby & Roberts vs. Smith’s heirs, 2 A. K. Marshall’s R. 514; Talbot vs. McGee, 4 Monroe R. 378), an if he seeks such relief against a co-efenant, by this statutory means, he must, after answering the original bill, procee to charge his co-efenant as he woul by a regular cross bill, an take steps to get his answer, because otherwise, although it might be in the nature of a cross bill, as against the complainant, it woul not be as against his co-efenant, (Talbot vs. McGee, 4 Monroe, 378, Shelby & Robertson vs. Smith’s heirs, 2 A. K. Marsh. R. 514.)
But in this case, if Byers ha shown himself to be within any exception to the general rule, thus lai own, so as to be entitle to a ecree against his co-efenant, Walker, upon the pleaings an evience, his ecree against Walker coul not be sustaine, because it woul have neither pleaings or evience to rest upon. The bill of Manning was not sworn to, an although Walker might be consiere as having waive this objection as to him, by reason of his never having in any way taken this specific objection to the proceeings by him, he cannot be suppose to have waive it as-to Byers, either as to the pleaings or the evience, because, in resisting the only apparent effort of Byers to seek a ecree against him as aministrator, he expressly interposes this specific objection, which in all fairness shoul avail him, as well when Byers falls back upon the bill of Manning to sustain his ecree to any extent, as when he relies upon his own cross bill. When then he is allowe the benefit of the objection to this extent, it cuts out the bill of Manning as- to Byers, an with it falls Byers’ answer, which is a epenancy, an even if the pleaings were not thus overthrown, all the evience in the entire case was, as in favor of Byers an against Walker, incompetent as to Walker, in the face of his specific objection, for want of authentication staning in the recor, an insiste upon at the hearing.
The ecree then against Walker, as aministrator, cannot be sustaine, either upon the cross bill, or upon the pleaings an evience in the original suit of Manning. It is therefore unnecessary for us to examine Walker’s thir groun of efence, which is that the claim for an account against him as aministrator, was not a subsisting claim or eman at the eath of his intestate, for the allege reason, that it was then barre by the lapse of time, within the octrines applie uring the present term of this court in the case of Aams, amr. vs. Cree Taylor.
We are of opinion, therefore, that so much of the ecree of the court below, as is against the appellant Walker, as aministrator, ought to be reverse an hel for nought, that the bill an cross bill, as to him, ought to be ismisse,, an that he shoul recover his cost. Let this be one an this cause remane to the court from whence it came with instructions so to reform the ecree of that court, that all of it that now appeal’s either against the appellant severally, or against him jointly with Manning, may be set asie an hel for nought, an the resiue of the ecree be so forme that it may stan an be execute as a several ecree against Manning.
Walker, J., not sitting.

case_name: State use Perryman vs. Stephens et al.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The action in this case was brought upon the official bon of a sheriff, against himself an his securities. After setting out the bon with its conitions, the plaintiff avers that Nancy Perry-man, for whose use the suit is brought, commence her action in replevin for slaves, against William Drew in the Sebastian Circuit Court, an sue out her writ of replevin, which, whilst in full force, was place in the hans of the qualifie eputy of sai Stephens, who was then sheriff of Sebastian county, by which he was commane that if the sai Nancy Perryman shoul give security as require by law, that he cause sai slaves to be replevie an elivere to her; that sai sheriff i, whilst sai writ was in full force, by his eputy, take sai slaves by virtue thereof into his possession. An the plaintiff then alleges, as a breach of the official uty of sai sheriff that he refuse to take bon an security as require by law, from sai Nancy Perryman; but frauulently intening to injure an cheat her out of the negroes, elivere them to sai Drew.
The secon count is in all respects like the first, with this ifference, that it is allege for a breach, that sai sheriff, by his eputy, took the slaves into possession, by virtue of sai writ, but woul not, an i not take bon from the sai Nancy Perryman as require by law, an wholly faile an refuse to o so.
To this eclaration a emurrer was file, the groun of which was, that the breach assigne in each is insufficient in this, that it was not sufficient to aver that the sheriff refuse to take a bon, fyc., or that he woul not take such bon, or i not take it, but that in orer to charge the sheriff for a breach of official uty, it was necessary to aver that the sai Nancy Perryman, or some one for her, execute an tenere such bon, as require by law, to the sheriff before he execute his writ, or took the property into possession uner it. The emurrer was sustaine by the Circuit Court, an the plaintiff having ecline to amen, final jugment was renere in favor of the efenants, from which the plaintiff appeale.
There can be no oubt but that the sheriff was not only not boun to take the property into possession, without first having the security require by the statute, but it was clearly his uty to esist from any attempt to execute the writ until such bon was tenere to him. The comman in his writ is conitional: that “if the plaintiff shall give you security,” &c., “you cause the goos an chattels to be replevie an elivere to the plaintiff,” &c.
The 10th sec. Dig. ch. 146, provies that such writ shall not be execute in any case, unless the plaintiff, or some other person in his behalf, shall execute bon, &c. An the 12th sec. provies “that upon the receipt of such writ an bon before require, the sheriff shall forthwith procee to execute such writ,” &c. No one can rea these sections without being satisfie that the sheriff exceee his power an authority in taking the slaves into his possession, without having receive the bon intene for the protection an security of the efenant, an that having one soj he was uner no obligation to retain the property so taken; inee, it was his uty at once to restore it to the efenant. The statute oes not require of the sheriff to prepare a bon, nor to eman one, but before he is authorize or require to execute the writ, it is the uty of the plaintiff to make, by herself, or some one for her, a goo an sufficient bon, conitione as require by the statute with sufficient surety, an to tener it to the officer. Then shoul he refuse or neglect to perform his uty he may be hel to account by the party injure; an shoul he, as in this instance, improviently take the property into his possession without first having receive such bon, (to place the case in the most favorable attitue for the plaintiff,) it was the plaintiff’s uty to prepare an tener such bon before the sheriff coul be hel accountable for not elivering the property to her.
The language use in the breach oes not necessarily imply that a bon was tenere. A “refusal to take a bon,” or in the secon count, “that the sheriff i not an woul not take a bon,” are not equivalent to a tener an offer of a bon, prepare as require by law. The grouns of the refusal or failure to take bon are not state. The plaintiff may have offere to prepare a bon, an the sheriff have ecline to hol up the property until it was one, or for other cause, an uner the rule'that the pleaer must be suppose to have presente the facts in the most favorable aspect for his client, we must presume that ha a bon been tenere an offere to the sheriff it woul have been so state.
We think the grouns for the emurrer well taken.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins.
This was an action of assumpsit with a count for professional services, the common money counts, an an account state, brought by Bertran against Mrs. Yiser, the plaintiff in error. The bill of exceptions isclose a claim for $150, charge as an attorney’s fee, an $300 money avance for her, an at her request.
The evience on the trial conuce to show the following state of facts. Bertran ha been the attorney of Mrs. Yiser in prosecuting a suit in the Pulaski Circuit Court, against her husban for ivorce, an for his services in conucting that suit, the fee of $150 was charge. It appears that Mrs. Yiser ha several negroes, which she claime as her separate estate, but in which Yiser also claime- an interest by virtue of his marital rights 1 Mrs. Yiser, the complainant, was living in LittleRock, an Yiser, the husban, was in New Orleans. A negotiation ensue between the parties to that suit, through the meium of their respective attorneys, the result of which was, in the language of Yiser’s attorney, the only material witness to this point, that “Mrs. Yiser’s attorney agree that she woul pay me $300 for Yiser, if he woul relinquish his claim to the negroes an make no further opposition to the ivorce, which as Yiser’s attorney, I accepte.” The attorney of Viser wrote to him at New Orleans, an obtaine his ee of relinquishment of the negroes. The ee was execute to Bertran, an elivere to him, with the unerstaning that, after the ivorce, he was to convey to Mrs. Yiser. Bertran on behalf of Mrs. Yiser, gave his obligation for the payment of the $300. Subsequently, in July, 1850, Mrs. Yiser obtaine a ecree in the ivorce suit, Yiser making no opposition. The payment of the $300, was elaye for some time after the ecree, the excuse being that Mrs. Viser ha not succeee in raising the money by the sale of one of the negroes, as was intene, an which she mae some efforts to o. Accoring to my unerstaning of the recor there was evience conucing to show that Mrs. Yiser, after the ivorce, requeste Bertran to avance the money for her, until she coul raise it by a sale or mortgage of one of the negroes, or from which the jury might have inferre the fact of such request, which however, I o not regar as material. Finally, Bertran, who, not long after the ivorce, ha pai $100 aboutthe first of February, 1851, close the matter by giving his note for the remaining $200 to Yiser’s attorney, who accepte it with the unerstaning that he woul pay it whenever calle on; the witness, however, up to the time of the trial, ha not calle on Bertran for the money. There was abunant evience showing that after the ivorce Mrs. Yiser, the efenant below, acknowlege her inebteness to the plaintiff for his fee, which was agree to be settle at $100 an also for the $300 avance or assume to be pai by him for her to Yiser, an that she, on several occasions promise to pay him those sums.
On the trial in the court below, various instructions were aske for, the repetition of which in etail as given, moifie or refuse, woul be as little calculate to eluciate the ecision here as they were the issues before the jury. The points mae on behalf of the efenant below were, as gathere from the instructions aske, that as the retainer of the plaintiff an the contract or agreement about the payment of the $300, ha their inception whilst the efenant was a feme covert, such contract was absolutely voi an not bining on her; an being so, no subsequent promise by her, after she became iscovert, without some new or further consieration was shown to uphol it, woul amount to a ratification, or make such new promise bining upon her in law Seconly, that the plaintiff coul not recover for money pai, as to so much of the claim for which he ha given his note, an which i not appear to have been pai. The court below seeming to regar these propositions as law, instructe the jury on behalf of the plaintiff, that if they believe from the evience that the efenant mae a new contract, after the ivorce was grante to her, upon a sufficient consieration, to pay the $300 an the fee, they might nevertheless fin for the plaintiff uner the count upon an account state, but upon the return of the jury reporting a isagreement the court appears to have charge that, although the original contract was voi in law, yet if she mae a new promise to pay since she was ivorce, the consieration receive by her uring coverture, is sufficient to sustain such new promise, which became bining so as to authorize a recovery against her in that action.
It is certainly a rule of the common law that the contract of a marrie woman is voi. Her legal existence becomes merge in that of the husban, who, as he assumes her ebts, acquires as it were, a ominion of her estate as well as her person. She coul make no contract, the enforcement of which might eprive the husban of her society, or which coul be obligatory upon her, because of the legal presumption that it was mae uner uress. The wife may impose a liability upon the husbanby acting as his agent, by his express or implie authority, but then the contract is his. The husban being liable for her support an maintainance. the law will oblige him to furnish it, an in case of his refusal, where necessaries are furnishe to her, the law imposes the obligation an implies a promise on his part to pay for them. It woul seem that her contracts are voi by reason of incapacity to contract, an not voiable like those of an infant, to whom the law affors a protection, of which he may avail himself or waive at his pleasure.
But it has long been the establishe octrine of courts of equity, that in regar to her separate estate, the wife may have rights inepenent of, an averse to those of her husban, which will be protecte, an her liabilities in respect of such estate, enforce in that forum. When we consier the increasing tenency of legislation in this, as in other States, to emancipate the wife from the ominion of the husban, by securing to marrie women their separate property, an authority to acquire an hol it in their own names, ischarge from liabilities incurre by the husban, it behooves us to enquire whether it be the policy or esign of such legislation to exempt the separate property of the wife from liability, though it might have to be'enforce in a court of equity» upon her contracts in respect of such property. Wherever there is free agency an sufficient mental capacity, the right to contract, an the power of alienation ought to be inseparable from the ownership of property. It may inee be limite within the perio beyon which, the restraint woul become obnoxious as a perpetuity, so that where a separate estate is settle upon a woman in contemplation of marriage, the terms of the settlement an the powers conferre by it might have to be pursue in orer to enable the woman to charge her estate; yet it cannot be sai to be the policy of the law in this country, that property shoul be tie up from alienation, or absolve from the just ebts of the real owner; an the statute enabling marrie women to acquire an hol property irectly, instea of through the intervention of a trustee, is one of the many eviences of the isposition to o away with the istinction between law an equity, or rather to require courts oí law, in all cases where they are capable of afforing aequate relief, to aminister law in the spirit of equity.
Supposing in this case the money to have been fairly avance or assume to be pai, for the purpose of securing to the woman her separate property, or to quiet by way of compromise any oubtful claim of the husban to the usufruct', I apprehen it is not questione; but that the claim of the plaintiff below was such as coul have been enforce in a court of equity, an uring her coverture as against the property. The parties were living apart, an the treaty was concerning her separate property. So far from the husban being liable, he was the averse party in interest, an the wife by her agent or trustee, was contracting with him. The attorney thus acting as her agent, woul have a lien in equity upon the property for the moneys avance at her request, to secure her in the ownership or enjoyment of it. Even the court granting the ivorce, if satisfie of the fairness of the transaction, might have mae a summary orer, requiring the money so avance to be refune, an charging the payment of it upon the property ecree to the wife. Because to the .extent that a feme covert is capable of contracting, in a court of equity, she stans on the same footing with other persons, an is regare as a feme sole, uner no isability whatever. In the case of infants, who o labor uner a isability, where they avail themselves of the privilege, any court having the power, woul compel them to surrener an avantage or make restitution of property, which woul cease to be theirs, an be unjustly retaine upon the repuiation of the contract by which it was acquire.
So, a reasonable compensation for his services, to the attorney of a marrie woman, is chargeable upon her separate estate. If the suit is for ivorce, the complaint on the part of the wife, selom mae out of levity, but more often resorte to as a esperate remey for intolerable wrongs, though not to be encourage, is so far favore, that the court to which she appeals will eneavor to place her upon something like an equality with the contesting husban. If she have no separate estate the allowance to her for maintainance pening the suit, or for alimony by the ecree, are funs out of which she might be require to compensate her attorney. To eny to her the power of bining her estate for the retainer of competent professsional ai, so far from being an avantage, woul be to isarm her in a contest alreay unequal^ an require her to come into court efenceless save as an object of sympathy.
I am clearly of opinion, that if the jury believe the facts which I suppose the evience conuce to prove, (leaving out of view another feature in the cause to be presently notice,) the plaintiff below was entitle to recover upon the express promise of the efenant after she became iscovert, without any new or further consieration for the promise being mae to appear: an I rest my opinion istinctly upon the groun that the promise was bining, not by force of any mere moral obligation resting upon her, but because the contract or agreement mae uring coverture, whereby she receive an avantage, an the plaintiff below suffere a isavantage, was of such a nature as to be vali an bining upon her estate as a feme covert an a sufficient consieration to uphol her promise as a feme sole.
I o not unerstan the case of Lee vs. Muggrige, 5 Taun. 36, an the cases which followe it, to have been oubte or overrule, except to the extent of the loose expressions containe in that case, to the effect that any moral obligation is a sufficient consieration to uphol an express promise. The law is now well settle the other way, an without tracing the course of the ecisions, a correct exposition of it is containe in the more recent cases of Eastwoo vs. Kenyon, 11 A. & Ellis 438, in Englan, an Greer vs. Archer, 2 Barbour Sup. Ct. Rep. 420, among many ecie in this country. Strictly speaking, á moral, istinguishe from a legal obligation, an where there never was anything more than a moral obligation, is never a sufficient consieration to uphol an express promise. Many instances may be imagine where a person of refine feelings an cultivate min woul hol himself, or consier another boun by strong obligations of gratitue, where voluntary compensation might well be mae, but where no promise for future compensation coul raise the uty to the slanar of a legal obligation. Such uties belong to that class of imperfect obligations, bining in conscience, but whiclffihejlaw'fioes nofrecognize an will not enforce, because it cannot appreciate the consieration, or estimate the amages for a breach of uty. Inee, no greater change in the fabric of the common law coul well be conceive, than for the courts to put moral obligations upon a footing of equality with valuable consierations to uphol contracts. Besies the vague an inefinite nature of such obligations, the liability to unjust preferences of them over creitors whom the law has recognize as more meritorious, will suffice without any further conjecture, to illustrate the startling consequences that woul result from such a change. The rule euce from a review of the cases containe in the note, so often cite an approve, to Wennall vs. Abney, 3 Bos. & Pul. 249, exclues the iea of a mere moral obligation as a sufficient consieration to support a promise, by confining its operation to those cases where there was a preceent goo consieration to support an express promise, or from which the law woul imply a promise, which might have been, or coul yet be enforce, but for the operation of some'positiverule of law, as for instance, a ebt once vali an subsisting, but ischarge in bankruptcy, or barre by limitation, or the contract, of an infant which he may confirm at majority.
It may somtimes be ifficult to istinguish, between what are legal an what are moral obligations, but when ascertaine, the istinction has no peculiar application to the contracts of marrie women, or their moral obligation for benefits conferre. It is applicable alike to all persons who have full capacity to contract. If the agreement of a feme covert to contract is vali, so as to be obligatory in equity, her promise after she becomes is-covert nee not epen upon the moral obligation; nor is the promise of one, not uner a isability, aie by any moral obligation where there never was a preceent goo consieration.
. It is true the original contract of the efenant below, while a feme covert, coul not have been enforce against her in an action at law; but if I am right in concluing that it was one for her benefit, which equity woul sanction an enforce in her favor an against her estate, it woul seem to be a technical an unfoune istinction to hol that there was no consieration to uphol her subsequent promise, because the original contract coul not have been enforce at law. I take it to be the spirit of the rule given in the note to the case in 3 Bos. Sf Pul., that wherever the promisee ha a right, upon a goo consieration, of which he might have availe himself, at law or in equity, against the promisor, an whether in the prosecution or efence of a suit, such right, though it has become unavailing, is a sufficient consieration to uphol a promise to continue or renew the former liability. The case of Littlefiel vs. Shee, 2 Barn. & Aol. 811, where the plaintiff, a butcher, ha supplie the efenant, when a marrie woman, with meat for her own use, while her husban was abroa, an after his eath she promise payment, oes ilot militate against the position that the efenant may be liable upon her promise in this case, because there, supposing the eclaration to have been free from any objection, the court must have hel that if anyboy was liable to the plaintiff it was the husban, it being in law his ebt an not that of the wife, for whose subsequent promise there coul have been no consieration beyon the suppose moral' obligation. So, in the case of Watkins vs. Halstea, 2 Saun. Sup. Ct. Rep. 311, where goos were furnishe to a marrie woman living apart from her husban, an having a separate property hel for her by a trustee, an after being ivorce from her husban, she promise to pay for the goos, the court say, “It is not pretene that inepenently of the express promise of the appellant, after she obtaine her ecree of ivorce, this action coul be sustaine. If when the ebt was contracte, when the goos were elivere any person was liable it was the husban. We see nothing in the case to exempt him from liability. The appellant was then a feme covert an clearly not liable. Her promise to pay was mae after she was ivorce, an if that promise is not supporte by aequate consieration, the action must fail.” Assuming therefore, at the outset, that the original promise was not bining on the wife, an never coul have been enforce against her, the court go into an examination of the cases an unavoiably conclue that the moral obligation resting upon her was not sufficient to support her subsequent promise.
The other point of law raise by the instructions, is settle by the ecision of this court in Neale vs. Newlan, 4 Ark. 506. See also Logan vs. Williamson, 3 Ark. 216. R. E. Di■gest 931. The statute is only cumulative, an the common law moe woul still be goo. But this instrument being estitute of either, coul not, in our opinion, operate to pass the legal estate. But the court shoul have allowe the proof, an if sufficient, have amitte the instrument, because there can be no oubt that it woul be competent evience uner the general issue, to at least show that the grantee ha lawful license an authority to enter on the freehol, erive from the owner, an coul not therefore be guilty of trespass any more than the legal owner of the freehol himself.
It is not conceive important to iscuss the instructions given or refuse, because we think it appears istinctly that the close mentione in the eclaration, was not the close of the plaintiff, that he neither ha the right of possession nor property, an therefore any instructions preicate upon the iea of his right to recover woul be in their nature improper. Asie from that, the first an thir instructions given for him are objectionable, because they assume the allege trespasses to have been prove, an whether they were or not, was a fact to be foun by the jury, an which the court ha no right to assume as establishe. Instructions shoul be hypothetical, an emboy in plain an succinct language, the true principles of law, applicable to the facts as evelope on trial; but not assume facts to be prove, because that is an invasion of the province of the jury. Eight instructions were aske by the efenants, two of which were given an the rest refuse. These instructions were base mainly if not entirely on the rejecte testimony, an shoul not have beep aske; but the efenants ought to have stoo on their exceptions to the rejecte testimony. A party has no right to instructions looking to or base on such testimony; because the instructions are just as abstract as if no testimony ha been offere an rejecte. If the testimony, which the court improperly exclue, ha been before the jury, the fourth, fifth an seventh instructions aske woul have fairly presente the law of the case, an the others woul have been unnecessary, an might for that reason have been refuse. To multiply instructions an put ieas in .every conceivable phase is a highly objectionable practice; because it increases the labor of the court, an has a tenency to confoun the jury, by making the impression on their mins that instea of one or two, they have many an ifficult issues to ecie.
These instructions woul necessarily put an en to the case an accor with the law; for a person having a right to enter on lan, is not liable in an action of trespass for entering even with force, Wile vs. Cantillion, I John. Cas. 123. Hyatt vs. Woo, 4 John. 150. 13 John. 236. McDougal vs. Litcher, 1 John. 44. No person can recover upon a claim of right to property against .another whose rights to the subject matter are superior to those .of the person so claiming amages for a violation of his suppose rights. If the entry is violent an with a multitue of people, it may be an offence for which the» party so entering must answer criminally, but it woul be an absui’ity to say that he must also be responsible in amages, as for an injury to a person who has no right. Per Spercer, J., in Hyatt vs. Woo, 4 John. 158.
In Tribble vs. Frame, 7 J. J. Marsh. 601, it is sai that, at the common law a person holing the title to lan an having the right of entry, might use actual force, if necessary, for overcoming any forcible resistance; because his right of entry being perfect, no other person coul lawfully resist him in the exercise of his perfect right. Now the right of entry in Floy was perfect from the 10th of August, 1848, an Ricks coul not rightfully oppose it; an the entry on the lan as actually mae by the Floys, seems to have been peaceable an orerly, an intene to secure an preserve the crop; most of which, however, was taken away by Ricks, who ha no right to it. The court shoul have grante the motion for a new trial on the groun of the improper exclusion of the evience before allue to.
This is a fit opportunity of averting to a practice which seems to have become prevalent in inferior courts, as it regars new trials. A motion for a new trial, in many instances, appears to be regare as a matter of form, an as a moe of saving the points accruing at the trial, an of putting a case in a proper attitue to be reviewe by this court. The party usually expects no benefit from it in the inferior court, an as it is mae without hope, it is enie without ue investigation. In view of the zeal of suitors, the want of time for eliberation, especially as to complicate questions, an the usual circumstances attening a trial at nisi prius, it is no imputation against the learning an ability of the respective presiing juges in those courts, to say that errors are almost unavoiable. But upon more mature eliberation they may an ought to be correcte in the tribunal where they were committe, without forcing the unsuccessful party into this court for reress. An the means of oing justice are more extene in the inferior than in this court, because, as it is the uty of the juge there, to observe an note the testimony an points uring the progress of the trial, he is presume to o so, an is through that meium cognizable of the whole case from beginning to en; the emeanor of the witnesses, an other circumstances calculate to have an influence on the verict. A motion for a new trial places the law an facts before him, unembarrasse by any question of power, an he is more likely to be able to correct injustice than an appellate court, because the latter acts only on questions of law, an cannot act on matters of fact, or isturb a verict on the mere weight of evience.
Reverse.
Watkins, C. J., not sitting.

case_name: Bankhead, ex. vs. Hubbard, et al.
text_content:
Hempstea, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The constitution of this State vests in the Probate Courts such jurisiction in matters relative to the estates of ecease persons, executors, aministrators, an guarians, as may be prescribe by law. Const, sec. 10, Art. 6. The aministration law authorizes the clerks of Probate Courts to grant letters testamentary, an of aministration, subject however, to the confirmation or rejection of the court {Digest 110), an requires bon from the person to whom letters testamentary or of aministration are grante with two or more securities, resients of the county, to the State of Arkansas, in such sum as the court or clerk shall eem sufficient, not less than ouble the amount of the estimate value of the estate. If the bon is taken by the clerk in vacation, it is subject to the approval or rejection of the court in term time. Digest, 112, 113. An as to securities, it is ^enjoine as a uty to take persons who are solvent an sufficient, an who are not boun in too many other bons, an testimony may be taken to ascertain these facts. An an aitional bon may be require in certain cases, an on failure to give it, the letters may be revoke. Digest 116.
These provisions speak for themselves, an are too plain to Require construction or argument. They inicate the general policy of' the act to be to require security in all cases. This security is for the benefit of creitors, heirs, evisees an legatees, an there are but few instances in which it shoul be ispense with. Perhaps, in the case of a sole heir or evisee, being appointe executor or aministrator, an no ebts against atf estate, bon an security nee not be given, because waste or mismanagement of the estate woul be guare against by motives of self interest, an in any event coul injure no one but himself, an there may be other cases within a similar reason.
But the case shoul be clear, because a oubt in the scale ought to operate in favor of requiring security, that being a general requisition, which the Legislature ha the power an thought proper to make. The clerk stans in a ifferent position from the court, an has, in our opinion, no iscretion on the subject, an must therefore take bon an security in all cases. His act must pass uner the review of the court, an must be confirme or rejecte. The court has iscretion, but the clerk none, an his act is merely ministerial/’
We are not to be unerstoo as eciing that letters grante without security are absolutely voi; because we o not eem the bon a conition preceent to the valiity of the letters. We think the statute is irectory, an that the court may, in some instances, ispense with security.
But in granting, rejecting, or revoking letters, or taking, or ispensing with security, or requiring new security, the Probate Court possesses uner the law a large iscretion; which will not an shoul not be controlle by this court, unless there has been such an outrageous abuse of that as to prouce manifest injustice. The case must be a strong one to call for our interposition.
In this case we regar the action of the Probate Court as entirely proper, an within the scope of its legal authority. But if otherwise, we woul not interpose for another reason, which is, that oral testimony might be taken on these investigations; an where, as in the case here, the bill of exceptions fail to show either expressly or by necessary implication, that it contains all the testimony auce on the investigation or trial, the presumption must be in favor of the jugment. Everett vs. Clements, 4 Eng. 480. Collins vs. McPeak, 4 Eng. 558. That is the settle law of this court, an is irectly applicable.
Watkins, C. J. not sitting.

Hon. Isaac Strain, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This is an action of ebt brought upon a writing obligatory for one thousan ollars. To this action the efenant below file several special pleas in bar. To all of which the plaintiff emurre, an the court below sustaine the emurrer; the efenant reste, an jugment was given for the plaintiff below.
The first plea sets up, “that the sai writing obligatory was execute an elivere in consieration that sai Thomas H. shoul obtain, an upon the supposition that he i then an there obtain a vali title to, an become the absolute owner of a certain negro slave name Manuel; an the sai efenant avers that sai Thomas H. i not, nor i any person claiming by, through or uner him, obtain or acquire a vali title to, or become the absolute owner of sai negro, an so sai efenant says, that the consieration of an upon which sai writing obligatory was given has faile; an this he is reay to verify, &c.
Whether the “sai Thomas H. receive a vali title an become the absolute owner of sai slave Manual,” is a question of law epening upon the facts of the case. These facts ought to have been set out in the plea. It shoul have shown how the title to sai slave Emanuel was invali, an the facts which preclue the sai. Thomas H. from becoming the “absolute owner.” Pleas alleging an “invali” or efective title, an that therefore the consieration faile, must set forth the particular facts showing how the title is invali, an wherein it is efective. Dickson vs. Burk, 1 Eng. 414. The plea is eviently efective an the emurrer was properly sustaine thereto by the court below.
The secon plea is the same as-the first with the aitional allegation: “That sai Ewars on the ay of the ate of sai writing obligatory obtaine possession of sai negro an hel him until the ay of March, 1851, when sai negro kille sai Ewars, an was afterwars, to wit: on the ay of May, 1851, for that offence, pursuant to the sentence of this court, capitally punishe an execute. An sai efenant avers that sai Ewars never i acquire a vali title to or become the absolute owner of sai negro, an that sai Ewars, in his lifetime, to to wit: on the 20th ay of Nov. 1850, pai to the plaintiff the sum of one hunre an fifty ollars upon sai writing obligatory, which sum was much more than sufficient to satisfy an pay for the hire an services of sai negro after sai Ewars so obtaine possession of him an for all benefit he erive from sai purchase.”
The matters an things containe in this allegation, instea of going to show that Ewars ha no vali title, amit an show that he i have a vali title to sai negro. In October, 1850, when sai writing obligatory was execute an elivere in consieration of sai negro Manual, the sai negro was elivere to sai Ewars, the venee, at the same time, án all the right an title of Gray an wife, the venors, to sai negro Manuel, then veste in sai Ewars; an the plea oes not preten to allege that any other person, at that time, ha any right or title to sai negro. The sai negro having subsequently kille the venee, an by the State convicte of murer therefor, an sentence to eath an execute, affors no efence to this action. It oes not ivest the venee of title, or rener the title invali, or affect it any Way. The venee took the negro subject to all subsequent casualties. The plea is ba an the court below correctly sustaine the emurrer thereto.
The thir an last plea is in substance the same as the first, with the exception that it alleges, “that the plaintiffs falsely an frauulently represente to sai Ewars, that he” (Ewars) “ha acquire a vali title thereto, an become the absolute owner of sai slave Manuel,” &c., without stating what the false an frauulent representations were, an why he i not acquire a vali title an become the absolute owner. It is therefore for the same reasons fatally efective, an the emurrer was properly sustaine thereto.
The allegations in these pleas, “that Ewars i not obtain a vali title to, or become the' absolute owner of sai slave Manual,” in the absence of all facts upon which such euctions may be preicate, is pleaing a euction of law, which is in contravention to the rules of pleaing. 1 Ch. Pl. 244, 245.
Let the case be affirme.
Wations, C. J., not sitting.

Mr .Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
Accoring to a settle octrine often heretofore applie in this court, the ecision mae when this cause was here before, is the law of the case, (5 Eng. R. 211,) an consequently nothing etermine can be now reviewe.
The evience exclue, both as to the suppose voi jugment an the process of execution thereof, an that going to show that the appellee was present at the sale of the negro in question, was properly exclue in conformity with the ecision heretofore mae in this cause, (ib. 211,) whatever oubt the court might now entertain as to either of these propositions. An even if we coul go behin that ecision, an were now to hol that the suppose estoppel coul have been as well set up in the court below on the law as upon the chancery sie thereof, the appellant coul not be consiere as having been injure by the exclusion of the latter evience, because it falls short of showing such a state of facts as woul amount to the suppose estoppel. Ha the exclue evience been amitte, all 'the evience in the entire recor tening to the point in question, so far from going to establish clearly, when consiere together, such facts an circumstances as woul have authorize the jury to presume that the purchaser was le into the purchase by reason of the presence of the real owner, aware of his rights, an by his silence or his other acts, or conuct; it conuces to show, with perhaps equal clearness, that he woul not have been eterre from the purchase by any thing that the appellee coul have sai on the occasion.
We think the instructions given were obnoxious, only to verbal criticism, if any, which coul not possibly have affecte injuriously the interest of the appellant. Certainly the suppose excessive generosity of the first instruction as to the possession of the son, by means of the possession of the father, is fully enough qualifie by the wors, “so long as they live together,” which follow, when consiere in reference to evience before the jury. An the fourth instruction, although broa enough in its terms to inclue all purchases an sales of personal property, whether mae by private or juicial sale, although exceptional in some cases that might be conceive, coul not possibly have mislea the jury in this case, where the contest is about a purchase an sale by juicial process in a cause, where the principle caveat erwptor ha been alreay ajuicate as applicable. (ib. p. 227.)
We think therefore, that there was no error either in the exclusion of the evience excepte to, nor any error, even unsubstantial, that coul have possibly affecte injuriously the appellant’s cause either in the instructions given or in those refuse. An fining the verict an jugment sustaine by the evience the jugment must be affirme.
CASES ARGUED AND DETERMINED IN THE SUPREME COURT OF ARKANSAS, AT THE JANUARY TERM, A. D. 1854,

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the court.
This is a bill brought by Higgins against Henry Johnson, Robert A. Johnson, Margaret Erwin, wiow, an Henry C. Erwin, an others, heirs at law of James Erwin, ecease.
On general emurrer the bill was ajuge insufficient for want of equity. Without going into the etails of the bill with its voluminous exhibits, the substantial allegations mae by the complainant are as follows:
That in 1838 he purchase of James Erwin a certain tract of lan, in Fayette county, Kentucky, for which he pai Erwin twelve thousan ollars : that Erwin execute his ee in fee, with covenants of seizin an general warranty for the same to the complainant, who entere into possession, mae improvements, an continue in possession until 1852, when he was evicte of one half of it by paramount title, an until about that time, he never suspecte any efect in Erwin’s title, who, when he sol to the complainant, was repute to be wealthy.
That in truth the lan belonge to the first wife of James Erwin, Anne B., to whom it ha been conveye by her father; so that James Erwin ha only a life estate, as tenant by the courtesy. That Anne B. ie leaving four heirs, Henry C., Lucretia, Eugene, an Ewin, who are living an are mae efenants to the bill; that the secon wife of James Erwin is Margaret, aughter of Henry an sister of Robert A. Johnson, also efenants. That in 1847 James Erwin was the owner of a large quantity oí lans situate in Phillips an other counties in Arkansas, an being then hopelessly insolvent, for the purpose of covering up these lans from the claims of his creitors, an securing the benefit of them to himself an family, he conveye them to Henry Johnson, who, soon afterwars, conveye them to Henry C. Erwin, who.execute a general power of attorney to James Erwin, uner which the latter, uring his lifetime, continue to control an ispose of them as if they were his own.
That all these successive conveyances were frauulent an colorable, mae without any consieration pai or expecte to be pai, with intent to hiner an efeat the claims of the creitors of James Erwin, an upon the secrét trust, that they shoul be hel for the benefit of his family, an that Henry C. Erwin is no w liable to be charge in equity, as trustee of the legal title to the lans for the benefit of the creitors of James Erwin. That in 1851, James Erwin, then repute to be without property of any escription, ie wholly insolvent an intestate, an no aministration has been ha of his estate. That he left several minor chilren, of his secon marriage, also mae efenants, an that none of the chilren an heirs at law of James Erwin have succeee to any property or estate by inheritance from their father. That in 1852, after the eath of James Erwin, Henry C. an Lucretia, two of his chilren by his first marriage, relying on the title erive from their mother, institute suit in the Fayette Circuit Court against the complainant, an obtaine jugment with an orer for a writ of possession against him for an univie two-fourths of the tract of lan in question, originally conveye to him, with warranty by James Erwin; that the suppose title, so pretene to be conveye, has faile, an the complainant is in aily expectation of being evicte by Eugene an Ewin, the two remaining heirs of Anne B. Erwin.
The bill prays for iscovery, an that the allege frauulent conveyances from James Erwin to Henry, an from Henry to Bobert A. Johnson, an from him to Henry C. Erwin, may be set asie an cancelle, an the lans embrace in them subjecte to, an sol for the payment of the ebts of James Erwin, particularly that of the complainant, for the amount of which, with interest, a ecree is praye against the efenants, to be ischarge out of the procees of the lans referre to, an for general relief.
Upon the case mae by the bill, the grouns of equitable jurisiction are, that for the want of any aministration upon the estate of James Erwin, there is no legal representative against whom the complainant’s right to compensation in amages for the breach of warranty coul be establishe by an action at law; an even if there was such representative, the remey woul not be complete or aequate; because amitting tbe title of the heirs of Anne B. Erwin, to be superior to that conveye by James Erwin, so that the complainant might have been entitle in equity, before the final payment or consummation of the purchase,' to a recision, an return of the money, yet it is questionable whether, having been only partially evicte, his remey at law woul not be confine to that position only. The effect of the covenant of warranty, as now unerstoo in this country, is that for the breach of it, the grantee is entitle to be compensate in amages, equivalent to a return of the purchase money, with interest, put of the general estate of the grantor, mae subject by law for ■the payment of his ebts; an in the event of his eath, to be establishe like other claims against his estate in charge of his aministrator, an no part of which can regularly go to the heir until after all the ebts of the ancestor have been pai. An though the weight of authority is, that while a jugment of recovery uner a better title is equivalent to an eviction, without the issuance of execution, or an actual turning out of possession, the grantor coul not maintain an action for a breach of the warranty, upon the bare fear or possibility of being sue or evicte by a superior title, so that, being evicte of part, he occupies the position oí a purchaser, who has only gotten a part of the lan he bargaine for, an so woul be entitle to go into equity for a recision; an he may well unite in that suit his claim to compensation in amages for the part of which he has been evicte. Besies, on the Supposition that the property of James Erwin has improperly gone into the hans of his heirs, without being first subjecte to a ue course of aministration for the payment of his ebts, an such is the attitue in which Henry C. Erwin, the principal efenant, stans on this recor, in the suit in equity to establish the claim an subject to its payment, the property in the hans of the heir, he cannot be regare as a stranger, though professing to hol by purchase an not by escent; because in such case the heir is only liable to be sue, because he has the assets, which, for any cause, cannot be reache by a suit against the aministrator, an it may be safely sai, that as a general rule, in view of our system of aministration, where the creitor is compelle to resort to the heir for payment of the ebt of the ancestor, his remey is in chancery rather than at law.
It will not be questione that where chancery once obtains jurisiction for some substantial purpose (apart from any oubt as to mere iscovery,) it will retain it for all purposes, so as to o complete justice between all the parties; an certainly it.woul be ifficultto suppose a case, where the exercise of such a jurisicl tion woul be more beneficial than the class of cases like the present.
There is nothing in Meux vs. Anthony et al., 6 Eng. 411, that ought to conflict with the opinion here. In that case, the facts were, that Royster ha mortgage certain personal property to Anthony an Perciful, to secure ebts he owe them, an pening suits brought by them to foreclose, an while the property was out of Royster’s possession, it having been place by the orer of the court in the custoy of a receiver to prevent its being waste or remove by him pening the suits, an while Royster himself was in prison, uner a writ of ne exeat, issue in one of those suits, he execute a bill of sale of the property in controversy to Meux, expresse to be in payment of a ebt ue to him, by Royster, an Meux thereupon file his bill to arrest the foreclosure suits of Anthony, on the groun that Royster never was inebte to him, an that the mortgage was execute without consieration an with intent to efrau Royster’s creitors; The court there o not seem to have consiere the allege purchase by Meux as either fair or vali; because as the lawful purchaser, no goo reason is perceive why he might not have gone into equity to impeach an set asie any prior frauulent sale or contract respecting the same property, which was a clou upon his title to it; but the opinion of the court, on the question here involve, is preicate upon the iea that Meux was a creitor of Royster, having a claim against him of a purely legal character, which he was seeking to enforce, an obtain satisfaction of it out of the property in ispute. Wherever the remey is purely legal an aequate in a court of law, the rule is believe to be without exception, (See Brinkerhoff vs. Brown, 4 Johns. Chy. 671.) that the creitor must not only establish his claim by obtaining jugment at law, but he must pursue it to execution, an perhaps to a return of nulla bona, before he can invoke the ai of a court of equity to assail any prior conveyance to a stranger on the groun of frau, or enable him to reach any equitable estate or creits of the ebtor intangible at law. The cumulative remey by statute regulating creitor’s bills is to the same effect. In the subsequent case of Williams vs. Bizzell et al., 6 Eng. 716, where this principle was applie, the complainant, Williams, instea of exhausting his remey at law, faile to show that he was even a creitor by having pai the ebts for which he was only liable as security.
Another cause of complaint state in the bill remains to be notice. The complainant alleges that, in April 1851, he purchase of James Erwin two tracts of lan in Phillips county, of which he suppose Erwin to be the owner, but when he emane a ee, to his surprise, it was mae to him by Henry C. Erwin. That he ha pai his acceptance in favor of Henry O. Erwin for the purchase money, the raft having come to the hans of the efenant Margaret, who presente it for payment. That those two tracts were parcel of the lans inclue in the frauulent conveyances, allege to have been mae by James Erwin through Henry an Robt. A Johnson, to Henry O. Erwin. Both causes of complaint are covere by the same prayer for relief.
The fact of this money having come to the hans of Margaret Erwin, might be a circumstance in evience, tening to show the real nature of the transactions allege to be frauulent; but if'the complainant purchase these two tracts in goo faith, for aught that appears on this bill, he acquire agoo title, which is notin anger of failing.
As to this part of the bill, the ecision of the chancellor was right; but for the error in eciing that there is no equity in the bill, the ecree must, for the reasons before state, be reverse, an the cause remane for further proceeings.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This was an action of covenant, brought by Williams against Green, upon an article of agreement entere into between them on the 6th of October, 1852, for the sale of a tract of lan an improvements: the substance of the agreement, so far as necessary to be here state, being, that Williams trae an bargaine to Green a certain tract of lan, containing forty-five acres more or less, the price to be thirty ollars per acre for the lan, with the aition of the value of the improvements upon it, such valuation to be mae by two persons name in the article, an for which payment was to be mae in goos of Green, then in store, consisting of groceries, harware; &c., at the original cost, with the aition of freight on certain of the articles, an the balance of the payment for the lan to be mae in goo mules at cash valuation. The. agreement conclues as follows : “In wtness of the above trae we hereby set our hans an seals, an on forfeiture of complying with it on the part of either Green or Williams, we hereby bin ourselves, our heirs, &c., in the sum of five hunre ollars, to be well an truly pai. In testimony whereof, &c.
The eclaration, after setting out the execution of the agreement, procees to aver that Waters an Grayson, the persons name therein, value the improvements referre to, at a certain sum of money, of which the efenant ha notice, an that, on the 20th ay of the same month, Williams an wife mae an acknowlege their ee of conveyance in fee, of the lan an improvements to Green, expresse to be for the gross consieration of $1,636, with covenant of general warranty an relinquishment of ower, an tenere the same to Green, who refuse to-accept it, or to comply in any respect with the agreement on his part. Therefore, accoring to what seems to be the intention of the pleaer, though somewhat inartificially expresse, the plaintiff cl aims to recover the specifie sum of five hunre ollars agree to be pai by either party, on forfeiture of complying with the trae.
The case went off in the court below upon emurrer sustaine to the eclaration. One of the causes assigne for insufficiency, an again insiste upon here is, that the eclaration avers a tener of the ee by the plaintiff to the plaintiff. Supposing this allegation to be in any way material, the whole tenor an the immeiate context of the eclaration show it to have been a mere clerical misprision, the amenment of which, if any amenment was neee, coul occasion no surprise to the efenant; an the objection is only notice because it has been urge by counsel.
But uner the clause of general emurrer, an treating the action as being brought to recover the sum of five hunre ollars as stipulate amages, the question arises upon the construction of the instrument sue on, whether it was the intention of the parties to liquiate the amages consequent upon the failure of either party to comply with the agreement, or whether the clause quote was esigne as a mere penalty.
If there is any branch of the law, sometimes inveighe against for uncertainty, eserving of such a reproach, it is the subject we have here to consier. An though amonishe by the caution evince by other courts of the anger of attempting to lay own any general rule for cases of this escription, it seems to be necessary, in orer to explain the grouns of our ecision, to notice, albeit in a cursory an unsatisfactory manner, the principles which may affect the question to be ecie.
Anciently, at the common law, the penalty name in a bon was a security for the performance of the conition annexe to it. Upon forfeiture of the conition the obligee was entitle to recover the penalty, which was at the same time the utmost limit an beyon which the obligor’s liability coul not be extene. To obviate the harship an injustice often growing out of this stubborn rule, arose one of the early jurisictions of courts of equity, to relieve against penalties an forfeitures, by ecreeing that the jugment for the penal sum shoul stan as a security for the payment by the obligor of such amages as the obligee ha actually sustaine, of which an account woul be taken. Such steps can be taken in the Circuit Court only in the absence of statutory regulations, touching such cases, of which we have none, beyon the act of the 21st December, 1846, (Dig. p. 313, sec. 12), investing the Circuit Court with intermeiate appellate power, but making no regulations for its exercise.
Until the Legislature shall think proper to make such regulations, the Circuit Courts, at the instance of parties, must use their common law an other means known to the law, to give effect to these intermeiate appellate powers thus investe in them as (Carnall vs. Crawfor county, 6 Eng. The process in the Circuit Court performing the functions of a writ of error, (ib. at p. 614).
Neither the constitution nor any statute of this State invests the county court with exclusive j urisiction in matters of public roas, close to superior review; on the contrary these courts are oubly open to the primary review of the Circuit Courts clothe, as they are, with constitutional power of superintening an statutory power of intermeiate appeal. There is no oubt but that the slaves were inherite by the wife, an- hel by her uner the provisions of the act of 1846, uner a substantial compliance with the provisions of that statute. u
But the question is, whether the statute exempts them from, liability for the payment of this ebt, which was contracte before the estate veste in Mrs. Lovette, an before the scheule-was file in the Recorer’s office.
The first section of the act permits the wife to hol property,, real or personal, by bequest, evise, gift or istribution in her own right an for her own use, except such as may come from the husban after coverture. The secon section continues the title of slaves in the wife which she hel at the time of her marriage, notwithstaning her coverture, an allows her to hol an possess the same as her separate property, exempt from any liability for the ebts or contracts of the husban. The thir section confers a like right to property thus acquire before the passage of the act from the payment of ebts contracte after its passage. The 9th section provies that “before any marrie woman can avail herself of the privileges an benefits of this act she an her husban shall make out a scheule of the property erive through her, uner oath, which shall be verifie by the oath of some other reputable person, which scheule shall be file in the Recorer’s office, of the county within which the property is, as well as in which they live.” An then the 8th an last section provies that “the operation of this act shall not interfere with the collection of ebts alreay contracte by any marrie man, or which shall hereafter be contracte before the filing of the scheule referre to in the preceing section.” These are the material provisions of the statute, an although the secon section provies in general terms, that the wife shall hol such property exempt from any liability for the payment of the ebts or contracts of the husban, still the 8th an last section in express terms, eclares that this act shall not interfere with the collection of ebts alreay contracte by a marrie man, or which shall afterwars be contracte before the scheule provie for in the 7th section shall have been file, which filing is a pre-requisite to the enjoyment of the benefits of the act. In the case uner consieration tbe ebt was not only contracte before the passage of the act, an consequently the filing of the scheule uner it, but also before the inheritance escene to the wife, an therefore comes irectly within the provisions of the 8th section, unless we coul, as contene for by the appellants, construe this section so as to make it apply to contracts entere into upon the faith an creit of this property whilst in the joint possession of the husban an wife, an before the scheule ha been file, as require by the provisions of the 7th section. But the 6th an 8th sections were eviently intene as limitations upon the general terms of the secon section, particularly the 8th, which is clear an explicit in its terms, an is esigne to limit the operation of the preceing sections. There is nothing ambiguous or oubtful in the language use, an when such is the case there is no room for construction ifferent from the plain language use. It follows, therefore, from the conclusions at which we have arrive, that the slaves, although no oubt exempt from the payment of ebts contracte by the husban after the scheule of the slaves ha been file in the Recorer’s office, were nevertheless liable to the payment of this, it being a ebt contracte before the passage of the act of 1846, uner which the wife claims protection for the property.

The efenant was inicte in the Yan Burén Circuit Court for an assault an battery, allege to have been committe on the person of one William York. At the foot of the inictment there ■is the following enorsement: “ This inictment is preferre upon the testimony of the party injure, who was summone on presentation an by orer of the gran jury.
JOHN H. BYERS, Pro. Atto.”
The question is, was this enorsement sufficient uner the 87th sec. Dig. ch. 52. That section provies that “ No inictment for any trespass on the person or property of another, not amounting to felony, shall be preferre, unless the name of the prosequtor be enorse thereon, except where the same is preferre on the information or knowlege of one or more of the gran jury, or on the information of some public officer in the necessary ischarge of his uty, or on the' testimony of some witness other than the party injure, in which case a statement of the fact shall be mae at the en of the inictment an signe by the attorney for the State.”
The enorsement in this case falls short of a compliance with the statute. The fact that the witness was summone to testify, was not sufficient to supersee the necessity of his enorsement as prosecutor. If the party assaulte was permitte thus to evae the statute, he woul rarely incur the responsibility of paying the costs of the prosecution, in the event of an acquittal, by enorsing himself as prosecutor, when by procuring himself to be summone, he coul by his testimony put on foot a prosecution intene to gratify his private resentment without incurring such responsibility.
It may sometimes be the case that the party injure is the only witness by whom the offence can be proven, an that, because of his refusal to become prosecutor, the offener may go unpunishe; but we apprehen that cases of this kin will be rare. The language of the enorsement is somewhat peculiar; it is that “the inictment is foun on .the testimony of the party injure, who was summone upon presentation, an by orer of the gran jury.” This language strongly implies that the gran jury were informe, or ha knowlege of the fact, an upon such information summone the witness. If such was the fact an their information was sufficient to satisfy them, that an inictment shoulabe preferre, the enorsement woul have been sufficient, if it ha simply state the fact that it was foun upon the information of one or more of the gran jurors. But in the case before us, it is expressly state that the inictment is foun upon the testimony of the party injure, an the resiue of the enorsement is intene to show how an uner what circumstances he was brought before the gran jury. The enorsement was clearly insufficient, an the motion to quash properly sustaine.

•The bills charge Cockrell with a frauulent esign to efeat the collection of the eman by the removal of his property beyon our jurisiction before the creitor coul have any available an aequate remey at law.
