The court, on the motion of Lavine, instructe the jury, that the instrument sue on furnishe sufficient evience to them of inebteness without looking to any other testimony, an refuse, at the request of Owen, to instruct, that in orer to entitle the plaintiff to recover, he must prove that efenant got possession-. of the procees of the crop of cotton mentione in the raft sue on.
The raft or orer, in question, was not a bill of exchange, accoring to the law merchant; because it was rawn payable upon a contingency; that is, out of a particular fun, which the rawee might not have on han, belonging to the rawer, or which might prove"eficient in amount, an coul not be put into circulation as a negotiable instrument, payable at all events, an base on the personal creit of the rawer. So it was rule in Hamilton vs. Myrick & Williamson, 8 Ark. 541, where, apart from other questions there involve, the case may be thus state; that Hamilton mae an orer in writing upon his merchants in New Orleans, irecting- them to pay to one Poor or orer, a certain sum of money, “out of the money receive on my account from the insurance office when collecte;” an which orer Poor enorse to, Myrick, who sue Hamilton upon it, alleging that the merchants, to whom the orer was aresse, ha collecte the money in question from the Insurance Company; but that they refuse to, pay the orer, when presente to them for payment, whereupon it was proteste, an of which Hamilton ha ue notice, &c. The court there hel that uner the statutory provision, Digest 25, section 14, the term “bill of exchange,” as use in that act, shoul be so construe as to inclue “all rafts or orers, rawn by one person on another for the payment of a sum of money specifie therein,” i not mean to imply that the fun might be contingent, or to make any change in the law merchant as to the essential requisites of a bill of exchange; an so it might be questionable whether that provision woul have the effect to exten the rules applicable to bills of exchange, to checks on bankers an the like.
An in Gwin vs. Roberts, ib. 72, Roberts ha rawn an orer on Saugrain, requesting him to let one Chambevs have thirty oR lars in merchanise, out of his store; Chambers assigne the orer to Gwin, who presente it to Saugrain, an he refuse to accept or pay it. Gwin sue Roberts upon the orer, an the «court there hel that it coul not be regare as a bon, bill, promissory note, raft or orer, within the operation of the law merchant, or any statutory provision in force in this State, or assignable, so as to vest in the assignee a legal right of action against the rawer, an intimate that the plaintiff ha misconceive his remey — that is, we infer, he might have sue Chambers to recover back the consieration pai him for the assignment, an Chambers, in turn, woul have ha a like recourse upon Roberts, the rawer.
In both of those cases the orers, not being bills of exchange, an not having been accepte by the rawees, were incomplete as assignable contracts. But the statute of assignments (commente upon in Walker vs. Johnson, 13 Ark. 522), makes all bons, bills, notes, agreements an contracts in writing for the payment of money or property assignable, so as to enable any assignee to sue for the same in his own name, an so having the legal interest ’he must sue, as hel in Block vs. Walker 2 Ark. 4, followe in several cases. True, the law merchant is, to a certain extent, introuce by the 9th section of the statute concerning assignments, but the octrine of assignments, an the rules of the law merchant are essentially ifferent, as notice in Walker vs. Johnson. That section makes enorsers or assignors, upon receiving ue notice of non-payment, primarily liable to the holer of “ any instrument in writing, assignable by law for the payment of money alone.” Upon the construction of this section, cai'rying out the principle asserte by Hamilton vs. Myrick an Williamson, in regar to bills of exchange, it might be proper to hol that promissory notes, payable upon a contingency, are not negotiable accoring to the law merchant.
But that issue is not the question here. A promissory note, or any other contract in writing, though not negotiable because payable in property or upon’a contingency's nevertheless assignable, so as to vest a right of action in the assignee against the maker or obligor. That such is the law in this State has never been oubte. The broa an comprehensive terms of the first section of the statute of assignments oes away with the common law octrine of maintainance as to all the instruments in writing embrace in it. Supposing the term “bills” there use oes not mean a bill of exchange or orer, but bills single, or seale notes, as they are sometimes calle in the western States, yet accoring to the spirit of the statute, the instrument here sue upon must be regare as a contract or agreement complete by the acceptance of Owen, assignable by law, an upon which, for' any breach of it, he is liable to any holer or assignee. It oes not follow that upon such a contract the payee or enorsee coul hol the rawer, or any intermeiate assignor primarily liable upon notice of non-payment by the acceptor. But the contract here is the same in effect, as if Owen ha mae his promissory note payable to Foster, in property or upon a contingency, an Foster ha assigne it to Lavine. There is no reason for allowing the acceptor, who intene to become the principal ebtor, to repuiate the contract because of the shape in which he chose to make himself a party to it. If the instrument in question was any contract at all on the part of Owen, then accoring to our statutory rules of practice, it importe a consieration, an the execution of it nee not be prove, unless enie by plea uner oath; so that it was properly mae the founation of the complaint, an the Circuit Court ecie correctly in amitting it to be rea as part of the plaintiff’s case before the jury. No importance is attache to the circumstance, which, however, exists in this case, that the suit, having been commence before a justice of the peace, formal pleaings are not require, an no question coul arise as to the form of the eclaration.
The opinion here expresse is irectly oppose to the ecision in Hawkins vs. Watkins, 5 Ark. 481, followe by Henry vs. Hazen, ib. 401. In the first case, leaving out of view any question as to the insufficiency of the eclaration, for counting on the instrument in form as a bill of exchange, an omitting to aver the value of Arkansas money, the court rest their ecision on the groun, that a raft payable in Arkansas money cannot be mae the basis of an action against the acceptor of it. The gist of the reasoning is a re-affirmation of that in Hamilton vs. Myrick & Williamson, an Gwin vs. Roberts, where it was right, because the orers there never were accepte, an clearly the instruments were not negotiable as at the law merchant, to charge the rawer or enorser, on notice of non-performance by the rawee. In Henry vs. Hazen, the orer was rawn by one Hutchinson on Hazen, requesting him to pay Henry a certain sum of money, “as soon as you receive the amount of my account with the government from Capt. Wm. Armstrong,” an Hazen accepte it on the conition that the account was not curtaile below his own account an notes, meaning, as may be suppose, what Hutchinson alreay owe him. The eclaration containe two counts, one on the instrument an the other for money ha an receive. The court consiere, that such an instrument, “though not vali as creating any legal liability against the parties to it, is yet competent written evience of the acceptor’s liability uner the count for money ha an receive, in connection with other proof to establish the happening of the contingency, upon which the acceptor was to pay:” an the jugment was reverse, because the court below refuse to permit the plaintifF to auce evience, uner the common count, of the state of accounts between Hazen an Hutchinson, in orer to show' that the contingency ha happene, upon which Hazen woul become liable; an this was carrying out the intimation in Hawkins vs. Watkins, that the bill there sue upon coul be mae available in another form of action as evience. So that, after all, the question was not so much as to the liability of the acceptor, but whether he coul be sue in a particular form of action. On the other han, in Hawkins vs. Watkins, it is sai that though the acceptor woul not be liable as such, upon an orer payable in property, yet a note for property woul be assignable, because the payee has a right'of action on the privity of contract.
Now we take it that if Hawkins or Hazen, in the cases referre to, were liable at all, or in any form of action, to the payees or assignees of those rafts, it was not because of any privity of contract or consieration, passing between them, but solely by virtue of the statute of assignments, an upon the written contract of acceptance. . The innovation mae upon the common law by bills of exchange, the theory of which is a transfer, by the rawer, of a sum of money which the rawee owes him, to the payee, epene solely on their negotiable character by the law merchant, an in orer to make such transfer effectual to the rawee or any remote enorsee, without any new consieration or privity of contract, between the acceptor an any holer, they must have certain requisites, unerstoo an settle by the law merchant. If A accepts B’s orer in writing, to pay C, but upon remote conition, or contingency, or for property, it oes not operate as a bill of exchange to transfer any right to C, to eman the money or property of A. So, since the statute of Anne, a note for property, or for money, payable upon a contingency, woul not be a promissory note having any negotiable qualities, but only a parol contract in writing, which oes not import a consieration, an coul not be the founation of an action. But when, by the statute, all contracts in writing for money or property import a consieration, an are the founation of the action, an are mae assignable at law as in equity, no istinction is perceive between the contract of an acceptor an the maker of a bon or note for property or payable on a contingency. In either case the liability of the maker or acceptor, oes not epen upon the law merchant, an it woul be singular if it i. Such instruments are not commercial paper, an no question can arise as to the liability of the rawer or enorser, on notice of nonpayment. But the maker or acceptor having boun himself by a vali contract in writing, just such right of action as the payee or obligee has on the instrument, may be transferre by the assignment to any thir person, though he be an entire stranger to the original consieration.
The soli objection to the policy of the whole octrine of assignments, as regulate by statute, an an entire innovation upon the common law, is that it opens up controversies between the assignee an the obligor or promissor, respecting his equities as against the obligee an assignor, growing out of transactions to which the assignee is a stranger, an in a suit to which the assignor is not a party; an where the obligation itself is contingent or conitional, a variety of what may be terme collateral issues, are liable to spring up. Thus in Henry vs. Hazen, the court appear to have ha no hesitation in allowing Henry to go into proof of complicate transactions between Hutchinson an Hazen, the rawer an acceptor of a raft payable on certain contingencies, in orer to show that they ha happene. As to that part of the ecision there, we must conclue that if Hazen was liable on these transactions to a stranger, it was by virtue of his written contract, which the statute mae assignable.
It follows that the court below erre in instructing the jury, that the instrument sue on affore sufficient evience of inebteness, without looking to any other testimony. The plaintiff coul only recover by proving, an in a formal eclaration he woul have so to aver, that the efenant ha receive the procees of the crop of cotton in question to an amount sufficient to pay the raft. But for the contingency of the fun the instrument woul be a regular bill of exchange, an upon the facts proven the plaintiff was clearly not entitle to recover.
For this error the jugment will be reverse, an the cause remane for farther proceeings.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
Owen an Norris execute their writing obligatory to John H. Cornish, as guarian of Virginia E. Tobin, who, by his written enorsement thereon, assigne it to Gentry, the plaintiff. The efence set up by the plea is, that before the assignment by Cornish to Gentry, Cornish ha cease to be guarian, an that Ewar P. Tatum was, at the time the assignment was mae, an continue to be the guarian of sai minor, an as such ha, at the time of the assignment of the bon to the plaintiff, an yet has the legal right of action in sai bon.
Upon emurrer to the plea this efence was hel by the Circuit Court goo, an upon exceptions to the ecision of the Circuit Court, its legal sufficiency'is presente for our consieration.
The authorities, cite to show that when an aministrator is remove, his successor in aministration (the aministrator e lonis non), succees by operation of law to the legal rights of his preecessor in office, sustains the argument of counsel in regar to such rights as vest in the aministrator, alone by operation of law; as for instance, where a note or bon is execute to his intestate an comes to the han of the aministrator as assets. The right of action woul, in such case, vest in him by operation of law, in virtue of his office, an if remaining in his hans unaministere upon until isplace, woul, in like manner, pass to an vest in his successor in office. But where the contract (as in this instance) is mae after aministration with the aministrator, (although in regai- to a subject matter properly assets in his hans), he acquires a legal right in the chose in action by contract, annot by operation of law. For this reason ithas been hel by this court, that where a note or bon is mae payable to an aministrator, as such, he may at his election sue upon it in either his iniviual or his representative right, (Hemphill vs. Hamilton, 11 Ark. 425), an in case the suit shoul be Commence by the first aministrator in his iniviual right, the action coul not be revive an continue in the name of his successor, the aministrator e lonis non. So that, amitting the strictest analogy to exist between the legal rights an power of aministrators an guarians, as the bon in this case was execute to Cornish as guarian, he by his assignment to the plaintiff electe to treat an hol it as a ebt ue to him in his iniviual right, as fully as if he ha himself sue upon it in such right.
But counsel seem to have overlooke the marke ifference which exists between aministrators an guarians in respect to the source an extent of their respective powers an uties. It is by operation of law that aministrators represent the intestate himself, succee to his lights an,-to the extent of assets, to his-liabilities. But the guarian oes not succee to the legal rights of the war; by virtue of his guarianship he becomes the author-' ize agent of the minor to protect his person, an to take care of an manage his property, the legal title to which is not in him but in his war, an in whose name contracts are mae, an suits touching his rights are prosecute. Upon a change of guarians the property, the legal title in which still remains in the war, passes to the new guarian, whose rights an uties are co-extensive with his preecessors.
But as respects choses in action, execute to the guarian in consieration of the loan of money, hire of slaves, rents, &c., the-contract having been mae with him, he is thereby investe with the legal-right to the chose in action, which he may well pass to another by assignment, or he may turn it over to his successor as-part of his wars’ estate, who may, at his option, accept it as such, but in that event, we apprehen that, shoul the new guarian sue upon such bon, unless assigne to him, suit shoul be-brought in the name of the first guarian, in whom the legal title; woul still exist. Thus, in the case of Pon vs. Curtis, 7 Wen. 45, where a covenant for the payment of rent was taken to the* guarian, whilst his war was a minor, it was contene that suit-shoul have been brought in the name of the war, he having, 'arrive at mature age before the suit was commence, it was hel that the suit v;as well brought in the name of the guarian.
From the view thus taken of the case, it follows that the plea-was clearly insufficient, an that the Circuit Court erre in overruling the plaintiff’s emurrer to it. Let the jugment be reverse, an the cause remane for further proceeings therein,, to be ha accoring to law.

case_name: Welch et al. vs. Cole et al.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellants, in right of the petitioner, Ann Welch, file their petition to the Union Probate Court against the aministrators an heirs at law of Joseph Rhem, ecease, for ower in the estate of sai ecease.
It is allege that the estate consists of lans, slaves, an personal estate, now in the aministrator’s hans, an also a large amount of money, arising from the hire of the slaves, in all of which she claims ower. That the estate is solvent, an uner the statute, she is entitle to receive, out of the goos an chattels of the estate, over an above her ower, the sum of $ 150, at the appraise value thereof; an prays that the aministrators be mae to account an that ower be assigne her.
The aministrators answer, to which a special replication is file, by which issue is taken to so much of the efenant’s answer as enies the right of the petitioners to ower in the slave Cato, name in the petition, an to so much of the answer as relates to the hiring of the slaves, an the sum for which the aministrators shoul account.
The case was trie upon petition an answer.
Upon the hearing of the case, the Probate Court refuse to allow the wiow ower in the slave Cato; an also refuse to charge the aministrators with such an amount of hire as petitioners thought themselves entitle to receive.
From the ecision an jugment of the Probate Court the petitioners appeale to the Circuit Court, where the jugment of the Probate Court was affirme. The exceptions taken before the Probate Court present the only questions for our consieration'. They relate alone to the right to ower in the slave Cato, an in respect to the hire of the slaves. The efenants amit that Cato was one of the slaves inventorie, an hel by them for a time as part of their intestate’s estate; but set up in avoiance or excuse for not accounting for the slave, that by an orer of the Probate Court, he was ischarge from their custoy!. If such was really the case, an if the Probate Court ha power to orer such ischarge, as this was affirmative matter, with regar to which the efenants’ answer coul not be receive as evience, (See Scott, White & Co. vs. Henry & Cunningham, 13 Ark. Rep. 121,) the efenants shoul have introuce the recor, or other competent evience to prove that fact. As this appears not to have been one, that slave stoo in the same situation that the other slaves i, an shoul have been taken into account in ecreeing ower. The efenants i not attempt to' account for the hire of the slaves; inee, they assume that they were, uner the circumstances, not boun to account for hire. They amit that the slaves belong to the estate an were hel an controlle by them, but state that the slaves were most of the time, kept upon the intestate’s farm at work, an that they accounte for the procees of their labor in their settlement with the court; that they were inuce to pursue this course, because it ha been pursue by their preecessors in aministration, an because they were so requeste to act by the wiow, (the claimant for ower.)
It was certainly the uty of the aministrator to put the slaves to labor at public or private hire, whether so orere by the Probate Court or not; or, whether hire or not, they were at all events accountable for the reasonable value of the services of the slaves. The procees of the labor of the slaves, whether employe on a farm or otherwise, is not the measure of the1 amin-tors’ accountability, but the orinary value of the services of tbe slaves at hire. This Is the only safe stanar of accountability easily to be arrive at by putting slaves to public hire upon notice, or by proving the rate of hire for such slaves at a given time. The procees of the labor of the slaves is so epenent upon the Mn of labor to which they were put, their management, the value of prouce, an like consierations, as to rener it extremely ifficult to arrive at any just estimate of the sum so realize, an is unwarrante by the’ nature of the trust repose in the aministrators. If (as allege) the wiow i sanction an irect the course pursue by the aministrators, so far as they pursue such irection, they may be protecte, as against her claim to ower, to a stricter account. But of this there is no evience ; nor is there any evience of the amount realize from the labor of the slaves. Reference is mae in efenants’ answer to a settlement mae with the court, in which they charge themselves with the sum so receive, but such settlement is not mae an exhibit, nor is it to be foun in this recor ; nor is there evience here to be foun sufficient to take an account for hire, or to assign ower except as to the slaves.
The Circuit Court shoul have sustaine the exception taken by the petitioners in the Probate Court, an have proceee to try the case e novo. Upon such trial all the evience which might legally have been introuce in the Probate Court upon the hearing of their cause there, woul have been alike amissible upon the trial e novo in the Circuit Court, so as to enable the court upon such trial to rener a final ecree accoring to the rights of the parties upon the facts presente.
The jugment of the Circuit Court must be reverse an set asie, an the cause remane to that court to be proceee in accoring to law an not inconsistent with this opinion.

case_name: Pike and Bertrand vs. The State and State Bank
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellants exhibite their bill in the court below against the State an the Bank of the State of Arkansas, the object of which was to enjoin a jugment at law renere against them in favor of the Bank. The questions involve may be consiere as epening upon the sufficiency of the bill, the substantial allegations of which are as follows : That on the first of September, 1843, one John Clark, as principal, .an the complainants, as his securities, execute their promissory note to the Bank of the State of Arkansas, which was iscounte by the principal bank at Little Rock, for the benefit of Clark, an became ue twelve months after ate. That Clark eparte this life, on the first ay of January, 1845, leaving the note wholly unpai, an his estate insolvent; that Clark, at the time of his eath, was a member of the State Senate, an in attenance upon the Legislature, then in session at Little Rock ; an there was ue to him, from the State, a sum of money for his pay an mileage as a member of the Senate, an for his services as commissioner employe by the State in running a bounary line, more than sufficient to pay the note in question. That the State ha the entire beneficial interest in the note an was really the owner an holer of it, an on the fourth of January, 1845, the complainants, by a notice in writing, aresse to the Auitor of Public Accounts, notifie the State that she woul be require to appropriate the moneys so in han belonging to the estate of Clark, to the payment of the-note, an warning the Auitor to retain a sufficiency of such moneys for that purpose; that the State isregare the notice, an on the 9th of January in the same year, the General Assembly enacte that one Wilfre Garner be authorize to receive such moneys ue from the State to Clark, an an after efraying all expenses incurre by him uring that session of the Legislature, to pay over the resiue,if any, to such aministrator upon Clafrk’s estate, as might be thereafter appointe, an in pursuance of this act, Garner, an entire stranger to the estate, receive from the Treasury the money owing from the State to Clark. That the Bank ha subsequently obtaine jugment against the complainants, for the amount ue upon the note; the execution of which jugment they praye might be perpetually enjoine.
Upon the case mae by the bill, our opinion is, that the relief sought was properly enie. The position contene for the complainants is, that as the State owne the Bank, an ha full control over it, as a public corporation, the note of Clark an his securities to the Bank was really a ebt ue to the State, an they argue that in such case, it woul be within the scope of the Auitor’s uty an authority to arrest the payment of any money, that might be ue from the State to Clark, or so much of it as woul be sufficient to satisfy a eman which the State ha against him. It will not be necessary to ecie whether the complainants woul have the right to require of the Auitor to pursue this course, for their protection as Clark’s securities, upon a ebt ue to the State, or whether by his failure to o so, they woul become release. The ebt of Clark an his securities, ■the collection of which they seek to enjoin, was incurre to the Bank. It is true the State owns the Bank, but equally true, as shown by all the legislation concerning it, since the first liquiation act passe at the session of 1842, an by the public history of the country, that the Bank is insolvent. Her assests then constitute a trust fun for the payment of her ebts, an without violating the obligation of contracts entere into by the Bank, there is no moe by which that fun coul be iverte, so as to eprive her creitors of the right to resort to it. This octrine is peculiarly applicable to the State Bank, because, unless her assets became plege as a fun for the reemption of her liabilities, it woul be ifficult to maintain that her issues for circulation, as contemplate by the charter, were not bills of creit, an therefore obnoxious to the feeral constitution. If it be suppose to follow from the opinion of this court in the case of The State et al. vs. Curran, 1 Eng. 321, that the State coul be require, in preference to any creitor of the corporation, to appropriate so much of her assets, .consisting of the note of Clark an his securities, as woul ischarge a ebt owing from the State to Clark, we o not assent to any such conclusion.
Unless the State were at the same time the ebtor an creitor of Clark, the act of the General Assembly referre to in the bill authorizing Garner to raw from the Treasury the moneys ue to Clark, can be no cause of complaint by this proceeing. It might be argue that the act in question was a violation of the right of the creitors of Clark, which ha become veste uner' the general laws in force at the time of his eath, to have his estate aministere an istribute in ue course of law, an it-might moreover be objectionable as a usurpation of power, insomuch as it contemplate that Garner, no matter how honestly exercising his iscretion, shoul appropriate the money so receive, to the payment of Clark’s ebts without any juicial ascertainment of them; yet if this be so, the only consequence woul be, that even if Garner, by rawing the money from the Treasury an thus intermeling with the estate, i not rener himself' liable to the creitors, as executor in his own wrong, still he was liable for all the money so rawn from the Treasury to the aministrator who might be appointe upon Clark’s estate. Supposing then the complainants to be creitors of the estate of Clark, by having pai any ebt of his, for which they were securities, they woul have the right, in common with the other creitors, an accoring to the classifications fixe by law, to a istributive share of the assets, incluing the money rawn from the Treasury by Garner.
In any view of the case, we think the ecree ought to be affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The original bill' in this cause was exhibite by one Lamburton an Anne, his wife, she being one of the heirs at law of John Saffol, against the other heirs at law, for an account an partition of his estate. Among the efenants to this bill were the appellant John J. Saffol, against whom an orer of publication was taken as a non-resient efenant, an the appellee, James F. Saffol. Pening this suit, James F. Saffol exhibite his cross bill against the complainants an his co-efenants to the original bill, incluing the appellant. The cross bill .praye for an account an partition in respect-of the subject matter of the original bill, an the .particular relief sought by it, as against the appellant, was base upon the allegation that he, by one Tapley II. Stewart, his attorney in fact, ha sol an conveye all his interest an claim as one of the heirs, in the estate of John Saffol, to certain persons, who ha in turn sol an conveye the same interest to the appellee an John F. Saffol, another of the parties to the suit. One of the objects, an so far as the appellant is concerne, the main object of the cross bill, was to ivest him of his entire portion of the estate, an cause it to become veste by the ecree of the court in the appellee an John F. Saffol.-
An orer of publication was taken upon the cross bill against the appellant, as a non-resient efenant, an he failing to appear, a ecree pro confesso was entere, an upon the final hearing of both suits, a ecree was renere against him in accorance with the prayer of the cross bill.
The appellant, acquiescing in the ecree for partition uner the original bill, has appeale from the ecree upon the cross bill, affecting his rights.
It will only be necessary to notice one of the matters assigne for error in the proceeings ha against the appellant upon the cross bill, which is, that they were ha without any sufficientor lawful notice to him of the penency of the suit. lie contens that the notice was insufficient, because the affiavit of the non-resience, which the statute requires to be mae by-the complainant, or some other person for him, in orer for service of notice to be ha by publication, i not state that the -appellant was a non-resient, but only that the affiant believe he was; that the orer mae for publication against the appellant, pro-, fessing to statejhe nature of the complaint in general terms as require by the statute, set forth that “ the object an nature of the cross bill is to obtain a iscovery an account to be taken between the complainants an the efenants thereto, relative to the lans an slaves, goos, chattels, money, creits an effects which were of John Saffol, ecease, the hire, rents, issues, an profits thereof, an to obtain partition of sai lans an slaves, an istribution of the personal estate of the ecease,” but was silent as to the most material object of the cross bill so far as it affecte the rights of the appellant, namely, to exclue him from partition, an by virtue of the allege conveyances to ivest him of all interest in the estate to which he was an heir. An lastly, it is objecte'for the appellant, that the evience of publication, when returne an file, purports to be verifie by the affiavit of the eitor instea of the “printer or publisher” of the newspaper, as provie by the statute in such case.
Upon inspection of the recor these objections appear to be well taken in point of fact, an ahering to the opinions in Broie vs. Skelton, 6 Eng. 129 an Clark vs. Strong, 13 Ark. 491, the conclusion is inevitable that they are well foune in law.
The revise statutes of 1839, require the publication of notice to non-resient efenants, of the penency of the suit, to state fully the substance of the allegations an prayer of the bill, an this notice ha to be publishe for eight weeks successively.
By the act of 1843, it is only necessary to state the nature of the complaint in general terms ; an the act of 1845 shortens the time of publication to two weeks in succession. We must suppose that the policy which influence these changes in the statute, was to lessen the expense of legal proceeings an not to eprive the absent efenant of any safeguar for the ue protection of his rights. It therefore affors no color of license to the courts to epart from the practice requiring that all the steps by means of which the complainant may charge a non-resient efenant upon constructive notice, be substantially complie with. The nature of the complaint upon the cross bill in this case is not sufficiently state to comply with the spirit of the statute. So the affiavit of. the printer or publisher is require, or in lieu of that, the prouction of the papers containing the avertisement. The affiavit of the eitor, in any given case may be true in fact, but the law, which must prescribe general rules, oes not authorize the authentication by an eitor, who may be an often is a person not concerne in the printing or publishing of the paper.
Without passing upon any other question sought to be raise by the assignment of errors, the ecree upon the cross bill, from which the appellant has appeale, will be reverse, an upon the remaning of the cause for any further proceeings, that maybe ha upon this branch of it, he will be consiere in court as if uly serve with process, with leave to emur, plea or answer to the cross bill.

case_name: Sanger et al. vs. State Bank
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The plaintiffs in error being sue by the Bank, upon a note which they ha mae payable to her, interpose a plea, setting up certain matters in abatement. The plea, on motion of the plaintiff below, was stricken from the files, to which the efenants excepte, an suffere final jugment.
Inasmuch as the plea, re-instate upon the recor by the bill of exceptions, appears to be applicable to the action, an, for aught that appears, pleae in apt time, goo in form, signe by counsel an verifie by affiavit; in short, having all the formal requisites of a plea, our opinion is, that it ought to have been emurre to, if the plaintiff below woul question its legal sufficiency. This point was expressly rule in Sillivant vs. Rearon, 5 Ark. 140, followe by Wilson vs. Shannon, 1 Eng. 198. In Pope vs. Tunstall, 2 Ark. 209, the question of practice was waive, because the court thought the plea which ha been stricken out in that case, was goo in substance as well as form, an therefore felt at liberty to consier the case in the same light as if the pleaings ha come up on emurrer. But the case last referre to cannot be safely followe as a preceent, because the refusal of the court in any case that might come before it, to consier the legal,sufficiency of a plea, which ha been improperly stricken out on motion, woul be an implie ecision against its legal sufficiency; whereas, accoring to the establishe rules of pleaing, the proper moe of tenering an issue in law is by emurrer; an without breaking own those rules the emurrant cannot evae it by an informal motion, so as to eprive the efenant of all benefit of any question of law upon the legal sufficiency of the plea, unless he shall get it again upon the recor by bill of exceptions.
True, a plea, apparently goo on its face, might well be struck from the files, because frivolous or vexatious ; as for example, where the same matter is attempte to be pleae, which the court has once ajuge insufficient, an the pleaer coul only rest upon the ecision, or plea over. But nothing of the kin is shown here. An so, like many other legal istinctions, where the lines run into one another, it might sometimes be ifficult to etermine whether a party shoul move to strike from the files, or be put to his emurrer. But accoring as one or the other may be proper, the office of a emurrer cannot be subserve by a motion.
At an early ay, Means vs. Cromwell, 1 Ark. 247, this court foun it necessary to check the practice which ha grown up, of interposing by informal motions, not traversable or tenering any issue of fact, matters in abatement, or which properly belonge to that class of efences. An without any particular examination of that or the several subsequent cases to the same purport, there can be no oufitthat the general tenency of them to iscourage such innovations in pleaing was right.
Jugment reverse an cause remane with instructions to reinstate the plea, an leave to the plaintiff to emur.

case_name: Yell, Gov. use Conant & Co. vs. Outlaw et al.
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
Bogy an Bonne, two of the efenants here, have pleae in bar of the w'rit of error, that at the May term, 1851, of the Jefferson Circuit Court, at which the jugment brought up by this writ for revision, was renere, the now plaintiff in error praye an appeal from the same jugment, which appeal was uly prosecute, an upon the filing of the transcript, the appeal was ockete; the appellant assigne errors, an these efenants joine therein, an such further proceeings were ha, that the appeal came on to be hear an was submitte to this court for its final ecision an ajuication therein. The plaintiff emurs because the plea fails to show that the appeal is still pening an unetermine, or that it has been prosecute to final jugment in this^ court.
The ecision at July term, 1853, granting the motion of the appellant in the cause referre to by the plea, for leave to is- . miss the appeal after submission, seems to be also ecisive of the question here presente. We are content to say that the right of an appellant to ismiss, at his own costs, an appeal in a common law case, an sue out a writ of error to the same jugment, oes not epen upon the enquiry, whether the appeal was actually pening in.this court, or whether being so pening it ha been prosecute own to submission. We take the istinction to be between those cases where the appeal oes not operate as a superseeas, an those, on the other han, where by operation of law or the act of the suitor, by entering into recognizance, the execution is staye upon the granting of the appeal to this courti If the successful party in the court below, is not hinere by the appeal from having execution, no goo reason is perceive why* the appellant may not ismiss his appeal, at any time before the final ajuication of it, with like effect, as if he ha brought the cause here for revision by writ of error, without superseeas. As the plea fails to show that by the original appeal, the execution of the jugment became suspene, it is not sufficient to bar the present writ of error. The penency of the appeal at the time of suing out the writ of error, might be goo in abatement of the latter proceeing, but woul not be appropriately mae in bar.
In Clay vs. Notrebe, 6 Eng. 631, this court went so far as to refuse to abate a writ of error, upon a plea that an appeal ha been taken in the court below with stay of execution in the same cause. Though the ecision there turne upon the issue mae by the pleaings, whether the appeal ha been in fact pening in this court, the juge elivering this opinion is constraine to think it was an immaterial issue; because where there has been a superseeas, the option of the appellant to abanon his appeal an bring error, is inconsistent with the right of the appellee, uner the statute, to have an affirmance of the jugment, unless the appeal is iligently prosecute; besies, upon appeals taken in the Circuit Court, the stay of execution oes not epen upon the opinion of any court or juge, who, in his iscretion, may think there is probable groun of error, but the suspension is eman-able at the pleasure of the appellant, upon the sole conition of his ability to furnish satisfactory security. But waiving any such consieration it is certainly a much stronger case than the present one.
Demurrer sustaine.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The plaintiff in error, file in the office of the clerk of the Hempstea Circuit Court, his account, verifie by affiavit, of work an materials one an furnishe in the erection of certain builings for the efenant, in orer to secure a lien on the premises uner the mechanics lien law, for abalance claime to be justly ue. Subsequently, in pursuance of the statute, the plaintiff sue out a scire facias, requiring the efenant to show cause why jugment an execution shoul not be ha against the property charge with the lien. The statute makes the scire facias equivalent to a eclaration, an obviously contemplates, that the cause shall be proceee with as other suits, which the efenant may contest; an the plaintiff may be require to prove that he is entitle to the lien, an can only have jugment for the amount which he proves is justly ue him.
In this case the efenant pleae by way of set-off, that, before an at the time oí suing out the writ of scire facias, the plaintiff was an continue to be inebte to him for goos sol, work an labor, money pai, for interest, an an account state, for a larger amount than that claime by the writ of scire facias; an also, by way of set-off, that, before the issuance of the scire facias, there ha been assigne to the efenant a certain writing obligatory, escribe in the plea, which the plaintiff ha execute to George W. Green, the amount of which thereby became ue an remaine wholly unpai with interest, from the plaintiff to the efenant. The plaintiff resting upon the overruling oí his emurrer to these pleas, the efenant ha final jugment.
The point which seems to be mae for the plaintiff is, that the pleas shoul not have been to the action of the scire facias, but shoul have been to the account an affiavit, the effect of which might have been to efeat, in this suit, the set-off pleae. Because the pleas, having relation to the state of the mutual inebteness of the parties at the time the suit was institute, if the filing of the account an affiavit is to be regare as the institution of the suit, no after acquire emans coul be available to the efenant by way of set-off.
It is clear from the statute that the filing of the account an affiavit, or laying the lien, as it is calle; is notthe institution of any suit, but is a preliminary step, by which the mechanic or material man may secure a lien, provie he follow it up by suit, that is, by scire facias, or bill in chancery, within a year; an then, the jugment he obtains in such suit, has relation back to the time of filing the account an affiavit. There can be no injustice to the plaintiff in holing, accoring to the orinary rules of pleaing, that a plea in such case is goo, which sets up a cross eman, in other respects properly the subject of set-off, subsisting at the time' of the commencement of the suit, which is the issuance of the scire facias.
At the same time, the remey, as regulate by statute, is a peculiar one, an is of an equitable character. The person claiming a lien is require to file a just an true account of the work one, &c., showing the amount really ue him after all just creits are given. It is for this balance that the plaintiff emans jugment in the scire facias. An it might turn out that the cross emans set up by the plea, are in whole or in part, those for which the claimant ha alreay given creit in his account originally file uner oath. It may be, the emurrer was preicate upon the iea that for this reason, the efenant ought, in fairness, to plea to the entire claim as set forth in the account, an not to the scire facias, which only claims the balance. An in such case a question might, arise, as in Burr vs. Byers, 5 Eng. 398, whether, if the plaintiff is boun to prove his whole account an failing as to part, the efenant, making no proof, can have the benefit of the creits amitte on the face of the-account.
But we apprehen that any question of that kin woul not. affect the legal sufficiency of the pleas. The statute gives the claimant the benefit of a lien by his complying with certain conitions, one of which is, that he shall state all just creits in his account. His act in laying the lien is ex parte, an not at all conclusive on the efenant. The intent of the statute woul seem to be that, at the trial on the scire facias, the plaintiff shoul go into proof.of his whole account, which, though verifie by'the oath of. one of the parties, oes not thereby become evience for either party. Though the plaintiff may not be entitle to recover more than the balance claime - with interest, the enquiry is now merely one of.inebteness as in<an orinary suit.. If the plaintiff establishes his account an the efenant relies on payment or offset, he must prove them as any other affirmative pleas, an by the orinary channels of evience. If he chooses to rely on the creits given in the account, the whole account,, charges as well as creits, ought, perhaps, to be taken as one entire amission; an if the efenant relies upon a set-off, or claims creits, in aition to those given in the account, the court or jury trying the issues, must etermine from the efenant’s bill of particulars an the proofs, whether they are the same items for which the plaintiff has alreay given creit, so that, in the language of the statute, the verict shall be “for such sum as shall be foun to be ue.
Upon the sufficiency of the pleas, as they stan confesse by the emurrer, the jugment of the court below is right an must be affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court!
This w'as an action of assumpsit upon open account, to which the efenant pleae non-assumpsit an set-off. The bills of particulars on either sie consiste of various items, which were sought to be establishe by proof. No objection was mae to the introuction of evience, an the cause was submitte without instructions to the jury, who foun a balance of account in favor of the plaintiff below. The efenant move for a new trial, because the verict was contrary to evience, an upon the groun of newly iscovere testimony. The motion being overrule, he excepte to the ecision of the court an took a bill of exceptions, setting out the evience. From this it oes appear that the efenant auce testimony conucing to prove a a larger amount of off-set than was allowe him by the verict of the jury. But the istinction is to be taken between cases where this court will venture to set asie a verict, because it is without evience as to some material fact necessary to uphol it, an cases like the present, where the verict is objecte to merely because it is against evience. The principal item of his account, which the efenant here attempte to prove, an which the jury woul seem to have rejecte, was for a quantity of corn, which the plaintiff ha taken an sol from the plantation of the efenant. But it is inferable from the testimony, though conveye to this court through the unsatisfactory meium of a bill of exceptions, that this was corn which the plaintiff himself, ha raise upon a plantation of the efenant, an therefore, might have ha a right to ispose of as his own. The presumption is to be inulge that if the verict was grossly unjust to either party, because against the weight of evience, the juge who presie at the trial, woul not have refuse to exercise his iscretion to set it asie. But surely upon the verict an the concurring refusal of the court below to isturb it, every possible presumption ought to be ha in favor of its correctness. Else this court woul be assuming the power it has not, to ictate to juries that they must believe evience against their own convictions of its truth.
The efenant, in his affiavit, state that he ha iscovere, since the trial, that he coul prove by an absent witness, the payment of a certain sum of money to the plaintiff, not long before the commencement of the suit. The witness was then resiing in the county. Besies the want of iligence inicate by the tenor of the affiavit, there are various objections to its sufficiency. No such item is charge in the efenant’s bill of particulars, as that to which the newly iscovere testimony woul apply. If the efenant ha, in fact, mae such payment, it is reasonable to suppose he woul charge it in his account, among other items of cash an merchanize. But the affiavit oes not aver that any such payment was mae except by inference, because he was informe an believe he coul prove it by the witness referre to. If the efenant were inicte on this cautious affiavit for swearing falsely, that he ha mae such payment, it is oubtful whether he coul be convicte.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This is an application for an appeal uner the provisions of our statute, (Dig. ch. 28, p. 244, an 135), an the question presente, is whether or not, uner the provision of the 21st section of our statute of ower; (Dig. ch. 59, p. 448), when the husban ies, leaving a wiow an no chilren, she takes one-half of the real estate, an one-half of the slaves of which he ie seize, absolutely an in her own right, or only a ower estate in them, for the fall term of her natural life; an vve think it perfectly clear, when this section is consiere in connexion with the other provisions of the ower law, that she takes only a ower interest an estate for life.
It is manifest that if she takes the slaves, absolutely an in her own right, she takes the real estate in the same way, an this woul be in conflict with the policy of our statute of escents, of preserving the inheritance in the bloo of the first purchaser, subject to ower in the common law sense of that term; as to the uration of the estate. It is only when there are no kinre, either paternal or maternal, capable of inheriting, an next before it escheats, that real estate escens from the husban to the wife, or vice versa, (Dig. ch. 56, sec. 7). It woul be easy to show, by enlarging upon this view of the subject, that if the wiow coul take one-half of the lan absolutely, an not a oWer -estate in it for life only, the Legislature ha really achieve much less than half they eviently esigne by the system of escents fthey set on foot.
The application is enie.
Watkins, C. J., not sitting.

case_name: Wheat et al: vs. Moss et al, use &c.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Scott,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This case is presente by a emurrer to a plea in abatement.The plea sets up, that on the 28th of May, 1853, which was the-ay of the renition of the ecree, the appellants praye an obtaine an appeal in this cause from the Circuit Court, an in pursuance thereof file in this Court on the 24th of June, following, a complete transcript of the recors an proceeings therein,, whereby the cause was brought into this court an remaine a cause pening here until after the commencement of the present term.
The appeal now pening here, which is sought to be abate by this plea, came here in pursuance of an appeal with stay of' execution, grante by one of the juges of this court uring the last vacation, in pursuance of the statute, (Dig. ch. 28, sec. 135.)
In the case of Taylor vs. Aams, 13 Ark. 61, this court sai, that uner this provision of the statute, a juge in vacation might grant an appeal, notwithstaning one ha been previously grante in the Circuit Court. But although this is true, it oes not follow that such an appeal may not be abate like any other-suit improviently commence. If this appeal ha been ismisse, instea of the other, which it seems from the plea ha been perfecte, an was pening here when this was grante, it woul have been competent for this court, as hel Davis vs. Tarwater, (13 Ark. R. 52), to have grante a stay of execution upon recognizance, although a juge in vacation coul not have one so.
We cannot sustain this emurrer without overturning some of the well settle rules of pleaing. It must, therefore, be overrule, an the appeal abate.
Watkins, C. J., not sitting in this cause.

case_name: The State vs. Vaughan et al.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Walker.,
elivere the opinion of the Court!
An interlocutory jugment was renere against the efenants upon a recognizance conitione that efenant, Vaughan, shoul appear at the Maison Circuit Court, an answer to an inictment for gaming; an separate writs of scire facias issue against them, irecte to the sheriff of Maison, the county in which the efenants resie. At the return term, upon the motion of Yaughan, these writs were quashe upon the groun, that a single writ, an not separate writs, shoul have issue. But no further jugment appears to have been renere.
The State has brought this case before us on appeal; but there is eviently no final j ugment of the Circuit Court, from which an appeal might be taken to this court. If the State ha esire to test the correctness of the-ecision of the Circuit Court, she shoul have refuse to procee further, an suffere final jugment to bo renere, isposing of the whole case. The question is one of practice, an we. think, properly ecie by the court below, an is sustaine by State Bank vs. Terry et al. 13 Ark. 390.
But as there was .no final jugment in the court below, this court can acquire no jurisiction by appeal.
Let the appeal be ismisse-for want of jurisiction.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
James F. Lee brought his suit in replevin against John Row-ark, for a mule. The general issue was pleae, an by consent of parties, the case was submitte to the court sitting as a jury. After having hear the evience the court foun for the plaintiff, an as the property ha not been replevie an elivere to the plaintiff, the court also hear evience, as well touching the amages for the etention of the property as the value thereof, an renere a jugment in his favor for the same. Whereupon, the efenant move the court to grant him a new trial, because the fining of the court was contrary to law an evience; which motion the court overrule. The efenant excepte an mae the evience matter of recor by his bill of exceptions.
The questions presente an argue by counsel are, first, as to the sufficiency of the evience to sustain the fining of the court; an secon, that it was error in the court to rener an absolute jugment for the value of the property.
As regars the first question, there can be no oubt but that the evience is sufficient to uphol the fining of the court. There is no lack of evience upon any point necessary to a recovery; an although the evience of several of the witnesses is somewhat contraictory, as well with regar to the purchase of the mule by the plaintiff, as the ientity of the mule in the efenant’s possession, as the same purchase by the plaintiff, it was the peculiar province of the court sitting as a jury to weigh the evience an etermine the facts, an having one so, we o not feel at liberty to isturb the verict.
After fining the issue for the plaintiff, the court, uner the circumstances of the case, properly ascertaine the value of the mule, but faile to rener a jugment thereon, in accorance with the statute. Section 39, ch. 13G Dig., provies “that in case the plaintiff shall recover jugment upon the whole recor, he shall be entitle, in aition to jugment for amages an costs, to a further jugment, that the property be replevie an elivere to him without elay; or in efault thereof, that the plaintiff recover from the efenant the value of the property ascertaine by the court or jury. Uner the provisions of the statute, the court shoul have renere jugment that the property be replevie an elivere; as well as for the value thereof. Uner the provisions of the statute jugment, when properly renere, the efenant may surrener the property an ischarge himself from the payment of the amages: but by the jugment, as renere in this case, he is eprive of the privilege of oing so.
For this error the jugment of the Circuit Court must be reverse, an the cause remane with instructions to the court below to rener jugment on the verict an fining of the court in accorance with this opinion.

Mr. Justice Walker,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
When this case was, upon a former occasion-, before us (see 6 Eng. Rep. 675), the 4th plea of efenant, Fowler, the legal effect of which was to eny the existence of a subsisting cause of action in the plaintiff at the time his suit was commence, was hel to be a goo plea in bar; an consequently no question can now be raise as to its legal sufficiency.
When the case was remane to the Circuit Court for further proceeings therein to be ha, the plaintiff replie to the 4th plea, matter which showe that his right to sue accrue to him at a ay subsequent to the commencement of his action. An the legal sufficiency of this replication is the sole question now' to be ecie.
If the plaintiff ha, by a general replication, traverse the efence setup in the plea, the material fact thus putin issue woul have been the penency of the appeal at the time the suit was commence. Instea of oing this, he file a special replication, by which the existence of the appeal at the time state in the efenant’s plea was amitte, an the subsequent isposal of the case in the Supreme Court was set up in avoiance of the matter pleae by the efenant. This new matter was clearly insufficient for that purpose. The question raise by the plea was, as to the existence of the plaintiff’s right of action at the time the suit was commence, an not as to whether it ha subsequently accrue. So that unless the subsequently acquire right was, in legal effect, equivalent to a pre-existing right, it was not responsive to the plea; for it is a well establishe rule that no one can sue in a court of law, wffio has not, at the time of bringing his-suit, a then existing- right of action in himself. The right of action in the plaintiff in this case accrue from an at the ate of the final ecision of the Supreme Court, affirming the ecree of the Circuit Court, an whether the pre-existing isabilty to sue shoul be consiere as matter in bar or abatement, although the jugments upon these pleas are, in several respects, ifferent; that in bar being conclusive upon the parties, upon all pre-existing matters at issue; that in abatement, where a temporary isability is pleae, that the plant remain without ay, &c. In this case the efence was that the right of action at the time the suit w'as brought, ha not accrue. The jugment, then, upon the plea in bar, although conclusive upon their existing rights, coul not be pleae in bar of a subsequently acquire right of a„ction. So that, so far as the rights of the parties are concerne, it woul be as-harmless as the jugment upon a plea in abatement woul.
Suppose suit ha been brought upon the injunction bon before the ecree in the Circuit Court. It is very clear, accoring to the ecision of the Court of Appeals of Kentucky, that no action coul be maintaine upon the bon, an as was the case there, that this matter coul be pleae in bar. Cates &c., vs. Woolrige, 1 J. J. Marsh. Rep. 268. In that case, as in this, suit was brought upon an injunction bon an a plea in bar interpose. In reference to this efence, the court sai, “ If the emurrer coul be consiere as applicable to the plea, enying the issolution of the injunction, as allege in the eclaration, we shoul not hesitate to reverse the ecision of the court below, in sustaining the emurrer, for the plea is unquestionably goo. No cause of action coul accrue on the injunction bon until the injunction was ischarge or issolve.” But although no action coul be maintaine, an although it was also hel that a plea in bar was properly interpose, no one vvoul conten that the jugment renere upon such plea, however conclusive upon any then existing cause of action, coul be plea in bar to a suit upon a subsequently accruing right of action, or, as in the cáse of Barry vs. Long, 9 Ala. Rep. 785, if suit shoul be brought upon a contract before it fell ue, it coul never be, that jugment upon the issue forme coul be pleae in bar of a recovery on such contract after it ha mature. The case of Barry vs. Long, was assumpsit, where the general issue ha been pleae. The court, in that case, hel that the fact that the contract upon which, the suit was brought ha not mature, nee not be pleae in abatement, but might be given in evience uner the general issue. So that, in any point of view in which this case presents itself, it is a matter of form, rather than substance, whether the matter of efence be pleae in bar or abatement; an the replication of the plaintiff woul have fallen as far short of a sufficient response to the plea in the one case as in the other.
In conclusion, we will remark that we have been le by the argument of the plaintiff’s counsel, into a fuller investigation of the manner of reaching efects of this kin, an of the jugment to be renere on the issues, whether in bar or abatement, than the precise point at issue might seem to require.
The replication was clearly insufficient.
Jugment affirme.
Watkins, C J., not sitting.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellant, Brock, who was the plaintiff below, sue the efenant in trespass for breaking an entering his close, an taking therefrom a quantity of cor-woo; to which the efenant pleae not guilty.
The facts proven, as shown by the bill of exceptions, were, that in the year 1849, the efenant cut fifly cors of woo on the lan mentione in the eclaration, while the same was public lan belonging to the Unite States. In the month of June, 1850, the plaintiff entere, or purchase the lan in question from the Unite States, an it became his private property; but the only evience, introuce by the plaintiff to show title in himself, was the certificate of the Register of the lan office, that he ha entere an locate the same by virtue of a Choctaw certificate, an also the Receiver’s reeeipt for the amount of money pai in by the plaintiff for the purchase of the excess of lan over an above the number of acres calle for by the Choctaw certificate. To the’introuction of which evience, it being at the same time ami'te that the plaintiff never ha been in possession of the lan, the efenant objecte, upon the groun that trespass coul not be maintaine. It further appeare that, at the time the plaintiff purchase the lan, the cor-woo referre to was •still upon it, not having been remove, an shortly afterwars he gave the efenant notice that the lan was his, an not to to remove the woo from it. Notwithstaning such notification the efenant went upon the lan, carrie off the cor-woo an sol it. Woo staning in the tree was worth ten cents per cor, but when cut into cor-woo an after being haule to the river, was worth one ollar an fifty cents per cor.
Each party aske for instructions : the plaintiff insisting that, upon the facts state he was entitle to maintain the action, an recover of the efenant uner the statute, three times the value of the woo carrie off: an it was insiste on behalf of the efenant, that if he was liable it was only for the value of the timber in the tree, an not for its increase value after it was cut into cor-woo. The court charge the jury, that if Smith cut the woo upon Government lan, an after the woo was cut, an before the same was remove, Brock purchase the lan from the Government, the right of the woo was in Smith, an he was not guilty of a trespass in taking it off. The jury being so instructe foun for the efenant.
It is argue for the plaintiff that the opinion in Floy vs. Ricks, ecie at July term, 1853, etermines all the questions presente on this recor. An it is argue for the efenant that by virtue of the pre-emption laws an the general policy of the lan system^of the Unite States, recognize by our statutes, he ha an implie license to cut timber on the vacant public lans, an that in consequence of his labor bestowe, the woo became his by right of accession.
