text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins,
elivere the opinion of the Court..
These cases involve the same question ecie in Hanly vs.. Carneal: an the executions which issue after the act of January 10th, 1853, having been quashe, because there ha been no revival, nor any regular issuance of execution within a year an a ay, an the cases in other respects coming within that ecision, the jugments are reverse.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellant was' attache for contempt in failing to atten •the Desha Circuit Court, when uly summone as a witness in certain State prosecutions, an which in consequence of his absence were nol. prosse by the attorney for the State; an being interrogate faile to purge himself, to the satisfaction of the court, of the allege contempt. The court orere him to be fine in the sum of fifty ollars an to stan committe until the fine an costs be pai, &c. He took a bill of exceptions, praye an appeal an entere into recognizance before the court below for stay of execution.
The isposition manifeste by the Circuit Court, to cause to be state upon the recor, fairly an truly, for the protection of the person ajuge to be in contempt, the grouns an reasons for the same, an the substance of which ought to be set forth in the warrant of commitment, is every way commenable. But as hel in Cossart vs. The State, at this term, the appeal an superseeas, if allowable, woul virtually set at naught the power óf a Circuit Court to punish summarily for contempt in any case.
Appeal ismisse.

Mr. Chief Justice Waticins
elivere the opinion of the Court!
Coleman applie to the White Circuit Court for a rule upon McDaniel to show cause why a manamus shoul not be aware to compel him to issue execution upon a jugment which, the petitioner allege, he ha obtaine against one Walter, on the trial ha before McDaniel, as a justice of the peace, of a suit in which the petitioner was plaintiff an Walker was efenant, on the 6th ay of September, 1851, to which ay the summons issue by the justice in that suit an which ha been uly serve on Walker was returnable. The magistrate, in his response, amitting that he ha renere such jugment, as set forth in the alternative writ, further state that afterwars an on'the same ay the jugment was renere, an application was mae to him by Walker’s counsel, to set it asie an grant a new trial, because an offset, offere to be file on the part of Walker, ha been improperly rule out at the trial in question; an he, the responent, being satisfie that he ha erre in rejecting the offset, i set asie an vacate that jugment an grant a new trial, of which new trial the petitioner, Coleman, ha notice. That upon a secon hearing of the case, a jugment was renere against Coleman, which stans in full force upon the responent’s ocket as a justice of the peace, unsatisfie an unappeale from; an there being no longer any such jugment as that allege by the petitioner, the responent submits whether he can or ought to issue execution upon it. Upon the hearing the court below ajuge that a peremptory manamus issue.
This case presents a question of no little interest to the numerous class of suitors before magistrate’s courts,- that is, whether a justice of the peace can set asie a jugment an grant a new trial. An it is one of some ifficulty; because justices of the peace being juicial officers, it woul seem that so much iscretion ought to be confie to them, as woul enable them to correct their own erroneous jugments, by granting anew trial. But the Legislature has not thought proper to provie for such remey, an the power cannot be inferre as one inseparable from a court of such inferior an limite jurisiction. While the General Assembly coul not eprive justices of the peace of any part of the jurisiction given to them by the constitution, or even so legislate as to clog or impair it, or prevent its exercise by omitting to legislate Moore vs. Wooruff, 5 Ark. 214, there can be as little oubt that the moe an manner of exercising their jurisiction may be controlle an regulate by law. The various provisions of the statute concerning justices of the peace an regulating the proceeings in suits before them, are so minute an specific, as by intenment to exclue the power of granting new trials in conteste cases, to which no allusion is mae. A justice of the peace may ajourn causes from ay to ay until the business qn his ocket is ispose of, Digest, Title, Justices of the Pf.ace, sec. 11; may ajourn a case, ifhe eems it necessary, not exceeing thirty ays, ib. sec. 71; may grant continuances for cause shown on the application of either party not exceeing sixty ays, ib. sec. 75; may set asie a jugment of non-suit or by efault, if applie for within fifteen ays; ib. sec. 89, an then the justice is require to make out an cause to be serve, in the same manner as a summons, a notice to the opposite part¿ of the time an place fixe for the new trial, ib. sec. 91. Either party aggrieve by the jugment of a justice may appeal within thirty ays (except from a jugment of non-suit, or by efault, where no application is mae within fifteen ays to set it asie) to the Circuit Court, where the trial is e novo upon the facts an merits, ib. see. 174, et seq., whereby the party aggrieve is relieve from all apprehension of irreparable injury by means of an unjust an erroneous ecision, an if the right of appeal be lost without any fault of the party, or is attempte to be taken away by the legislature, the supervising controll of the superior courts may be exercise in some other appropriate moe.
Leaving out of view any case where the new trial might be grante by consent of parties, or where the appearance to the merits by both parties at the new trial might amount to a submission to the jurisiction — there being no limitations or restrictions upon the granting new trials by justices of the peace, where there has been a trial an jugment, an no power conferre except in the cases specifie of jugments of non suit or by efault, the assumption of such .a power in all cases woul be prouctive of the utmost confusion an uncertainty an might lea to gross abuses. The number of new trials, the causes for which they shoul be grante, the kin of notice to the opposite party, the time beyon which the magistrate shoul cease to have contrail over jugments renere by him, woul, as the law now stans, be left to the iscretion of a vast number of inferior courts, only quasi courts of recor, having no clerk, no seal, no perpetual succession or continuance of office, an without terms of fixe an limite uration.
In Kentucky an Iniana it seems that justices of the peace may grant new trials, Hotten vs. Greenwell, 4 Dana 633, where certain, limitations upon the power are prescribe. Robieau vs. Ewing, 5 Blackfiel, 552, where it appears to be expressly allow-, e by statute; an in that State justices’ courts are courts of recor. Hooker vs. The State, 7 ib. 272. An in Kentucky justices of the peace by statute have powers wholly unknown to our laws. Breckenrige vs. Coleman, 7 B. Monroe, 331, while in New York, an some other States, they are treate as jurisictions even more inferior an limite than with us.
But in Missouri, uner a system very similar to ours, the power of justices to grant new trials not being conferre by statute, is utterly enie. Cason vs. Tate, 8 Missouri, 45, referring to Downing vs. Gainer, 1 ib. 751, an Rutherfor vs. Winn, 3 ib. 14. So in Iowa, Helmich vs. Johnson, 1 Morris 89.
Our opinion is that if Walker, the efenant in the suit before the justice, was aggrieve by the ecision there, his appropriate remey was by appeal, an that all the proceeings of the-justice subsequent to the renition of the first jugment mentione in the pleaings were unauthorize by law.
This conclusion is not preicate upon any want of capacity-in justices of the peace to set asie the vericts of juries an grant new trials in causes pening before them, but upon the istinct groun that the Legislature, having the power to regulate the exercise of their jurisiction, intene, accoring to what seems to be the proper construction- of the statutes- on the subject, the trial e novo upon appeal as a substitute for the granting of new trials by the justices themselves.
Jugment affirme.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court,
The appellant was inicte uner the statute for maiming one Jesse Ewars, the offence being a felony: The same statute, Digest, Title, Criminal Law. Part 4, Art. 3, Sec. 8, enacts “that if persons fight by mutual agreement, an one of them be maime, it shall not be eeme maiming within the meaning of this act; but the parties shall be punishe by fine an imprisonment as fin-an aggravate affray; which fine shall not exceeone thousan ollars, an the imprisonment shall not excee one year, at the iscretion of the court.” On the trial the verict was, “We the jury, o fin the within name John Strawn, not guilty, as charge in the within inictment, but fin that he an the within name Jesse Ewars fought by mutual agreement. By authority of the statute, Digest, Title, Criminal Proceeings, sec. 186, the court assesse the punishment to fifty ollars fine an imprisonment for one hour, an passe sentence accoringly. The prisoner move in arrest of jugment, because the verict, which acquitte him of the offence charge in the inictment, faile to show that he was guilty of any minor offence.
Certainly it might have been proper for the verict to have state more explicitly that the accuse was not guilty, as charge, of the offence of maiming, but that he an Ewars fought by mutual agreement, whereby the latter was maime. But looking at the inictment, the statute an the verict as returne, the conclusion is reasonable, if not unavoiable, that such was the meaning an intention of the jury; an although the verict oes not state, in express terms, that Ewars was maime, it will bear that construction, an was therefore sufficient to warrant the sentence. Uner the existing law, Revise Statutes, Title, Criminal Jurispruence, Division 3, Art. 5. See Eason vs. The State, 6 Eng. 502, an accuse convicte of an assault merely, with intent to commit certain felonies, incluing mayhem, might have been subjecte to an equally severe punishment by fine an imprisonment; an so for an aggravate assault: an for a simple assault, not attene with battery, the fine may be in any sum not exceeing one hunre ollars. Whatever might be the egree of strictness require in convictions for felony, we are not ispose to apply it to misemeanors after verict, an the present case is not stronger than that of McBrie vs. The State, 2 Eng. 374. The verict here was not a special one, which referring the law to the court, must state all the facts essential to a conviction; as for example, that the act suppose to constitute the felony, was one within the county, but was a general one, fining conclusions of law an fact, as will appear from the case of The Commonwealth vs. Call, 21 Pick, 514, cite for the appellant. The verict oes inee specially acquit the prisoner of the particular offence with which he is charge, but such acquittal, so far from vitiating the verict, or precluing the jury from proceeing to fin the lesser offence, in cases where it is allowable to o so, Cameron vs. The State, 4 Ark. 721, it is the proper form of returning the verict in such cases. 1 Chitty Crim. Law, 642.
It is argue here for the appellant that as the jury foun the accuse guilty of a misemeanor only, the verict shoul have state that such offence was committe-within a year previous to the fining of the inictment; else having pleae to an inictment for a felony, the limitation of which is three years, he might have been illegally convicte of a misemeanor, which for aught that appears, was barre by lapse of time. Though the better opinion woul seem to be that where an averment in an inictment as to time is not material, The People vs. Santvoor, 9 Cowen, 655, unless inee the averment be of an impossible ate, it is not require to be prove as lai, yet any question that might arise uner the statute, whether an inictment ought not to be quashe, or the jugment upon it arreste, where upon the face of the inictment, the offence of which the prisoner may be convicte appears to be barre, is obviate in this case, because here the offence is charge to have been committe within a year previous to the first fining of the inictment. The language of the statute is, “No person shall be trie, prosecute an punishe for any offence less than felony, unless the inictment be foun within one year after the commission of the offence.”. Our unerstaning is, that the uniform construction of the phraseology quote has been, that in orer to make out the offence the State is require to prove affirmatively, to the satisfaction of the jury, upon the issue to the plea of hot guilty, that the allege misemeanor was committe within a year previous to the fining of the inictment. Stevens vs. The State, 3 Ark. 66. Consequently, where the inictment alleging an offence within the year is goo on its face, if the proof at the trial iscloses an offence committe at some anterior time, the only way in which the prisoner can avail himself of the objection is, to bring it upon the •recor by exceptions; or it might be groun of motion for new trial; but woul not be available in arrest of jugment.
Affirme.

case_name: Jester et al. vs. The State
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The inictment, preferre at the February term, 1853, of the Hot Spring Circuit Court, charge that the appellants, on the tenth ay of March, A. D. 1852, at&c., bet a certain sum of money at an unlawful game at cars calle raw pocre, then an there playe by them together. Asecon count allege the game playe to be calle pocre. On the trial the State prove that, at the August term 1852, an inictment which, leaving out of view any variance between them, the jury were authorize to .infer was for the same offence, was preferre against Jester, Reay, Morehea an one Cyrus A. Hale, charging that the games in question were playe by those four persons together, on the tenth ay of March, 1852. That Hale, having pleae guilty to that inictment at the February term, 1853, it was then, on motion of the attorney for the State, quashe as to the other efenants, Jester, Reay an Morehea. The parol testimony on the trial conuce to prove that uring the month of January, 1852, in the county of Hot Spring, these efenants ha bet money upon a game at cars calle pocre, then an there playe by them together with Hale an one Joshua F. Morris,, an that the witnesses for the prosecution ha so testifie before the gran jury, at each term of the court when the respective inictments were foun.
The efenants aske the court to instruct the jury, that in orer to convict upon an inictment for betting at cars, uner the 8th section of the statute against gaming, it is necessary -as part of the escription of the offence, to set out the names of the persons by whom the game was playe, if known to the gran jury, ap that the proof shoul correspon with the allegations in that respect. The refusal of the court to give this instruction an the omission to charge the jury in any manner equivalent to it, was clearly erroneous, accoring to the opinions of this court in Drew vs. The State, 5 Eng. 82. Parrott vs. The State, ib: 572. Moffat vs. The State, 6 ib. 169. Stith vs. The State, 13 Ark. 680, an Johnson vs. The State, ib. 684.
An objection was also taken an reserve to the sufficiency an legal effect of the recor evience auce to prove the penency of the former inictment, in orer to isplace the operation of the statute bar, suppose to appear on the face of the secon inictment, which charge the offence to have been committe more than a year previous to the time when it was preferre, An it was further objecte that the State coul not avail herself for this purpose of the recor of an inictment or prosecutipp pening an quashe at her own instance. The provision of the statute, Digest, Title, Criminal Proceeings, sec. 104, is “When any inictment or prosecution shall be quashe, set asie or reverse, the time uring which the same was pening, shall not be compute as part of the time of the limitation prescribe for the offence.” As the first inictment coul only have been quashe by the ecision of the court, the presumption is, that it was one, though on motion of the attorney for the State, for sufficient cause, in the exercise of juicial iscretion, an not capriciously, or with any esign to harrass the accuse, so that, although the quashal might operate as a harship, we cannot presume they yvere injure by it, because such a proceeing is a .contingency provie for by the statute an liable to occur in the aministration of justice.
Conceing that it was necessary for the State to prove that the offence, no matter when allege to have been committe, was in fact committe within a year previous to the fining of the inictment, (Strawn vs. The State, ecie at the present term), or to isplace the bar by showing, in accorance with the statute the penency an quashal of a former prosecution for the same offence, we might incline to the opinion, by parity of reasoning with the case of The State Bank vs. Gray, 7 Eng. 760, an The State Bank vs. Roy, ib. 766, that the recor of a former inictment against four persons might be amissible for that purpose on the trial of a subsequent inictment against any one or more of the same persons, an who might be separately inicte, provie the offence charge appeare to be in other respects the same, But the ifficulty here is, an it is, in a ifferent aspect, the same question presente by the motion to instruct the jury, that the secon inictment charges the games to have been playe by three persons, (the present appellants) while the recor auce in evience, isclose by the former inictment, a charge against them for betting at games playe by four persons — which being a istinct offence there was a material variance, for which the recor shoul have been exclue. If the secon inictment ha charge that these efenants bet at a game playe by them together with Hale, the question might have been analogous to The State Bank vs. Gray, an same vs. Roy, where the cause of action was the same, though all the efenants in the first suit were not embrace in the secon.
For these errors the jugment will be reverse an the cause remane with instructions to grant the motion of the efenants for a new trial, an that the cause be further proceee in accoring to law an not inconsistent with this opinion.-

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The appellant was inicte, trie, convicte an sentence to eath in the Inepenence Circuit Court for the murer of Hiram Payne, a white man. He appeale to this court, an his senténcé having been respite by the Circuit Court, uner the provisions of the statute, a sufficient time to allow him to make an application to a juge of this court for a suspension of his execution until his appeal coul be hear here, that orer was mae upon an inspection of a transcript of the recor an proceeings in accorance with his prayer.
From the bills of exceptions it appears that, on the ay before the killing, the appellant an his master, Benjamin Watson,ha a conversation, in which the slave talke improperly to his master,' an that at night when he returne from ploughing, he brought, a club in with him. That after supper he sat out upon the yar fence with the same in his han, an also picke up another stick, which he took to his quarters an set up at the oor, carrying the first name stick into the house. That in the course of the evening, an after supper, his master went into a room where the-school boys an hirelings were, whereupon the appellant left his own room an went to the chimney corner of the welling house. That about the mile of the night the appellant walke out into the yar carrying a fire torch, an the stick that he ha brought from the fiel, in his han. Upon returning to his quarters he tol his wife they were going to take him, but that he woul not be taken by bis master or any boy else, an that he woul knock the first man own that came into the room. ■ The next morning, the appellant went to mill an returne, an then bunle up his clothes an took them away. He then got some tubs, as he was orere to o, an went to the Woos for some hoop poles, as he was orere to o by a witness, who was oing some work for Watson, the master, an neee the hoop poles for the work in progress. It woul seem thats about this perio of time, Mrs. Watson, the wife of the master, ha sent a message to her husban, who was at the school house, to the effect that the appellant ha run away, an it appearing that while Watson, the master, was on the way from the school house to his welling, whither he was going in consequence of receiving such a message from his wife, he met the appellant coming from the woos with some hoop poles an an axe in his hans. It appears that then “Watson an others avance towars the (appellant) at the request of Watson, an for the purpose, as expresse by Mr. Watson of correcting” him. Who these others were an how they happene to be with Watson oes not appear. It appears, however, that when Watson an these others approache to the appellant, that he retreate, but that they overlook him in the roa an orere him to lay own his axe, an he refuse, an sai that he woul not be w’hippe by Watson, or any boy else, an that he woul kill the first man that attempte to take him, an that he then walke on, an Watson an the men after him. In a short time he stoppe again an was conversing with Watson, but what was sai oes not appear. At this point of time “Hiram Payne, the slain, walke rapily by the witness, from behin the witness, being behin the boy an the company, having in his hans a piece of pine plank. That Payne, the ecease, walke irectly up to Watson an Austin, the appellant, an rew his stick upon Austin. That Austin stoo with his axe rawn as Payne rew his stick upon Austin. That Austin ware off the blow of Payne with his left arm, an with his right struck Payne with the axe. That Payne was hit with the whole ege of the axe on his hea, the cut penetrating to the brain, an that Payne ie the Saturay afterwars.”
Upon the trial so much of the evience was objecte to as relate to matters that transpire the ay before the homipie, upon the groun of its isconnection with that principal fact, an irreleyan cy to the issue. It is certainly true as a general rule, both in civil an criminal cases, that the evience must be confine to the point in issue; an in criminal cases there is perhaps a greater necessity, if possible, than in civil proceeings to enforce the rule: but in neither class of cases oes this rule exclue all evience that oes not bear irectly upon the issue; on the contrary, all evience is amissible which tens to prove it, an no facts are forbien to be shown, except such as are incapable of afforing any reasonable presumption or inference in eluciation of the matters involve in the issue. In this case the line of efence taken, an which the State ha the right to anticipate, was that the homicie amounte to no more than manslaughter. The presen ce or absence of malice was therefore an essential matter of enquiry. To establish it the State was not boun to rely exclusively upon the malice that the law presumes from the killing, an the eviences of it which were otherwise shown by the circuriistances at the point of time when the killing occurre, but ha the right to a any other evience, as former gruges, former threats, previous lying in wait, cumulative of the former, an • thus effectually to repel any inferences that might be rawn in favor of the efence from the circumstances that transpire at the time of the killing. In like manner, anteceent facts an circumstances, from which any reasonable presumption coul arise, or inference be rawn, that the course of conuct pursue by the prisoner at the time of the killing ha been previously premeitate an resolve upon by him, in reference to a probable effort to bring him back into perfect suborination to the lawful authority of his master, although without any reference to the particular iniviual slain, tene at once, not only to eluciate the intention of the slave at the’time of striking the fatal blow, but the state an conition of his heart, both as to evil esign in general, an in being resolve, in pursuance of the ictates of such wicke, eprave an malignant evil esign in general, to o the particular, unlawful act of resisting the rightful authority of his master at all hazars, incluing that of taking human life in general, regarless of social uty an without respect to persons.
Such a resolye, prompte by the ictates of such a heart, coul not be otherwise, than essentially malicious, an if in being acte out, human life was taken, although uner circumstances which, isconnecte with such resolve, might lay grouns for presumptions that the slayer was actuate by a esign to save his own life, or was prompte by circumstances transpiring at the time strongly calculate to excite the passions of terror an resentment, it coul not be otherwise than a legitimate point of enquiry by the jury, whether or not the homicie ha been really superinuce by the former, although apparently by the latter, to the en that the presumption in favor of manslaughter might be legitimately overslaughe by these cumulative presumptions of malice.
. It is in this point of view that we think the jury in this case ha the right to consier an weigh the evience objecte to. They ivere sitting in jugment upon an act which, in point of law, was to be essentially characterize by the motive of the heart which prompte it. These in the orer of Provience are hien an beyon the reach of human law, until evelope by acts of commission, or of omission, which present them to its jugment in etermining the quality of the act brought in question. Every act then of either class, which in the range of probability coul cast a ray of light upon the motive, which prouce the homicie in question, was legitimately within the range of the investigation, although occurring at an anteceent time, or at another place unless forbien by the rule esigne to confine the investigation to the issue mae; an this rule, as we have seen, oes not exclue any evience that tens to prove or eluciate any of the matters involve in the issue. An regaring the evience objecte to in this case as of that character, we think the court below properly allowe it to go to the jury.
The secon bill of exceptions raises the question, whether or not the confessions of the accuse, being otherwise unexceptionable in point of law, can be allowe to be prouce in evience after the facts themselves have been proven by witnesses who were present when they transpire. We think it perfectly clear that they may, being both of the same grae of evience, although iffering in the weight to be given to them by the jury.
In the thir, it is amitte that it was shown that the confessions were obtaine without the prisoner having been promise or threatene in any way, an that there was no inucement ,or reason hel out to him to- answer the question propoune by one of his guars “what he ha against the ecease to inuce him to strike him,” or otherwise to talk upon the subject. But it is insiste, as the confessions were so mae in response to that question, which it is urge implie the guilty act of the prisoner, an was mae to one of his guar at a time when he was in chains an being brought to jail upon the charge in question, that they ought to have been exclue from the jury. In Mr. Greenleaf’s work on evience the law upon this subject is thus state: “Though it is necessary to the amissibility of a confession that it shoul have been voluntarily mae, that is, that it shoul have been mae, as before shown, without the appliances of hope or fear from persons having authority, yet it is not necessary that it shoul have been the prisoner’s own spontaneous act. It will be receivable though it were inuce by spiritual exhortations, whether of a clergyman or any other person; by solemn promise of secrecy, even confirme by an- oath, or by reason of the prisoner’s having been runk, or by some collateral benefit or boon-, no hope or favor having been hel out in respect to the criminal charge against him, or by any eception practice on the prisoner or false representation mae to him for that purpose, provie there is no reason to suppose that the inucement hel out was calculate to prouce any untrue confession, which is the main point to be consiere. So, a confession is amissible though it is elicite by questions, whether put to a prisoner by a magistrate, officer or private person, an the form of the question is immaterial to the amissibility, even though it assumes the prisoner’s guilt, In all these cases the evience may be lai before the jury, however little it may weigh uner the circumstances, an however reprehensible may be the moe in which, in some of them, it was obtaine.” (1 Greenl. Ev. part 2, ch. 12, sec. 229, p. 293, 5 eition.)
Although in some few of the cases state in this text, we woul look closely to the authorities, upon which they are base, before eclaring the law to the full extent that they are state to go, we can have no hesitancy, on the question before us now, in holing that the objection taken was not goo.
The fourth bill of exceptions presents a question of practice in this wise. The name of Benjamin Watson, the master of the prisoner, was enorse upon the inictment as a witness; he was summone as such for the State, was in attenance upon the trial, an with the other State’s witnesses was sworn in chief, but he was not interrogate or put upon the stan by the State as a witness. The prisoner claime the right to cross-examine him upon the whole case, an relie upon the English practice. The court overrule his motion. Upon an examination of the authorities, we think that the ecie preponerance in the American courts, is in favor of confining the right of cross-examination to those facts an circumstances only, connecte with the matters actually state in the irect examination of a witness; an that if the cross-examining party wishes to examine the witness as to other matters, he must o so by making the witness his own-, an calling him as such in the subsequent progress of the case (1 Greenl. Ev. part 3, ch. 3, sec. 445, p. 562.)
The fifth bill of exceptions presents the question whether the owner of a slave is a competent witness in a prosecution involving the life of the slave. In this case he was offere as a witness on the part of the prisoner; the State objecte because of his pecuniary interest as owner, an the court sustaine the objection. This question first was iscusse in North Carolina, in a case where a master refuse to testify against his slave, an on error his appeal was sustaine, but the court, in the iscussion lai great stress upon the fact of general incompetency,-because of the law of that State, which mae the master substantially a party to the recor, by reason of the provision for a jugment of ¡costs against him upon the conviction of his slave. (State vs. Charity, 2 Dev. Rep. 543). In that case, however, Chief Justice Henerson elivere a separate opinion from the majority of the court, an foreshaowe the principles which have since been recognize an aopte in some of the other slave States. He sai, “ My concurrence in the opinion of the court, in excluing the master on the groun of interest, is so feeble that it almost amounts to a issent. Where pecuniary interest only is at stake, to exclue a witness on the score of interest, however small, is applying a scale of morality to our nature sufficiently humiliating. But when the life or eath of a fellow being is to be the result of the trial, to exclue a witness because he may have a pecuniary interest, either in preserving or taking the life of the accuse, is attributing to us, frail as we know ourselves to be, more epravity than we are willing, I think, to amit. The rule, as lai own by the court, as I unerstan it, exclues the master on the same groun, that of interest, in becoming a witness for his slave; for the rule must be mutual. If he cannot be compelle to give evience against his slave, because of his interest, he cannot, even if he is willing, give evience for him on the same groun. I shoul rather suppose that the interest at stake, being so entirely ifferent from that which is orinarily brought forwar to protect a witness from giving evience, orto exclue him> if willing, that it is not to be weighe in the same balances with mere pecuniary interest. It is so transcenant in its nature that its weight is not to be ascertaine by mere money balances.”
The same question afterwars arose in Tennessee, in a case where, like in this before us, the master’s evience ha been rejecte by the Circuit Court, on the groun of interest. The court reverse the jugment for that error, an in elivering its opinion, by Reese, J., sai: “ But it is sai the Circuit Court erre in rejecting the master of the slave when offere as a witness in his favor, on the groun of his incompetency from pecuniary interest. An of this opinion are the court. A father has an interest, which may be valuable, in the services of his minor son, yet it is not questione that he can be a witness for or against him on a charge affecting his life. A master may have a pecuniary interest in the future labor an services of his apprentice, much exceeing, it may be in a few pursuits, the entire value of his slave: yet perhaps it has never occurre to any one that the master is incompetent to testify on behalf of the apprentice in a matter affecting his life. The relation of master an slave is inee ifferent; but in a case like this, the law, upon high grouns of public policy, pretermits for a moment that relation, takes the slave out of the hans of his master, forgets his claims an rights of property,” — as in the case, the juge might have ae, where the trespass for killing a slave is merge into the felony, an prohibits the recovery of the money value of the slave until the slayer has been first trie uner an inictment for the felony. (3 Porter Ala. Rep. 424)—“treats the slave as a rational an intelligent human being, responsible to moral, social an municipal uties an obligations an gives him the benefit of all the forms of trial which jealousy of power an love of liberty have inuce a freeman to throw aroun himself for his own protection. If thep the master knows any fact tening to save the life of the slave, shall society, who have taken from him the slave for the purpose of trial, say to him, not that you are master, an we will weigh your creit, but you are master an shall not speak at all! On grouns of public policy, of common humanity, of absolute necessity, the master must be hel to be competent as a witness for or against the slave. Society will not allow him to say, I have a pecuniary interest in the event of the trial, my testimony may subject me to a loss, an I will not testify against my slave. On the other han, humanity forbis that society shoul say, you have such an interest an shall not be hear to prove a fact in his favor. In cases where one slave may kill another, the master may often be the only person cognizant of his guilt, or the only person who can establish his innocence. Shall he refuse to speak in the one case, lest he incur a loss? Shall his lips be seale in the other, because he has an interest? Public policy an common humanity eclare the necessity of so treating this relation that the guilty shoul not escape punishment, or the ipnocent be mae to suffer.” (Elijah vs. The State, 1 Humph. R. 102.)
Afterwars, in the year 1841, a case raising the same question was brought before the High Court of Errors an Appeals in Mississippi. That also was a case where the master of the slave was offere as a witness for him in the Circuit Court, an that court refuse to allow him to testify, on the groun of interest; an for this error the Court of Errors reverse the jugment, an Chief Justice Sharkey, after approving the opinion of the court in Tennessee, which we have cite, as “base upon soun an humane principles” an recognizing the analogy to the case of master an apprentice, on the score of interest, then, in treating the question as one of public policy an common humanity, remarks as follows: “The master has the custoy of his slave an owes to him protection, an it woul be a rigorous rule inee if the master coul not be a witness in behalf of his slave 1 What woul be the conition of the slave, if the rule which bins him to perpetual servitue, shoul also create such an interest in the master as to eprive him of the testimony of that master? The harships of such a rule will illy comport with that humanitjr which shoul be extene to that race of people. In prosecutions for offences, negroes are to be treate as other persons: an although the master may have ha an interest in his servant, yet the servant ha such an interest in the testimony of his master as will outweigh mere pecuniary consierations, nor can he be eprive of the benefit of that testimony by the mere circumstance that in a civil point of view he was regare by the law as property.” Isham vs. The State, 6 How. (Miss.) R. 35.)
Recognizing these principles of law, public policy an common humanity, thus so aptly presente, as clearly soun, we aopt them without hesitancy, as the true exposition of the point of law in question, an therefore think it clear that the Circuit Court erre in refusing to allow Watson, the master, to testify when offere as a witness on the part of his slave, Austin, the appellant; holing that the matter of Watson’s pecuniary interest lay to his creibility only an not to his competency as a witness.
The remaining question relates to so much of the charge of the court as was objecte to an save in the sixth bill of exceptions. That was, “That if the jury shoul fin that the efenant was in rebellion to the authority of his master, Payne ha a right to take the efenant an to use such force as was necessary to take him, an that if the efenant then attacke Payne an slew him, he was guilty of murer, an his offence coul not be reuce to manslaughter, even although the striking of the efenant by Payne woul have been evience to show an extenuation of the killing of Payne by the efenant from murer to manslaughter, if the slave ha not been at fault in acting in rebellion to the authority of his master.”
From the face of this recor we cannot say that this charge is too latituinous an unqualifie, because the bills of exception neither purport to save all the evience prouce on the trial of the cause, nor all to which the charge was applicable, so as- to exclue any presumption in favor of the charge, that other evience in support of it might have been prouce. But without any regar to this consieration, we are free to say, that the tranquility of the public at large, the security of the master, the value of the slave as property, an the just protection an comfort of the slave himself, all epen so essentially upon his entire suborination to the lawful authority of his master, that we woul hesitate long before we woul eclare otherwise than that the principle, lai own in this charge, was any other than a soun general principle of the common law of slavery, as it exists in our slave States. In preserving this lawful suborination, upon which the best interests of the community, of the master, an of the slave, so raically epen, every citizen in common with the master, has an abiing interest. An when a slave is in rebellion to the lawful authority of his master, whatever force may be necessary to bring him within the pale of suborination, grauate upon principles of law an humanity, let it tcome from what quarter it may, invaes no right of the slave, an consequently oes him no such wrong as the law can recognize as a mitigation or excuse for crime. (Jacob vs. The State, 3 Humph. R. 493.)
For the error of the court below in refusing to allow Watson, the master, to testify, when offere as a witness on the part of the appellant, the jugment must be reverse an the cause remane to be proceee with to another trial an jugment.

case_name: Biscoe et al. vs. Sandefur ad. et al.
text_content:
S. H. Hempstea, Special Juge,
elivere the opinion of the court.
A serious objection exists to the jugment of May, 1848, which forbis us giving it.sanctity or effect. The act of the Legislature of 7th January, 1843', authorizing the Circuit Courts to recall jugments on elivery bons, was pronounce unconstitutional an voi by this court, in Byr vs. Brown, 5 Ark. 710, chiefly on the groun that the General Assembly possesse no power to authorize a Circuit Court to revise its own jugments- renere at a previous term. Nothing nee be ae to the reasoning in that case, because if any proposition is self-evient, it is, that if the Legislature can confer on the Circuit Courts authority to revise one class of erroneous jugments, the same power may be conferre in all cases, an thus effectually eprive this tribunal of its appellate jurisiction grante by the Constitution. This cannot be one, an hence recalling the previous jugment an entering jugment anew on the elivery bon, were proceeings coram non juice; an consequently the execution which issue on this new jugment, the levy on lans, their appraisement an offer for sale, were mere nullities, an must fall with the jugment, because no vali thing can spring from a voi thing. An this brings us to the first jugment on the elivery bon renere in 1842. It was taken on mere motion, without process or notice, without etailing the facts otherwise than in the jugment itself, an was unoubtely so erroneous, as to have been reversible on error, in a irect proceeing for that purpose, if that remey ha been sought by either party. It was, however, voiable merely, not voi; an accoring to the octrine in Boren vs. The State, 6 Eng. 519, must be regare by this court as a vali jugment, since the court pronouncing it was a superior court in contemplation of law, an ha jurisiction over the subject matter. There is then no alternative but to treat it as a bining jugment.
The attempt of the same court at a subsequent term to recall it ha no effect on it whatever. Fellows vs. Griffin, 9 Smees & Marsh. 362. Dow vs. Hunt, 11 Sm. & Marsh. 417.
An it may be remarke, that in aition to the unconstitutionality of the law above allue to, the court, on general principles, ha no power to set asie its own jugments after the term ha passe, inasmuch as jurisiction over the subject matter ha been exhauste, an to assume it again woul be the same, in its effect, as acting in a case where there was an entire want of jurisiction. This octrine has been approve by this court in the cases of Ashley vs. Hye, 1 Eng. 100; Cossitt vs. Biscoe, 7 Eng. 95, an Rawon vs. Rapley, 14 Ark., an has become the settle law of this tribunal.
The execution which issue on the original jugment was levie on two slaves as the property of Naborne T. Nelson, one of the efenants, on the 27th of November, 1841, an were restore to his possession, upon his giving a elivery bon, signe by all the efenants in the original jugment, with Ambrose K. Ellett as security, an this bon was forfeite an jugment renere on it, as state, in 1842, for the whole ebt; the slaves levie on having been of that value. The question then is irectly presente as to the effect of a levy an elivery bon on the original jugment, an the ifference between a simple forfeiture not pursue to jugment an an actual jugment on the elivery bon. An to a proper unerstaning of the subject in all its bearings, it will be necessary to avert to the previous an present law concerning elivery bons, noting such ifferences as may exist, but still regaring those laws as forming one system, accoring to the ancient rule of exposition, that acts in pari materia are to be construe together.
As a system it is sui generis, an has affore a fruitful fiel of litigation for more than ten years, an it woul seem to be high time that something shoul be settle with regar to it. The counsel of the appellants have well sai it is a “vexe question,” an although we might evae, yet we think it more compatible with uty to meet an ecie it. s
1.. An first as to a levy on personal property.
A levy on personal property belonging to the efenant, to an amount equal to the ebt, is a temporary satisfaction of the jugment. But if the' property is frauulently withrawn by the efenant, or by his procurement or agency from the custoy of the officer, or the efenant by his own act procures the release of the levy an the property comes again to his possession, it oes not amount to satisfaction. Ontario Bank vs. Hallet, 8 Cow. 194. Mickles vs. Haskin, 11 Wen. 126. Green vs. Burke, 23 Wen. 490. Ostraner vs. Walter, 2 Hill 331. Piper vs Elwoo, 4 Denio 165. McGinnis vs. Sillar’s Ex’r, 4 Bibb 490. Morrow vs. Hart, 1 A. K. Marshall 292. Porter vs. Boone, 1 Watts & Serg. 251. The People vs. Hopson, 1 Denio 578. Peck vs. Tiffany, 2 Comstock 456.
An this octrine, so conformable to justice an common sense, an so abunantly sustaine by the best authorities, has been sanctione by this court in cases running through a series of years, from the organization of the court to the present time. Walker vs. Braley, 2 Ark. 578. Caule vs. Dare, 2 Eng. 46. Sullivan vs. Pearce, 5 Eng. 500. Whiting & Slark vs. Beebe, 7 Eng. 548. Kelly vs. Garvin, 7 Eng. 617. The officer coul take no measure to force the ebtor to have the goos forthcoming at the ay of sale; an if the officer was boun to receive a sufficient elivery bon when tenere, an part, with the possession of the goos, was in no manner liable for them, coul take no measure to compel their elivery, an coul bring no action concerning them; it follows inevitably, in the language of Lor Holt, that there was “no person who coul make title to the goos by virtue of the execution,” an that the ebtor was therefore restore to his rights over them, 6 Mo. 292; 3 Munf. 433. The iea of legal custoy of them was utterly exclue, for, as has been shown, by the giving of the bon, the levy in contemplation of law was legally ispose of, an to still consier the goos as hel uner an by virtue of the execution woul be an absurity in itself. Malone vs. Abbott, 3 Humphries 532.
If there ha been no authority on this point at all, the previous statute woul settle the question; because if a forfeite elivery bon, not having the effect of a jugment an without jugment being sought or pronounce on it, coul amount to the extinguishment of the original jugment an satisfaction of the execution, no further levy coul possibly be mae, an the plaintiffs, nolens volens, woul be oblige to resort to the bon. But that law recognize both jugment an execution to be still effectual for all purposes. We have not lost sight of the fact that the 39th section of the execution law, authorizing the officer, when the conition of the bon was broken, to seize the same or any other property of the efenant subject to the execution, an sell the same on short notice to satisfy the execution, was repeale on the 3 December, 1840, Rev. Stat. 380; Acts 1840, p. 5. It was revive on the 6th of December, 1846. Acts 1846, p. 35. We have referre to, an argue from it merely to illustrate a general principle, an to evince the intention of the law maker at the time of the enactment of the system, as to the effect of a forfeite elivery bon pursue to jugment, an not pursue to jugment, an to emonstrate that such intention was in perfect harmony with general principles of law on the subject. Our reasoning an ecision however, rest on the latter an not on any statutory provision.
The original jugment mentione in the bill, was renere on the 8th of October, 1851;y?. fa. issue thereon the 27th of November, 1841; elivery bons execute on the 4th of March, 1842, an forfeite the 4th of April, 1842, an jugment was renere on the elivery bon, on motion, at the April term, 1842. All these proceeings were ha when the above section was not in force; an as the counsel for the appellants amit, that if there was no statute proviing that the lien shoul remain, an the sheriff seize an sell without process, the lien of the levy an the sheriff’s title are absolutely ischarge by giving a elivery bon: we might say shortly that there being no such statute, when the proceeings were ha, it woul follow on their own reasoning, that there was no lien on the slaves levie on, to be asserte or pursue, an that the court very properly refuse to recognize or enforce it, especially after such a lapse of time, an against bona fie purchasers at a public sale, who have ever been, an ought to be favorites of a court of equity, an whose titles or possessions are not to be isturbe except upon the strongest an most conclusive grouns, an certainly not on astute constructions, oubtful implications, or stale claims. There can be no question but that it is soun policy, as well as the uty of courts to strongly incline to uphol sales, mae uner the authority of law, an protect the title of puz’chasers, because pruent men az’e not ispose to risk their money in so precarious an izivestment as the purchase of law suits; an if szich a policy i not prevail the sacrifice of property at juicial sales woul be as ruinous as it woul be inevitable. But that proposition amits of a more conclusive answer, which is, fiz-st, that after the elivery bon the shez’iff has no title to the goos of any sort, an the levy is release; an secon, treating that section as not repeale, the effect woul be the same,because in the constz’uction of statutes, every part must stan it possible an that coul only be effecte, in cases circumstance as this is, by holing that their lien coul subsist no longer than the jugment remaine in foz’ce, an that if the plaintiff shoul abanon the original jugment an obtain a new jugment on the bon in cases where the property levie on was of equal value with the ebt, he must abie by all the consequences flowing fz’om that step; which have been eclare to be, that the original jugment was thereby extinguishe, its lien merge in the new jugment, an such lien as arose from the levy release an forever ischarge, an the execution en-' e. This, we think, was the true intention of the Legislature. This woul operate as a postponement of the collection of the ebt, an to that extent affor relief to the ebtor, an for which the creitor is suppose to have obtaine aitional security on the responsibility of the officer as to taking a sufficient bon.
Although not compelle, yet if the plaintiff electe to procee to jugment on the bon, then it was like an orinary case of waiving a lien create for his benefit, which waiver may be either express or implie. The statute fails to efine exactly how long the lien of a levy, so calle, shall last, or when it shall en, but that an the subsequent section authorizing the seizure of that or any other property of the efenant to satisfy the execution, when the conition of the bon was broken, an selling personal property on short notice, inicate clearly enough, when taken together, that the lien coul not subsist, when the ol was merge in the new jugment, since the accessary must follow' the principal. Harrison vs. Wilson, 2 A. K. Marsh. 551. An the reason of the rule is that the law', conemning a multiplicity of suits, which too often unnecessarily harrasss a efenant, will not as it has been sai, suffer two subsisting jugments on the same cause of action against the same iniviual. Nor oes this at all conflict with the rule, that a party, having several subsisting remeies, may pursue any one or all of them until he obtains actual satisfaction, (Taylor vs. Thomson, 5 Peters, 369); for that rule is not to be shaken or weakene.
Cases might an oubtless i occur uner the previous law, where the property seize was less in value than the ebt, an consequently the plaintiff ha no choice an was oblige, by motives of self interest an necessity, to procee on the original jugment, regarless of the elivery bon, thus showing that it coul not have been intene, as it coul not be in fact, a satisfaction, or tie up the hans of the plaintiff from proceeing on the jugment. This can never occur uner the existing law, because the bon covers the whole ebt, irrespective of the value of the property. The expression in the statute, that the “levy shall remain a lien upon the property,” means no more than that there is a lien upon it, not substantially ifferent from that general one which an execution creates upon being place in the hans of the officer. It oes not mean that the property is in legal custoy, or oes not belong to the efenant in the same manner as his other personal property, an the authority to seize it, “into whose possession soever the same may have passe,” was intene to guar against frauulent alienations; but not to inhibit bona fie sales before execution execute. The provision, that “no execution shall be a lien,” but from the time such writ •shall be elivere to the officer,” (Digest, 498), has been repeately hel not to alter the property of the goos until the execution is execute, (12 Johns. 406; 4 East, 536), an so, on a parity •of reasoning, the provision above allue to woul have no greater effect. An this exposition we conceive to be in exact accorance with the policy of the law, which oes not encourage liens •on personal property when the possession is parte with, be-, •cause such liens are of a secret nature, an ten to embarrass an obstruct the free alienation of property, so necessary in the trae an commerce of men. They open the oor to the perpetration of fraus on innocent persons, an owing to the mobility of personalty, nothing can be more uncertain than such liens an in no case shoul they be extene or enlarge by juicial construction, 26 Wen. 483. In point of ignity an certainty they are not like liens on real estate create by jugments, or evience by recore mortgages, for these are public an notorious, an preserve in the recors of the country, to which all have access, an of which all are boun to take notice, in all cases where the law makes such 'recors operate in that way.
The Legislature might have consiere that the seizure of property to answer the ebt, the release of the levy on giving a elivery bon, (8 Yerger, 161), an the passing of the goos out of the possession an custoy of the officer into the hans of the efenant again, might, in the absence of any enactment, be construe into the loss of all lien whatever; on a principle soun in law, that as a general rule, possession of personal property is essential to the creation as well as to the continuance of a lien on it. 2 Kent, 639. When a party voluntarily parts with the possession of the property, upon which a lien has attache, such lien is iveste, because it has been well sai, that if it was to follow the goos after they ha been sol or elivere, the incumbrance woul become excessively inconvenient to the freeom of trae, an the safety of purchasers. 1 Stra. 536; 1 East. 14; 2 East. 235; 7 East. 7; 26 Wen. 467; 7 Eng. 572. It has been sai by this court that the lien is only co-existent with the possession of the article, an being once surrenere, cannot be revive by any subsequently acquire possession. 2 Eng. 256. It is true that this octrine, arising from a ifferent lien, coul not apply in terms, but only by analogy to the lien of an execution, an to what we consier as the same in effect — the lien of a levy, since the latter too originates uner the execution an stans on the same footing. The Legislature therefore might not have thought it labor thrown away to exclue the conclusion that might otherwise have been rawn from the restoration of possession to the efenant.
But however full an inflexible an public the lien might be, still it coul not ischarge nor affect a jugment, nor amount to satisfaction, because it is inisputable, on both authority an principle, that a lien is neither a right in or to the thing, but is simply a right on the part of the creitor to have the property, charge with the lien, appropriate for the purposes of satisfaction, if he shall feel ispose to o so. 1 Peters. 443; 1 Mason, 221; 2 Peere Wms., 491. The fact, that the lien exists, oes not place the property in legal custoy, nor appropriate it to the payment of the ebt.
The two negroes, originally levie on an release upon giving the elivery bon, were sol uner an orer of court, at public sale, by the aministrator, as the property of Norbone T. Nelson, ecease, on the first of January, 1846, an purchase by Draper an Williams, two of the appellees.
From the views above expresse it is manifest, that the Real Estate Bank, ha no lien on, or claim to them, an the ecree of the court ismissing the bill as to them was correct.
Thomas M. R. Bankhea, as aministrator of Norbone T. Nelson, answere the bill an insiste that the claim set up by the complainants ha not been presente an authenticate accoring to law against the estate of his intestate within two years from the ate of letters of aministration, an that the same was barre. The court being of that opinion, ismisse the bill as to» him. This ecree we think was right. It falls within the principle ecie by this court in Walker vs. Byers, 14 Ark., where it was hel that, with the exceptions therein specifie, all claims an emans against the estates of ecease persons, whether legal or equitable, must be exhibite properly authenticate, within the perio of two years, or be forever barre. This claim is not within any of the exceptions an therefore that case is a ecisive authority on the question that the appellants can have no relief against the estate of Norbone T. Nelson, or his heirs, oristributees.
Whatever errors exist in the ecree as - to Joanna T. Carrington, aministratrix of Robert Carrington, ecease, Charles T. Nelson, an Ambrose K. Ellett, cannot be notice as these parties have not appeale, an certainly there is nothing,of which», the appellants have a right to complain.
Let the ecree be affirme.

case_name: Phillips, et al. vs. Wills, Pease & Co.
text_content:
Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This writ of error was sue out by the plaintiffs in error, to a jugment obtaine against them in the Clark Circuit Court, after execution ha been issue an levie upon their property, an they, together with others, as securities, execute a forthcoming bon, an the same ha been forfeite, an so returne by the sheriff, an the return term ha elapse, as appears by the ates set out. These facts were set up by plea, to which a emurrer was interpose, an the question is thus presente, whether the plaintiffs in error can now maintain their writ of error to the original jugment.
The constitutionality of the forthcoming law act was consiere an etermine in the case of Rearon, Ex parte, 4 Eng. R. 450. Its unconstitutionality was again urge in the case of Ruell vs. McGruer, (6 Eng. R. 584), an the point again rule as in the former case, with the aitional intimation that, after the lapse of the term, to which the forthcoming bon was returnable, the obligors of the bon coul fin relief only in a court of equity. Afterwars, in the case of Whiting & Slark vs. Beebe, et al. 7 Eng. R. 548, it was hel, that after the forfeiture of the bon the levy was ischarge an the former jugment was satisfie. An to the same effect are the cases of Wright vs. Yell, et al. 13 Ark. 505, an Jamison vs. May, i. 608. An in the case of The Trustees of the Real Estate Bank vs. Sanefur, a. et al. ecie uring the present term, where many of the cases ecie in Kentucky, Vix*ginia, Mississippi an the Feeral Court, as well as our own, are reviewe, it is shown that the statutory jugment is consiere as having the qualities, force, effect an ignity of a jugment, obtaine in the orinaiy moe of proceeing accoring to the course of the common law, in a court of competent jurisiction, an as such may be revive by scire facias, an, in another State, is within the act of Congress of 1790, an can no more be impeache collaterally than any other jugment, (Kelly vs. Lambs, 7 B. Monroe, p. 223.) An these cases sustain the ecision of this court in the case of Kelly et al. vs. Garvin, Carson & Co., (7 Eng. R. at p. 621), where it is hel that “the statutory jugment is an extinguishment of the first jugment upon the principle that a party cannot have more than one jugment for the same subject matter at the same time.”
These consequences resulting from the voluntary act of the efenant in the execution executing the forthcoming bon uner the provisions of the statute, it is no more unreasonable that he shoul thereby be cut off from any further remey in a court of law, an be riven to a court of equity exclusively for relief, as against any other jugment at law, than making an injunction operate as a release of errors at law.
We think the matters set up in the plea sufficient, an therefore the writ of error must be quashe.
Watkins, C. J., i not sit.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins sai,
The question presente in this case, is the same as that ecie in Hart, et al. vs. Wills, Pease & Co., on a former ay of this term. The efenant in error pl'eas in bar of the writ, that before it was sue out, a writ of fieri facias issue upon the jugment complaine of as being erroneous, an the execution being levie upon certain goos of the efenants, for the prouction of which, at the time an place of sale, they ha entere into a elivery bon with security, an containing the further conition prescribe by the act of Deccember 16th, 1846, that in case the property, specifie in the bon, shoul not be elivere as provie therein, the bon shoul have the force an effect of a jugment, on which an execution might be issue against all the obligors therein; that the property not being elivere nor the execution pai, the sheriff ha uly returne the execution unsatisfie, together with the elivery bon eclare to be forfeite, &c.,'to which plea the plaintiffs in error have emurre.
It might be sufficient to say that the ecision of the court is in accorance with that mae in Hart vs. Wills, Pease & Co., before referre to, overruling the emurrer; but as this is the first opportunity I have ha of expressing any opinion of my own on this subject, it seems to be proper that 1 shoul avail myself of at, though in a very brief manner.
When this question was first raise, I thought there were serious ifficulties attening the etermination of it, either way. When the act of December 1846 was passe, after several years of uncertainty an litigation, the effect of elivery bons an the moe of obtaining jugments upon them, where the creitor chose to pursue that course, ha come to be settle an unerstoo accoring to pre-existing statutes; an though oubtless enacte with the earnest intention of strengthening the obligation of contracts by facilitating the remey for any breach of them, it seeme to me that the various questions, growing out of the proper construction to be given to the amenatory statute, so as to harmonize it with the general law as it stoo before, an some of which never coul have been anticipate by the framers of the amenment, woul unfortunately be prouctive of renewe litigation. But while those ifficulties might have to be anticipate an consiere in construing the new law, they woul affor no color of license for isregaring its plain provisions, if within the pale of legislative power.
I am free to say, the oubt in my min has been whether the statute giving to a forfeite elivery bon the force an effect of a jugment, with all its conclusive an unimpeachable qualities,, was constitutional. Though the ecisions of this court, in Rearon, ex parte, 4 Eng. 450, an Ruell vs. Magruer, 6 ib, 578, sustaining its valiity, were imperative upon me, I might still have thought the law constitutional for the only purpose appearing to-be contemplate by it, that is, the summary issuance of execution; an to this en the elivery bon coul be likene to a general power of attorney, whereby the obligors authorize the sheriff to take an sell any property belonging to them for the purpose of paying a particular ebt. An this woul be leaving-out of view the various further questions, that might have to be etermine, some of them being whether the statutory jugment on the elivery bon became a lien on the property of the principal an securities, an therefore constructive notice to subsequent incumbrancers an purchasers, thus laying the founation, for a train of ajuications growing up into a law of property; whether it woul be respecte uner the authentication act of' Congress, when sought to be mae the founation of an action, in another State: whether a writ of error woul lie to it, as to the final jugment of a court; whether the same presumptions are to be inulge in its favor, as woul be accore to the jugment of a court of general jurisiction; an lastly this question, whether it was such a merger or extinguishment, that no writ of error coul afterwars lie to the jugment upon which the execution issue.
Accoring to the former elivery bon law, where there was a forfeiture by the non-elivery of the property, the plaintiff, not. choosing to sue out alias execution, might either bring an orinary action at law upon the bon, or he might obtain a jugment at any time uring the return term against the obligors, on summary motion an without notice or process. The power to rener a jugment without notice, was for a long time oubte, as being contrary to natural justice. But then the only question was, whether the obligors in the bon might not contract for notice, either as a waiver or an acceptance of it in avance of the suit. Yet whether upon actual or constructive notice, there was, in such cases, the intervention of juicial power; the formality at least of a juicial consieration an sentence.
Amitting that a party may well contract for notice of a jugment to be renere against him by a court of competent jurisiction, the ifficulty here woul still be, whether he can contract that his contract shall be a jugment. Because if this be law, the same principle might come to be greatly extene in its application to a variety of cases, whereby jugments woul spring into being without the intervention of juicial power. The policy or propriety of constitutional legislation is no official concern of a juge; but regaring the juiciary as an inepenent an coorinate epartment of the government, it becomes his uty to maintain its authority an assert its jurisiction, for wise purposes conferre by the organic law an for the time being entruste to his keeping. I can unerstan that, as the conclusive effect of a jugment operates by way of estoppel, the General Assembly might, by legislation, attach the same consequences to a contract voluntarily entere into by the parties to it, though it coul harly be sai to be of the same grae of ignity an solemnity; the ifference being that in the one case the party is estoppe by his own voluntary act, while the suitor at law has the right, with the ai of a court, to conclue his aversary by its jugment, against his will. Yet the receive iea, the recognize efinition of a jugment has always been that it is the exercise of juicial power. So that, to constitute a jugment, there must not only be a subject matter, about which an ajuication is sought, a plaintiff an efenant, whose rights are to be affecte by it, but a juge also, or court through whom the law speaks, an who is authorize to eclare its sentence. It was owing to this view that the case of Pickett & Gregg vs. Thruston, 2 Eng. 397, the authority of which is now fully establishe, may not have been regare as a safe preceent.
Sincerely esiring to uphol the statute giving to forfeite elivery bons the force an effect of jugments, I am enable to yiel to the authoritative opinions of my brother juges; but in oing so, feel it incumbent on me to characterize the statute referre to as a angerous innovation in the law, an one which in principle cannot, consistently with the constitution, be any further extene. Consent being amitte as the sole founation for these statutory jugments, I concur in the views expresse in The Trustees R. E. Bank vs. Sanefur, uring the present term, which treats them as jugments for all purposes. Otherwise the most injurious consequences woul follow; inee, there ought to be no mile groun, if it coul be avoie by any reasonable interpretation. An though this be one, many perplexing controversies may be expecte to grow out of the statute.
Demurrer overrule.

Mr. Justice Walker,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
'* Elijah D. Robins, in his life time, obtaine a jugment before a-justice of the peace against William Marlow, an for the purpose of’ having execution against the real estate of the efenant, as provie for by the statute, Dig. ch. 95, file a transcipt of such jugment in the Circuit Court clerk’s office; but before satifaction thereof was ha, the plaintiff ie, an his executor, John Robins,' sue out scire facias to revive the jugment in his name as such: executor! At the return term the efenant file his plea to the jurisiction of the Circuit Court, which plea, on motion of the plaintiff, was stricken out, an jugment renere in favor of the plaintiff.
If this ha been an original suit upon the contract sue upon, or upon the jugment renere in the justice’s court thereon, there can be no oubt but that the Circuit Court ha no jurisiction to hear an etermine the same, because the amount in controversy is a matter of contract for some $35, a matter exclusively within the jurisiction of a justice of the peace. But this was a proceeing uner the statute to reach the real estate of the ebtor to satify a jugment renere before a competent tribunal. The transcript, when file, ha uner the statute the force an effect of a jugment renere in the Circuit Court, as well to-bin the real estate by lien, as for process an sale uner it, with-no reference, however, to any ajuication upon the cause of action, because that ha alreay been ajuicate, but solely by the ai of the process of the Circuit Court to have satisfaction of the jugment,-
Such being the object of the statute, such transcript when file has the force an effect of a jugment in that court for that purpose. The object woul, in cases like the present, fail unless the court has the power to keep its process alive by reviving the jugment, so as to enable the plaintiff to sue out process. It is true that, in a limite sense, a proceeing by sci. fa, is a suit upon which an issue may be forme, but that issue is substantially an -enquiry into the right of the plaintiff to have execution of the jugment, an is not an infringement upon the constitutional jurisiction of the justices of the peace.
The plea of the efenant was therefore insufficient, an upon emurrer shoul have been so ajuge; but as a matter of practice, as settle by this court in the case of Sanger vs. State Bank, at the present term, the objection coul not be reache by a motion to strike the plea from the files!
For this error the jugment of the Circuit Court must be reverse an the case remane for further proceeings to be ha «ot inconsistent with this opinion.

Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
Waiving any objection to the manner in which the questions of law, suppose to be involve in this case, were sought to be-reserve in the court below, we may assume, for the consieration of them here, that the facts (an which might reaily have-been put into the shape of an agree case, or a special verict by the court below sitting as a jury), are as follows. In 1808 Asa Grant ie in North Carolina, leaving a will, one clause of which is in these wors, “ I further give unto my belove wife, (Jemmima), one negro woman, known by the name of Harriett,- an her issue, uring her natural life, an after her eath the sai negro woman Harriet an her issue, I give an bequeath-unto my belove aughters, Clarissa Grant an Polly Grant, to be equally ivie amongst them.” Jemmima Grant, the wiow,. marrie Arthur Morrow;, an they move to Tennessee, an from thence to Arks ansas, where she ie in the year 1848. Clarissa Grant marrie Eli Cox, in Tennessee, where they continue to live! Polly Grant marrie Hiram Williams an they move to Texas, where she ie in the year 1845, leaving several chilren, the issue of their marriage, who are still living. In 1849 Williams sol an conveye all his right, title an interest in the slaves in controversy to Pack an Cates, two 'of the appellants. From the time of his marriage with Jemmima Grant, Morrow always ha possession of Harriet an her; issue, in right of his wife, an after her eath, in 1848, he continue to keep them in possession, never until then claiming them as his own. The negroes now in controversy pre Delia, who is the aughter of Harriet, an George the chil of Delia.
Upon the refusal of Morrow to surrener them, when emane by the appellants, they sue him by action of replevin in the etinet. The efenant pleae non-etinet, an a special plea asserting property in himself, with a traverse of property in the plaintiffs. The court sitting as a jury foun upon the evience, for the efenant, an he ha jugment accoringly.
1. The action of replevin in the etinet, as now regulate by statute, is very similar to etinue, an may be sai to lie in all cases where the plaintiff has the right of property, either general or special, an the right to immeiate possession of a chattel taken or etaine by the efenant, an iffers from etinue in this; that in replevin the plaintiff obtains possession of the chattel in avance of the trial, an the efenant is suppose to be protecte from the harshness of the remey by the affiavit an bon of the plaintiff, an the short perio of limitation prescribe for it! The plea of non-etinet (Digest, Title, Replevin, sec. 34), puts in issue, not only the wrongful etention of the chattel, but the property of the plaintiff therein, an the special traverse pleae here ha no other effect than to tener a istinct an formal issue of the plaintiffs’ property, general or special, an right to possession at the time of suit brought. The action may be maintaine, not only for the breach of a contract of bailment, but the allegation of bailment is fictitious an not traversable; so that replevin in the etinet extens to all cases where the property of one man is wrongfully in the possession of another, though that possession may have been, in its inception, both peaceable an lawful; as in the case of a bailment eterminable by eman. It results from the nature of the action, which is to recover possession of a specific chattel, that if there be several part owners of it, they ought all to be joine as plaintiffs in the suit, an the non-joiner or misjoiner of parties in interest, who ought to be plaintiffs, is available in bar as well as in abatement. Although classe among actions ex elicto, an in theory the remey for a tortious taking, replevin in the etinet iffers essentially from actions ex elicto, where, for the injury, loss or estruction of personal property, owne by two or more persons in common, each part owner might consistently recover several amages, which woul be commensurate with his interest in the chattel, though the chattel itself be not susceptible of ivision. We think, therefore, the plaintiffs were require, uner the pleaings in this case, to show that, as against the efenant, they were the persons an the only persons having such right of property, as woul entitle them to present possession of the slaves in controversy.
2. There is no where upon the recor any allegation or proof of what was the law in North Carolina, the omicil of the testator when his will took effect in the year 1808, or of Tennessee, where Williams an Polly Grant were marrie, or of the law of Texas, where Polly Williams resie at the time of her eath, in 1845; all of which were legitimate subjects of proof, an might perhaps have been important in etermining the rights of the parties; in the first instance, as to the character of the limitation, by way of executory evise, in the will of Asa Grant; in the secon, for ascertaining what right Williams acquire, by his marriage, to the property in possession or expectancy of his wife; an lastly, whether by the law of Texas he succeee at her eath, as heir or istributee, to her property or right of property in the slaves.
It must be assume, as a settle proposition, that the courts of one State or sovereignty cannot juicially take notice of the laws of another an foreign State. They will by comity respect the foreign law, by protecting rights acquire uner it, an will interpret an fulfill the obligation of contracts mae in a foreign State, or with reference to its laws, but those laws are to be prove as facts upon which the claim or efence is base, though this rule of comity is subject to exceptions, where the right claime uner the foreign law is contrary to goo morals, public policy or positive legislation in the country where it is sought to be enforce. The origin an peculiar relations of the American States involve the consieration of this subject, so liable to expan itself, in many perplexities. In Connecticut it seems, Hale vs. The New Jersey Steam Navigation Co., 15 Conn. 539, that by statute, comity is carrie to the extent of requiring her courts to notice juicially the statutes an the reports of ecisions by the courts of other States of the Union; thus imposing upon them, as may reaily be imagine, a most elicate as well as ifficult uty. Notwithstaning the law of this State only relaxes the rule of evience by proviing, that the printe statute books of other States, purporting to be publishe by authority, shall be receive as evience of their contents, several cases are to be foun in the reporte ecisions of this court, not the least Remarkable among which is Mooy vs. Walker, 3 Ark. 147, where counsel argue an the court referre, for the rule of ecision, to what was unerstoo to be the common or statute law of other States, without any amission or proof of it appearing to have been mae in the inferior court.
The courts of every State are boun to take juicial notice of the public laws an treaties of the Unite States; because, to the extent of the powers elegate to the feeral government, an the subjects about which Congress may rightfully legislate, they form one country: while on the other han, the life of the feeral juiciary an its stronghol on the affections of the people epen upon respecting the reserve sovereignty of the States, an the ue aministration of their respective systems of law or local usage, uner which private rights have veste. An unless with the anomalous exception of the civil law proceure in Louisiana, goo policy has always ictate a conformity with the remeies furnishe by the State laws. So that, in a case like the present, a court of the Unite States, otherwise acquiring jurisiction by citizenship of the parties an value in ispute, woul be enable to know juicially the law of any State, an all moifications of it affecting the title to the slaves in controversy upon the facts here proven. An where two countries have the same origin, or were at one time associate, the courts of each are boun to take juicial notice of what the law was, when it was common to both. Thus, before their separation, the laws of Missouri extene over what is now Arkansas; an the courts of the new States, forme out of territory which belonge originally to one of the thirteen colonies, might have to look to the jurispruence of the parent State, while its laws were in force over the entire territory. No such relation has ever existe between Arkansas an Carolina, Tennessee, or Texas.
