Our English ancestors, who colonize America, brought with them certain funamental principles of the common law, such as the right of trial by jury, an the privilege of habeas corpus, which were essential to the enjoyment of civil liberty in Englan, as they are here. But it cannot be sai that the great boy of the common law, or the English Statutes, passe in ai of it, prevaile in the colonies, 1 Black. Com. 107, an it cannot be presume that it prevails now entire in any of the States of this Union. Even if the perios of its aoption coul be ascertaine, an a istinction taken between the common an statute law of Englan, we must know, as matter of legal history, that in every American State many of its leaing features have been abrogate or change by legislation, or essentially moifie by local common law or usage. Of so much of the common law, as has been expressly aopte, or is tacitly recognize, the reporte ecisions of the courts in Englan ought to be regare as its expositors. But even such aoption is partial, an isjointe: nor .are the ecisions of the courts of this country, feeral as well as State, in harmony with one another, or with those of the courts in Englan, upon a variety of purely common law questions. Even in cases involving commercial law, where#uniformity is so much to be esire, the ecisions of each State, liable to be influence by local consierations, not appreciable in another, cannot there be always safely followe as preceents. We nee not look beyon the case uner consieration for examples of such iversity of law. It is to be inferre from a provision containe in the Revise Statutes of North Carolina, vol. 1, ch. 37, sec. 22, passe in the year 1823, an the ecisions in that State, cite in Inge vs. Murphy, 10 Ala. 885, that previous to the statutes referre to, a limitation of a remainer in a chattel after a life estate, like that containe in the'will of Asa Grant, woul be effectual in North Carolina, by way of executory evise, but such limitation, if mae by ee, woul not have been vali, an the first taker woul have the absolute estate.
In Newton, ex’r vs. Cocke, ex'r. 5 Eng. 169, where suit was brought here by one claiming to be a foreign executor, by virtue of the statute authorizing foreign executors an aministrators, appointe in other States or territories of the Unite States, uner the laws thereof, to sue in any of the courts of this State in their representative capacity with like effect as if they ha been qualifie uner the laws of this State, in as much as the exemplification of the recor of the will in Kentucky prouce an oyer, i not affor any evience of the appointment or qualification of the plaintiff, suing as executor, an there being no evience of what the law of Kentucky was, an it coul not be juicially recognize here, .this court felt itself calle upon to presume that the law of Englan, as it stoo at the time of the American revolution, prevaile in Kentucky, an to etermine with apparent reference to it, the sufficiency of the evience auce to prove the appointment an qualification of the plaintiff, as executor. ■ An that course seeme unavoiable because the statute, by referring to the law of the State uner which the executor erive his authority, exclue the iea that his qualification was to be teste by the law of this State. But apart from that or like exceptions., which might be occasione by unguare legislation, the courts of this State have no warrant for knowing juicially, an so aministering the law of any other State or country foreign to this: an outsie of the feeral compact the States of this Union are to be regare as foreign to each other. In 1816 the Territorial Legislature of Missouri, formally aopte an eclare in force the common law of Englan of a general nature an all statutes of the British Parliament in ai of, or to supply the efects of the common law, mae prior to the fourth year of James the first an of a general nature, an not local to that kingom, an which common law an statutes were not contrary to the laws of that territory, an not repugnant to, nor inconsistent with the constitution an laws of the Unite States, as the rule of ecision in that territory, until altere or repeale by the Legislature: an that statutory aoption has ever since continue to be in force uner the territorial an State governments in Arkansas. Having thus intronce the common law, without inee the benefit of any of the juicious statutory reforms in Englan since the fourth year of James the first, when we aminister that law, or what is left of it consistent with our own coifications, we o so, not because it is the law of Englan, but because it is part of our own law. It is therefore the law of the forum, to which they have submitte, that, in the absence of proof or amission of any other, is to etermine the rights of the parties, no matter where the transactions occurre out of which those rights may spring. If the contract, for a breach of which suit is brought here, was mae, or to be performe in another State, the law of that State, unless shown to be ifferent, is presume to be the same as our own. So that if either plaintiff or efenant, asserting or resisting a eman by suit, claime that the law, peculiar to another State an applicable to the case, arising upon the facts proven, is ifferent from that of the forum, he can only obtain the benefit of the foreign law, by making it a part 'of the case in evience,
3. One of the questions mainly argue is, whether Williams succeee as istributee to the choses in action of his ecease wife, or her chattels not reuce into possession uring the coverture; an, supposing that he woul be entitle to them, whether he or any assignee of his coul bring- an action for their recovery, without taking out aministration upon his wife’s estate an suing in a representative capacity. It will be concee, that at the common law, the custom grew up for the husban to be entitle to receive from the orinary the elegate power of aministering upon the wife’s estate, an, becoming possesse of the goos as aministrator, he was allowe to retain any surplus after the payment of the ebts, without being require to make istribution to her next of kin. But neither the statute of 22 Chas. 2, requiring aministrators to make istribution; nor that of 29th of Chas. 2, exempting the husban, aministering in right of his being such, from the uty of making istribution, an thus recognizing his legal right to'retain the surplus, ever ha any force or operation in this State. An for the source of the husban’s right to aminister, it woul harly be necessary to go back to the common law; supersee here by a statutory system of aministration.
. Accoring to the Territorial law, Steel & McCamp, Dig., Title Aministration, sec. 4, the husban or wife ha the preference, before the next of kin, in aministering upon the estate of the other; an that law, ib. Title Descents an Distributions, unertook to efine accurately what interest the husban, surviving •his wife, shoul take in her real estate an slaves an personal estate in possession or in action, varie by the contingencies of her ying with or without issue. The Revise Statutes succeeing the Territorial law, re-enacte so much of it, Title, Aministration, sec. 6, as require letters to be “grante to the representatives of the intestate who may apply for the same an are qualifie, preferring first, the husban, or wife,.or one of the persons entitle by law to a istribution of t]ie intestate’s estate,” an though the language there use, woul seem as if intene to apply to a state of Case, where by law the husban or wife surviving woul succee, as istributee, to the whole, or some part of the estate of the other, yet the statute of Descents an Distributions, as re-moelle by the revisors, negatives any such apparent intention. The first section of that chapter provies, that “when any person shall ie having title to any real estate of inheritance or personal estate, not ispose of nor otherwise limite by marriage settlement, an shall ie intestate as to such estate, it shall escen an be istribute in parceny to his kinre, male an female, subject to the payment of ebts an the wiow’s ower, in the following manner; first to chilren or their escenants in equal parts,” &c. In aition to that section, which woul impose upon every aministrator the uty of making istribution in accorance with it, because no exception is any where mae in favor of the husban, the 7th section exclues all right of his by proviing, that in the event of there being no chilren or their escenants, or any paternal or maternal kinre capable of inheriting, the whole estate shall go to the wife or husban of the intestate, an if there be no husban or wife, then to escheat. Though an examination at large of this subject, an especially as connecte with a more recent enactment of December 8th, 1846, enabling marrie women to become seize or possesse of property, real or personal, in their own right, while the former law, enying to them the general power of testamentary isposition, is retaine in force, woul isclose much of lamentable uncertainty an inconsistency, we have no iscretion to construe away what appears to be the necessary result of the statute, whether so intene or not, 1 Swift Digest 28. Reeves Dom. Rel. 16. Bunch's a. vs. Hurst's am'r 3 Dessau. 289. Gough vs. Crane. 3 Marylan Chy. Rep. 127, an must conclue that as the law now stans, the husban surviviving is entitle only to the preference in the aministration of the estate of the wife, to enable him to recover her choses in action not ispose of or converte by him, an her personal property, not reuce to possession uring coverture, for the purpose of paying her ebts an making istribution of the surplus among her next of kin, to all of whom he is postpone in the succession.
It is not pretene that two of the plaintiffs have sue here in a representative capacity; an assuming the law to be as we have state it, we nee not enquire further whether the husban, entitie as istributee of the wife’s estate, shoul nevertheless sue as her aministrator; though we apprehen, that in such case he woul come uner the general rule, that in an action at law to recover the personal property of an intestate, the plaintiff must erive title by or through an aministrator.
4. Conceing that Morrow, upon the eath of his wife, who ha the use of the negroes uring her life, cease to have any right to etain them from those entitle in remainer, the only remaining groun contene for in argument, upon which the present plaintiffs can expect to recover, is that the interest of Polly Grant in the negroes being a veste one, though in remainer, it became also, upon her marriage with Williams, transferre to an veste in him as absolutely as it was in her. The argument is, that the negroes were not choses in action, but property, the possession of which is always presume to be with the title; that the possession of Morrow, in right of his wife an uring the continuance of her life estate, was not averse but consistent with the title of .those in remainer, an consequently, his possession was their possession, in like manner as if he ha been a mere bailee.
Plausible as that may appear, we apprehen the law to be Well settle, that marriage is a gift to the husban of personal property an choses in action of the wife, subject to the conition of his reucing them to possession uring coverture, an that being accomplishe the gift becomes absolute. By the marriage he becomes liable for her ebts previously contracte, but such liability ceases upon the issolution of the marriage by her eath, if not before that time enforce by suit against him. The creitors of the wife woul then be without remey, unless they can resort to the separate property of the wife, or her chattels, or choses in action, not reuce to possession by the husban uring coverture. Accoring to the law in Englan an many of the Unite States, the husban surviving is entitle to all such property of the wife, which he is entitle to recover as her aministrator, thus afforing a fun for the payment of the ebts of the wife whilst sole, an he retains the resiue absolutely, succeeing to it in the character of husban. The’ husban uring coverture, may sell or transfer by assignment, legal or equitable, for a valuable consieration, his wife’s choses in action, her chattels not reuce to possession, or, in more general terms, all her right to the present or future enjoyment of them; but if he ie without making such isposition, the title to them has not been change an they survive to the wife in preference to the aministrator of the husban. So that the marriage oes not operate transfer to the husban as an absolute gift, all the property to which the wife may be entitle, but only the power, by virtue of her right of property, of recovering or reucing it to his possession uring the coverture; though inee there may be a variety of vexe questions in practice, not affecting the theory, concerning what acts of the husban will constitute a reuction to possession. The later ecisions in Englan not only hol that as against the wife surviving, the husban must have exercise his power of alienation uring the coverture, but they go to the extent of making the valiity of the husban’s alienation contingent upon a reuction to possession by the assignee uring the coverture, not only in respect of sales of reversionary interests of the wife, which might not fall in, but of all choses in action, though at the time of assignment susceptible of being immeiately reuce into possession; proceeing upon the groun that such being the extent of the husban’s power, his sale or assignment passes no greater authority than he himself ha. If that apparent change in the common law is inuce by a esire to enlarge the equitable claim of the wife to a settlement or possession for her support, similar to that policy which has prompte the recent statutes in this country, allowing the wife to take an hol a separate property, it may be efective because its benefits are precarious; but it has the merit of enabling a court to affor, in harmony with the common law, an aequate provision for the wife where she nees it, an without any of the jealousies an heart-burnings attening a separation of interests while the marrie relation subsists. But without reference to what may be terme a new feature in the law, it oes seem that, upon ol an establishe principles applicable to the present case, the husban, Williams, i not acquire any absolute property in the slaves in controversy. The two aughters ha a veste remainer, which gave them a fixe right of future enjoyment, but the beneficial use of the slaves was in the mother uring her life.’ The right of possession was with the temporary use, which Williams coul not lawfully isturb, an as his wife ie before the etermination of the life estate, it was not possible that he, or any assignee of his coul have reuce it to possession uring coverture. At her eath, without any previous isposition of them by him, his power to sell her choses in action, or rights of property in expectancy cease, equally with his own right to recover them! It is true, those entitle in remainer to a specific chattel have an interest in preserving it, an may by injunction prevent its removal, or restrain those having the temporary use, from acts tening to injure or eteriorate it, an not necessary to a reasonable or juicious enjoyment. If estroye they might have a remey in trespass for amages, equivalent to the value of their interest in remainer; but there coul be no remey for those in remainer, inconsistent with the temporary right of possession in the person having the particular estate.
Upon an examination of the cases cite for the appellant in support of the position, that Williams by his marriage acquire an absolute title to his wife’s estate in remainer in the slaves even though she ie before the etermination of the particular estate, an not subject to any contingency of the property being reucible into possession uring the coverture, it will be foun that the octrine ha its origin at a very early ay in Virginia, the first reporte case being that of Dae vs. Alexaner, 1 Wash. 30, an the sole reason given in the report of the case, was the statement of the Presient of the court of appeals; that such ha been the constant ecision of the ol general court from the year 1653, to the revolution, since confirme in the then court of appeals in several cases, an that it ha thus become a fixe an settle rule of property. In Wallace vs. Taliafero, 2 Call., the same court, eviently embarrasse by having to ahere to another an inconsistent rule of the common law, yet respecte the former ecisions an uphel them upon the only intelligible groun, assigne by the Presient of the court, that he “ha consiere the principle as a fixe rule of property tening to quiet isputes.” The same remark is applicable to Robinson’s am’r vs. Brock, 1 Hen. & Munf. 224, an Wae vs. Boxley, 5 Leigh 442. In Dummon vs. Snee, 2 Call. 494, the sale by the husban surviving, of a slave to which his wife ha been entitle in remainer, was sustaine on that groun, an also because he was empowere to sell as aministrator. It was natural that the course of ecisions on this subject in Virginia, the parent State, shoul have been aopte in Kentucky. The first case where it appears to have been followe is Pinkar vs. Smith, Littell Sel. cas. 336; an there the court say, “Except for the purpose of ascertaining the proper parties to the present contest, it is not however material whether the husban was entitle to the remainer in the slaves, merely as surviving husban, or in virtue of his right to aminister on the wife’s estate.” In Bank’s am’r vs. Marksberry, 3 Littell 281, the rule was istinctly asserte, though it may have been influence by a statute of Kentucky there quote, an the court enter into the same argument use here, to establish a ifference between choses in action, which o not vest in the husban unless reuce into possession uring the coverture, an his marital rights in the wife’s expectancies in remainer; an argument which implies that the rule sought to be introuce was an innovation, an not a familiar principle of the common law! It has been since followe in that State, Ewing vs. Hanley, 4 ib. 346. Jackson vs. Sublett, 10 B. Mon. 471, though an attempt to reconcile all the cases, Tilfor vs. Anerson, 7 Dana 108. Turner vs. Davis, 1 B. Mon. 152. Thomas vs. Kenney, 4 ib. 236. Hor vs. Hor, 5 i. 83. Bowling am’r vs Bowling, 6 i. 33. Ring vs. Balrige, 7 ib. 535. Davenport vs. Brewett, 9 ib. 95, bearing upon the rule contene for, woul result in emonstrating it to be an exception, which the courts of that State have been eneavoring to limit in its application to the precise state of ease occurring in Dae vs. Alexaner, where but for the exclusion of the creitors, if any, of the wife um sola, it woul be immaterial whether the husban surviving took as such, or as aministrator of the wife. The case of Magil vs. Tolan, 8 Porter 36, stans upon its special circumstances, as woul appear from the subsequent case of Bibb vs. McKinley, 9 ib. 637, an ecies only that the possession of the guarian is the possession of the war. The case of Pitts vs. Curtis, 4 Ala. 350, (not within reach) has also been cite for the appellants,but as referre to an qualifie in Broome vs. King, 10 ib. 821, it appears to have been base solely upon the authority of Dae vs. Alexaner an Banks vs. Marksberry. An in this connection it is worthy of remark that the octrine of some of the later cases in Englan, Hornsby vs. Lee, 2 Ma. Chy. 16. Paren vs. Jackson, 1 Russ. 1, an Honnor vs. Morton, 3 Russ. 65, before allue to, has been formally recognize by the court of appeals in Virginia, Browning vs. Healey, 2 Robinson 370, though it may be subject to their peculiar istinction between the wife’s remainer in a chattel an her choses in action.
On the whole, we conclue that, whatever may be the result in a suit between other parties, or uner a ifferent state of proof, accoring to the case mae by the recor before us, upon the eath of Polly Williams, her estate in the slaves in controversy evolve upon her next of kin, accoring to the statute of istributions, an woul be recoverable by her aministrator for their benefit, an consequently two of the plaintiffs, claiming as assignees of the husban, have faile to establish any legal title in themselves.
Affirme.

case_name: Yell, Governor, &c., use of Conant & Co. vs. Outlaw et al.
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court*
The peculiar state of case, upon which the question here to be etermine arises, is as follows : Upon the remaning of this cause, after the ecision of it by this court, reporte in 3 Eng. 345, various amene pleas were interpose by the several efenants, to which the plaintiffs replie, an upon which issues of fact were forme, properly triable by a jury. We o not now consier or etermine, whether those issues were material or immaterial, or the legal sufficiency of any of the pleas to bar the action; because that enquiry is not now involve, an the plain-' tiffs having treate the pleas as sufficient, we may inten that they were so, an that they were amene in accorance with the intimations containe in the opinion of this court, before cite. A reference to that opinion an the previous report of the same case, Outlaw vs. The Governor, 5 Ark. 468, will explain the nature of the suit which was against the principal an securities on the official bon of an aministrator, an the various efences interpose. Upon the last trial of the cause a jury was empam nele an sworn to try the issues joine. There were also issues upon pleas of nul liel recor, which, being submitte to the coart, were foun in favor of the efenants: “An thereupon,” as state in the recor, “the plaintiffs excepte to the fining of the court upon sai issues, an immeiately file their bill of exceptions in respect thereof, which is signe, seale an orere to form a part of the recor herein. Whereupon the plaintiff refusing to procee further in the cause, it is orere by the court that the jury empannele in the cause be ischarge.” Then follows the jugment of the court, that the plaintiffs take nothing by their writ, an that the efenants go thence without ay an recover their costs, &c. It appears from the bill of exceptions that the plaintiffs offere in evience certain recors which are set out, to prove the recovery of jugment in the original suit by Conant & Co. against the aministrators, an which was all the evience auce in the cause.
The fining of the court, that there was no such recor, was without oubt, a gross error; the issues an the evience being the same in respect of which this court ecie, when the cause was here before, (3 Eng. 353,) that the court below ha correctly foun in favor of the plaintiffs: nor woul an enquiry be tolerate of an after iscovere variance, if any such be allege. An inasmuch as those issues were triable by the court itself, not sitting as a jury, having a plain uty to fin the evience sufficient, which the previous ecision of this court ha mae a foregone conclusion, there coul be no hesitation in reversing the jugment, if that was the only question; isregaring the point argue for the efenants upon the authority of The State Bank vs. Conway, 13 Ark. 344, where there was an exception to the fining of the court sitting as a jury, certifying the evience without raising any question of law.
But that error of the court i not, in our opinion, warrant the plaintiffs in stopping the cause there, an refusing to procee any farther with it. It is a clear proposition that a plaintiff woul not be entitle to jugment when there is a goo plea in unanswere, Cole vs. Wagnon, 2 Ark. 154. Boyer vs. Robinson, 1 Eng. 552; though a verict an jugment for the plaintiff will not.be reverse for want of a plea, which was the fault of the efenant. Shropshire vs. McLain, ib. 440. The question is, whether a jugment is final, so that a writ of error will lie to it, which isposes of only a part of the issues in the cause. In Wooruff et al. vs. The State, 3 Ark. 286, the efenants below ha pleae several pleas; to one of which a emurrer was interpose on behalf of the State, issues of fact being mae up on the others. The emurrer was sustaine in the court below, an by agreement, the other issues awaite the ecision of the Supreme Court on the emurrer; but the nature of that agreement, an the jugment consequent upon it, not necessarily notice in that ecision, will appear in the subsequent report of the same case, 3 Eng. 333, where the question arose whether the agreement ha not been violate after the remaning of, the cause upon reversal. The agreement was to the effect, that the court below, in case it sustaine the emurrer to one of the pleas, shoul procee by consent of parties to rener final jugment in favor of the State, not only upon the emurrer, but upon the other pleas, to which issues of fact ha been joine. Such jugment was accoringly renere, an unless that habeenone, we apprehen this court woul not have ajuicate the cause without an oversignt. The result was that the efenants below stake every thing on obtaining a reversal of the jugment, which they ha agree shoul be final, if against them upon the emurrer; because if the jugment ha been affirme, the cause coul not have been remane for the trial of the other issues of fact. In the report of the case last cite, the court say, “It is not in the power of a party to single out any one issue, even by the most solemn contract of recor, an submit it to the consieration of the Supreme Court, so as to elicit the opinion of the Supreme Court, upon the law or the fact of that particular issue. Such a jugment woul not be final; as not embracing all the issues in the case; an, consequently, it coul not become the subject of an appeal or writ of error. The real object of the parties was to take the opinion of the Supreme Court upon the question of law arising upon the emurrer to the secon plea; but in orer to receive the benefit of that ecision it became absolutely-necessary that the Circuit Court shoul pass upon all the issues joine.”
The language of the opinion quote is applicable to the present case an ecisive of it, though the position of the parties is inverte. In the case of The State vs. Wooruff et al., the efenants, if they wishe to take the opinion of the Supreme Court upon any one of their efences, were boun either to have withrawn the pleas upon which issues of fact ha been joine, or consente that final jugment might go upon them in favor of the plaintiff, so as to mature the whole case for the ecision of the appellate court, because the recor coul not remain in both courts at the same time for ajuication: otherwise causes woul be etermine by picemeal, an there woul be an en of the • salutary rule of law, the esign of which is to make an en of the litigation, that the jugment conclues the parties as to every matter examinable at law, in support or avoiance of the right asserte, whether urge there or not. In this case, where the jugment of the court below, in favor of the efenants, upon one goo plea, going to the whole cause of action, was sufficient to bar it, an the plaintiff coul not force the efenants, having the right to plea several matters, to withraw their other efences, the only course left for the plaintff was to procee with the trial, an obtain or submit to a verict of a jury upon the issues of fact, which they ha been sworn to try.
The most favorable construction for the plaintiffs, that can be put upon the recor entry, is that, uring the progress of the trial, they electe to take a non-suit, though such may not have been their intention. Since with us courts have no power to orer a peremptory non-suit, it is no answer to say that the plaintiffs were compelle to go out of court by an erroneous ecision upon one of the issues, which, if it ha been correct, woul have barre a recovery an put an en to the case. If the plaintiff goes out of court by his own voluntary act, though uner a misapprehension, no writ of error lies to reverse the jugment consequent upon it. He might move to set asie a non-suit occasione by surprise or alarm at some interlocutory ecision of the court, or if he persiste in going on to verict an jugment, might ask for a new trial upon the groun that the court ha erre: but even in such case he woul have to satisfy the court that but for its erroneous ecision, he was prepare with evience to entitle him to a recovery upon all the issues.
The ecision of the court therefore, is that the writ of error be ismisse. Upon this, see Peet vs. McGrace, 21 Wen. 667. Watson vs. Anerson, Harin Rep. 458. Van Worneer vs. Mayor of Albany, 18 Wen. 173. Vestal vs. Buritt, 6 Black. 556. It is proper to say, that in the ecision at a former ay of the present term, upon emurrer to a plea in bar of this writ of error, because the plaintiffs ha praye an prosecute an appeal without superseeas from the same jugment; that was the only question presente, an the recor itself was not before the court.
Writ of error ismisse.

Mr. Justice Scott,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The eclaration was in ebt upon a writing obligatory, averring that it was mae by the efenant, Allis, payable to the plaintiff, Bener, “by the style of D. Bener, & Co.” At the return term, after oyer grante, Allis pleae that he i not make the writing obligatory, payable to the plaintiff, Bener, by the style of D. Bener & Co., as allege in the eclaration, but that he mae it payable to sai Bener an one James A. Henry, as partners, by the name, style, escription an firm of D. Bener & Co., an of which he put himself upon the country. A emurrer was interpose, an the causes assigne were : 1st, that the plea was not sworn to; 2, that it conclue to the country, an not with a verification; an 3, that it was frivolous. The emurrer was sustaine an final jugment was renere for the plaintiff below, an the cause brought here by writ of error.
Accoring to the course of ecisions in this court, the emurrer i not reach the first objection. To o this a motion to strike out was necessary. (Wilson & Turner vs. Shannon & wife, 1 Eng. R. 196. Harwick et al. vs. Campbell, &c., 2 Eng. R. 118. Mayor & Alermen of Little Rock vs. State Bank, 3 Eng. R. 227. State Bank vs. War, 3 Eng. R. 506. Knott vs. Clements a. 13 Ark. R. 335.)
The averment in the eclaration that the writing obligatory in question, was mae payable to the plaintiff, Bener, by the style of D. Bener ¿¡ Co., was a material an traversable one, accoring to the ecisions in the cases of Bower et al. vs. State Bank, 5 Ark. 236, an Nicholay et al. vs. Kay, 1 Eng. R. 70. An although, in general, it is the property of the plea of the “general issue,” in any form of action, to eny all the facts set forth in the eclaration, an to put the plaintiff on proof of every essential fact allege by him, it was expressly rule, in the last mentione case, that the plea of non est factum woul not traverse an allegation like this in question, an that that plea putting in issue only the sealing an elivery of the writing obligatory, amitte as true all the other material allegations in the eclaration. From this then it follows that the allegations in question coul only have been specially ha verse. This was the object contemplate by the plea in question; the legal sufficiency only of which, an not its form, or want of verification by affiavit, is brought in question by the emurrer.
As a special traverse, esigne for the enial of only one of the several facts allege in the eclaration, although it containe other matter, an was otherwise objectionable upon special emurrer, before that was abolishe, it properly conclue to the country. An it woul have been equally goo in substance, ha it conclue with a verification, (1 Sauners 103, a. b. n. (3,) tenering as it woul have one, a material issue an amitting; as the plea i, the truth of all the other allegations containe in the eclaration.
The plea was therefore not frivolous, but goo in substance, an the emurrer shoul have been overrule.
The jugment must be reverse an the cause remane to be proceee with.

case_name: Moore & Cail, adm'r. of Irvin vs. Anders
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court!
The facts of this case, necessary to a correct unerstaning of it, may be thus state.
On the 29th of May, 1838, Reason an John T. Bowie execute a bon with covenant, to make title to one Blackmore, for certain tracts of lan in Phillips county. The bon was in the penal sum of $2,000, an after reciting, that the Bowies ha that ay sol the lans therein escribe to sai Blackmore, his heirs an assigns, for the consieration of $1,000; that is to say $400 cash in han, an the resiue in two installments of $300 each, one ue on the 1st of January, 1839, an the other on the 1st of January, 1840, it was conitione to be voi if they shoul well an truly make or cause to be mae to Blackmore his heirs or assigns, a goo an sufficient warranty ee, in fee simple, for the lans therein before escribe, so soon as the final payment of sai sums of money shoul be mae, or as soon thereafter as might be reasonably convenient. The bon for title was acknowlege an recore, on the ay of its ate, in the office of the recorer of ees an mortgages for Phillips county. Black-more pai the first note for $300, ue on the 1st of January, 1839, an Reason Bowie, to whom the secon note for like amount was mae payable on the 1st of January, 1840, assigne it to Irvin, to whom Blackmore afterwars mae payment of $150, upon it. The resiue of this note with interest remaining unpai. Ir.vin sue Blackmore, an on the 19th of November, 1841, obtaine jugment against him on the corfimon law sie of the Phillips Circuit Court for the amount ue. Execution was issue upon this jugment on the 27th of March, 1845, uner which the lans in question were avertise an sol on the 21st of April following, an Irvin became the purchaser of them, for the sum of $50. Aners an Horner being creitors of Blackmore, obtaine a jugment against him in the same court, on the 20th of November, 1841, for $1271, upon which an execution was issue, an uner it the same lans were avertise an sol as the property of Blackmore on the 1st of April, 1844, an Aners became the purchaser for the sum of $700, an by virtue of such purchase obtaine possession of the lans.
On the 27th of February, 1846, Irvin exhibite his bill against the two Bowies, Blackmore an Aners, alleging the foregoing facts, an farther representing that Aners ha become,insolvent an non-resient: that the jugment against him in favor of the complainant remaine wholly unsatisfie, unless it be entitle to a creit of $50, the amount of his bi at execution sale for the lans in question; an that the Bowies refuse to make a ee for the lans until Blackmore ha complie by the payment of the purchase money therefor, accoring to the conition of their bon an covenant to him for title.
The bill praye that the complainant’s purchase of the lans uner execution be set asie an hel for nought; that Aners be require to pay to the complainant the full amount of his jugment at law against Blackmore, or in efault thereof, that the lans be mae subject an ecree to be sol by a commissioner of the court for the satisfaction of the same: that the entire interest an claim of all the parties to the suit shoul vest in the purchaser of the lans at such sale, an that the same operate as an acquittance an release to the Bowies, from all obligation uner their bon for title to convey the same. The bill, on the emurrer of Aners, was ajuge insufficient an ismisse for want of equity.
The main question argue in this case, is settle by the ecision of this court in Smith vs. Robinson et al. 13 Ark. 533. When the Bowies sol the lans to Blackmore, an gave him their bon for title on payment of the purchase money, the transaction was, in all essential features, a security for the payment of the purchase money; the same, in effect, as if they ha mae him a ee an taken a mortgage back to attain the same en, which the parties ha in view. In the case referre to, the origin an history of this species of conveyance, peculiar to the new States, is explaine. Uner the lan system aopte by the Unite States, inchoate equitable titles were erive in various ways, from the government through its lan officers. Until the emanation of patents, often suspene or elaye for years, it woul be impossible for the owner of lan so situate, to make title upon a sale of it. Bons or covenants for title were therefore resorte to as a matter of necessity. The policy of the country having always been to facilitate the transfer of real estate, it often happene that the same tract of lan woul be successively sol in the same manner, where none of the venors or purchasers ha the legal title. So the custom grew up of selling lans by means of a bon or covenant of the venor,, conitione to make conveyance of the legal title when procure from the Unite States, an where the sale was upon creit, the further conition was inserte to make title upon the payment of the purchase money. This informal conveyance was something more than an executory agreement to sell; it importe a present sale, which passe the ownership an beneficial interest in the lan, to the purchaser, usually accompanie with possession, or the right of possession as against the venor, being an equivalent for the interest of the purchase money. Such an estate or interest in lan was recognize at an early ay by territorial legislation as a “seizin in equity.” Steele & McCamp. Dig. Title, Aministration, sec. 27; ib. Title, Conveyances, sec. 2; ib. sec. 7. Rev. Stat. Title, Aministration, sec. 161. Ib. Title, Execution, sec. 23. Provision was mae for the recoring of such instruments, whereby they became constructive notice of title; Rev. Stat. Title, Conveyances, sec. 22. The lien reserve by means of them to the venor, has none of the oious characteristics of the venor’s equitable lien for the unpai purchase money, where having conveye the legal title, acknowleging the receipt of the purchase money, he ought not to be hear to assert it against any subsequent purchaser or incumbrancer, without clear an unequivocal proof of actual notice.. On the contrary the venor, in this moe of conveyance, oes not expressly refuse to part with the legal title; an whether by the terms of the contract the payment of the purchase money be a conition preceent, or epenant upon the final execution of the ee, the result is the same. It makes no ifference whether the bon for title be recore or not. If recore, it becomes notice: if not on recor, that circumstance woul, of itself be sufficient to put any subsequent purchaser or incumbrancer upon enquiry; because an examination of the recor woul show title out of the venor. An unlike the equitable lien of the venor, who has parte with the legal title, if notes be taken for the purchase money with any aitional or personal security, the fact of the venor, who gives only a bon or covenant for title, taking such aitional security, is no waiver of the lien, where it is expressly reserve by the terms of the contract, so that the payment of the purchase money, from whatever source it may be erive, is to be a conition preceent, or a simultaneous act with the execution of the ee. Although in Brown vs. Morrison, 5 Ark. 217, this istinction is not clearly state, it necessarily follows, from the ecision there, upholing the lien of Brown, the venor, notwithstaning he ha taken the notes of Cole, with personal security. As the court there sai, “ His covenant only bins him to convey upon the reception of the purchase money.”
But the appellee insists, that whatever lien the original venor may have ha, it is not assignable, an i not pass to Irvin by the assignment of the note to him, but that when Bowie transferre the note for value receive, he got his money, being ail that he was entitle to ask, an that the conition being accomplishe, no further act remaine for him to o, but to execute the conveyance. Again, it woul be sufficient for the ecision of this point to refer to the opinion in Smith vs. Robinson; because whenever we assimilate the sale of lan, by means of a bon or covenant conitione to make title on payment of the purchase money, to a conveyance an mortgage back to secure the same en, the usual incients of a mortgage attach to the transaction, an the rights of the parties, growing out of it, are to be governe by analogous rules. The weight of authority no oubt is, that the equitable lien of the venor is personal to him, an is not, unless uner some peculiar equitable circumstances, assignable. We ecline going into any such question, because it is not presente here, an is only notice by way of contrast with the escription of lien now uner consieration: clearly the lien, uner a bon for title on payment of the purchase money, being expressly reserve by contract, tantamount to a mortgage security for the benefit of the venor, an the note for the purchase money transferrable like any other chose in action mae assignable by law, the assignment of the note tacitly carries with it the venor’s lien by way of mortgage security, an as an incient to the ebt. The value of the note, as a negotiable instrument in the hans of the venor, woul be impaire, if the security coul not accompany a transfer of it to an assignee. The right of the purchaser to a conveyance epens upon the payment of the note by him, or by some one who has become subrogate to his rights, as was the case in Smith vs. Robinson, an not upon the fact that the venor has receive the money upon the note, if it be still outstaning against the purchaser; an this woul be so, though he ha enorse it without recourse, or though he shoul become ischarge by the laches of the holer as at'the law merchant, or by his failure to pursue the maker with ue iligence to insolvency uner the statute of assignments, or supposing the assignor’s liability upon the "contract of assignment to become barre by limitation. That the venor’s lien, when thus reserve by the terms of the contract, is assignable in those States, where this moe of conveyance by bon for title prevails, see Tanner vs. Hicks, 4 Smees & Marsh. 294. Roper vs. McCook, 7 Ala. 319. Norvell vs. Johnson, 5 Humph. 489. Though it is remarkable, as an examination of the cases in the western States woul show, that the two escriptions of lien, though so entirely issimilar, are often confoune.
At the time the lans were sol upon execution of the jugment at law obtaine by Irvin against Blackmore, the lien of the jugment uner the statute ha expire; but the sale uner the junior jugment of Aners & Horner, uner which Aners purchase, was within three years from its renition: an although the sale of lan uner a junior jugment only passes the title of the efenant, subject to the lien of any prior jugment in force, yet the lien of Irvin’s jugment ha cease to be in force when he purchase uner it, an the jugment creitors being entitle to no equitable preferences as against each other, but having to stan or fall accoring to their legal priorities, it follows that if the lans ha been the absolute property of Blackmore, as between the two purchasers it is clear that they woul belong to Aners. An it is argue for him, that if Irvin stans in the place of the original venor, then by his purchase of the lans uner his jugment against Blackmore, there was a merger of the equitable title of the jugment ebtor into the legal title hel or represente by Irvin, whereby Irvin, having acquire both the legal an equitable estate, has no cause of complaint, an is not entitle to any relief. We apprehen that uner our statute, Digest, Title, Execution, sec. 25, which subjects to execution “all real estate, whether patente or not, whereof the efenant or any person for his use was seize, at law or in equity, on the ay of the renition of the jugment, orer or ecree, whereon execution issue, or at any time thereafter;” that Blackmore ha such an interest in the lans as was subject to execution upon any jugment renere against him. Even if he were not in possession, or ha not pai any portion of the purchase money, yet accoring to Smith vs. Robinson, the law regars the purchaser uner an execute contract of sale, evience by a bon for title, as the real owner of the lan, subject to an incumbrance for the purchase money, an occupying the position of a mortgager, who has iveste himself of the nake legal title as a security for a ebt, an whose equitable or beneficial estate woul, without oubt, be boun by the lien of a jugment, an subject to execution to satisfy it. The State vs. Lawson, 1 Eng. 269. In orer to present this case most strongly in favor of Aners, let it be suppose that Bowie,the original venor, ha obtaine the senior jugment at law for the purchase money against Blackmore, an ha cause his interest in it to be sol uner execution before the lien of the jugment ha expire. In such case, it woul follow from the argument urge on behalf of Aners, that the interest of Blackmore was forever iveste, an that neither he nor any venee of his, or purchaser uner execution against him, who ha thereby become subrogate to his rights, coul have been entitle to reeem. The enquiry, what effect the sale of the mortgage premises upon execution of a jugment at law for the mortgage ebt woul have, accoring to the laws of this State, upon the mortgager’s equity of reemption, allue to in the case of Price vs. The State Bank, at July term, 1853, might be the subject of an extene examination. We have no statute regulating the moe, sometimes resorte to elsewhere, of barring the equity of reemption by sale uner a power; nor is the consieration of this case affecte by any question, how far the equity of reemption of the venee, uner a bon for title, may be barre by a stipulation in the instrument, making the time of payment the essence of the contract, or whereby a forfeiture is agree upon, in the event the purchase money be not punctually pai. Avoiing any such consierations, which coul only be averte to by way of illustration, it must suffice to express our opinion of the law, as applicable to the particular case before us, an upon the facts state.
The substance of the statute concerning “mortgages,” is set out in Price vs. The State Bank. Upon any fair an equitable interpretation of that statute, our opinion is against the power of the mortgagee to foreclose the equity oí reemption, by a sale of the mortgage premises, uner execution of a jugment at law, for the ebt secure by the mortgage. It might be questionable whether such a sale, where the purchase is mae by a thir person, woul not operate to transfer to him the entire claim of the mortgagee upon the lan, that is, the right to have a foreclosure, or what is equivalent, to receive the benefit resulting from the reemption. An it might be true that a thir person, purchasing at such sale, woul become subrogate, by operation of law to the mortgager’s right to reeem. So that the purchaser, in such case, might possibly acquire the title, as against both the plaintiff an efenant in the execution. But a purchase of the mortgage premises by the plaintiff in execution, that is to say, the holer of the mortgage ebt coul not bar the equity of reemption subsisting in the mortgager: an in no event, whether the purchase be mae by the plaintiff in execution, or by a stranger, woul it have the effect to bar the equity of reemption, acquire from the mortgager by an intermeiate purchaser or incumbrancer, whose right to reeem woul not be cut off by execution of the jugment at law, to which they were not parties. As there ought to be a mutuality of rights, it follows, that the mortgagee is not preclue, by his purchase of the mortgager’s estate uner execution at law, from going into equity uner the statute, to have a foreclosure, thereby opening the foreclosure, an letting in all the equities of the mortgager, even if any oubt before existe concerning them. We have seen that Irvin’s purchase uner his jugment, after the lien of it ha expire, was a nugatory act, an of itself gave him no rights at law as against Aners, who claime uner Blackmore. But his right, erive by assignment from the venor, to subject to the payment of the original purchase money, the lan in question, whether hel by Blackmore or any one claiming uner him, an who of necessity acquire it with notice oí the conition upon which the title was to emanate from the venor, continue unimpaire, unless we hel that the mortgagee, suing at law, is preclue thereby from having a foreclosure.
Finally, it is argue for Aners, that by the law in force, five years being the limitation upon a writing obligatory, an Irvin’s bill of complaint not having been exhibite until six years after the writing obligatory assigne to him, fell ue, his right to subject the lan in question to the payment of it, is barre in equity by analogy to the statute at law; an that the jugment at law, obtaine by Irvin against Blackmore, an in a istinct proceeing, is no juicial ascertainment of the ebt as against Aners.
Until the ecisions of this court, beginning with Dickerson vs. Morrison, 1 Eng. 266, followe in Davis vs. Sullivan, 2 ib. 449, an Bir vs. Smith, 3 ib. 368, it 'was oubtful whether, until the passage of the act of December, 1844, there was any statute affecting the limitation to actions on writings obligatory, other than the presumption of payment arising after the lapse of ten years, accoring to sec. 31, of the Revise Statutes of 1839; but those ecisions i authoritatively settle the law, as now claime for the appellee. But for the reason that he is not affecte by the inepenent jugment against Blackmore, he can claim no immunity from it. No oubt exists, uner the statute of limitations applicable to these transactions, that the right of the mortgagee to assert an enforce his lien upon the lan by a bill to foreclose, woul not be barre until ten years from the time the right to foreclose accrue: because he woul have that time within which to bring ejectment at law, an for aught that appears, the ¡possession of the venee, being consistent with his contract of purchase, by no possibility coul a title by length of averse possession have become mature as against the venor, within a shorter perio. That the venor, who gives a bon for title, may bring ejectment on failure of the venee to comply with the conition of the bon by the payment of the purchase money, is fully establishe by Brown vs. Morrison & Sullivan, an Fears vs. Merrill, 4 Eng. 459: nor is any notice to quit necessary, accoring to Smith vs. Robinson. By analogy therefore to the limitation at law, we hol that the bill in this case, to subject the lans in'question to the payment of the original purchase money, was well brought within ten years from the maturity of the writing obligatory, execute by Blackmore, for its payment; an so the converse of this woul be law; that Aners, if uner ifferent circumstances it ha become important to his rights, woul have ha a like perio, within which to reeem.
Upon the facts allege in the bill, the complainant, Irvin, was entitle to the relief praye for. The ecree of the chancellor is therefore reverse, an the cause will be remane with instructions to overrule the emurrer, an for further proceeings.

Mr. Justice Scott
elivere the opinion of the Court.
On the first ay of the April term 1845 of the Pulaski-Circuit-Court, the appellant became the purchaser of the lan in controversy. It was sol as the property of Moses Ferguson, by virtue-of an execution, against him an one Michael Hogan, in favor of one Nathaniel Migett, upon a jugment obtaine in May, 1843. During that term the appellant obtaine a writ of possession upon his motion, to which Moses Ferguson appeare; From the jugment of the Pulaski Circuit Court granting the writ of possession, an appeal was taken to this court, where .in the month of October, 1845, the jugment of the Pulaski court was-affirme. (1 Eng. R. 297.)
In the meantime, in the month of August, 1845, Mary Ferguson, as wiow, an Moses Ferguson an others, as heirs of Joseph Ferguson, ecease, file a bill in chancery against the appellant an the heirs of Sampson Gray, ecease, alleging that on the 5th of November, 1827, the sheriff of Pulaski county, in the then Territory of Arkansas, sol the lan in controversy, in ue course of law, for taxes, to the sai Sampson Gray, an execute to him the prescribe certificate of purchase; that Gray sol, the lan to the sai Joseph Ferguson for the sum of $-- “in-han, pai by the sai Joseph to the sai Sampson,” with the express unerstaning an agreement that he, Gray, woul convey the lan by ee as soon as he shoul himself receive one from the sheriff in pursuance of law an in accorance with his certificate; but that Gray eparte this life before receiving such ee-from-the sheriff, an before making one to the sai Joseph Ferguson: that by virtue of the aforesai sale an agreement, Joseph Ferguson took possession of the lan, an use an occupie it by putting his son, Moses Ferguson, in the possession an quiet enjoyment of the same: that Moses ha continue to hol-that possession, without averse claim from any one, up to the - 2 of April, 1836, when the sai Joseph eparte this life, an' that since the eath of Joseph, Moses ha continue in- the possession by the consent an permission of the heirs an aminisirator of the sai Joseph: that in April, 1845, the lan ha been, sol by execution as the property of Moses, an that the appellant Blakeney became the purchaser, who ha receive a ee .for it from the sheriff of Pulaski county, conveying all the title .an interest of the sai Moses.
The bill, upon these allege facts, procees to pray the court to ecree to the heirs at law of Joseph Ferguson, a vali an sufficient •title in law an equity to the tract of lan in question, upon conition that they allot to the wiow, one thir part as a ower estate, an convey to the appellant, Blakeney, an univie sixth part of the resiue, or pay him an equivalent in money, the sai ■sixth part being the allege interest of Moses in the lan.
To this bill, Blakeney interpose a emurrer assigning for cause; 1st, That there was no equity upon the face of the bill. 2? That complainants showe no title to the lan, but a parol agreement between Gray an Joseph Ferguson, which is forbien by the statute of fraus. 3, No facts to take the case out of the statute. 4th, No money pai in part performance. 5th, That the agreement was without consieration an voi.
The Circuit Court overrule the emurrer, an renere a final •ecree in favor of complainants as to Blakeney, an an interlocutory one as to .the heirs of Gray, who were uly summone, but mae efault. Blakeney appeale to this court, an upon a hearing here, ¡at the January term, 1848, it washel that the facts •allege were .sufficient to take the case out of the statute of fraus, but that the allegations were not sufficient to show title in Gray. An the ecree appeale from was reverse, an the cause remane to be proceee with accoring to the principles of equity, an not inconsistent with the opinion herein elivere. (3 Eng. R. 272.)
While this cause was pening in the Circuit Court, an immeiately after the ecision of this court, in October, 1845, affirming the jugment of the Pulaski Circuit Court, in the matter of the writ of possession, the same complainants, Mary Ferguson an others, file their petition in the Pulaski Circuit Court, alleging that they ha, on the 28th of August, 1845, file the before mentione bill of complaint, .an praying that a copy thereof, which they exhibite, might be taken as a part of their petition: that the efenants ha been serve with process of subpoena; that the lan in question ha been sol as aforesai, an purchase by Blakeney; that the latter ha obtaine an orer of possession; that the orer ha been appeale from to this court, where the jugment of the Circuit Court in the premises ha been affirme. An upon these allege facts, verifie by affiavit, praye that the appellant, Blakeney, shoul be enjoine from all further proceeings with his writ of possession (the awar of which ha been so affirme by this court,) until their bill aforesai shoul be finally hear an etermine. This prayer was resiste by Blakeney, but his resistance was of no avail, an the injunction was aware. Afterwars he interpose a emurrer to the petition an assigne for cause: 1st, That there was no equity upon the face of the petition. 2, That it was an attempt to re-investigate a matter alreay etermine by this court, without any showing of further facts or new matter. 3, That the petition allege no title to the lan, but set up a parol agreement with regar thereto. 4th, That no sufficient facts were allege to take the case out of the statute of fraus. 5th, That no gum of money was allege to have been pai in part performance. 6th, That upon the face of the petition, the allege agreement appears to have been mae without consieration, an is therefore voi, irrespective of the statute. 7th, That inasmuch as there is failure of any allegation of title, there is no groun ppon which to base partition. 8th, That if on the other han, title be allege, then there is an aequate remey at law.
Upon argument, the emurrer was overrule, an the appellant, Blakeney, eclining to plea to, or answer the petition, the injunction was perpetuate, an Blakeney appeale to this court, where upon a hearing at the January term, 1849, the ecree of the Pulaski Circuit Court, perpetuating the injunction, was reverse, an the cause remane to be proceee with, accoring to the principles of equity, an not inconsistent with the opinion therein elivere, (4 Eng. R. 487.)
•In the meantime, the same complainants, at the October term, 1848, of the Pulaski Circuit Court, ha file an amene bill as a substitute for their original bill, hel ba on emurrer by this court, at the January term, 1848, alleging with exceeing minuteness the peformanee of every pre-requisite for a vali sale for taxes uner the territorial statute, from its inception up to an incluing the issuance of the certificate of purchase to Sampson Gray in the year 1827: that in 1828, before obtaining the sheriff’s ee in pursuance of the certificate, Gray sol the lan to Joseph Ferguson for the sum of fifty ollars, an receive the money therefor; an agree that he woul procure such ee an convey all his right, title an interest in the lan to the sai Joseph, an at the same time place the latter in possession thereof, in pursuance of this contract: that no person offere to reeem the lan within the time prescribe by the statute: that Gray having eparte this life before receiving such ee, mae none to Joseph: that the representatives of Gray, after his eath elivere to Joseph the certificate of purchase, uner which an in pursuance of the contract of sale to him aforesai, he continue to hol possession: that in 1831, Joseph place his son Moses in possession of the lan as his tenant, who occupie as such until the eath of Joseph, in 1836: that ever since then Moses has hel the possession, by the consent an permission of the legal representatives an heirs at law of Joseph, subject to the rights of the latter, an of the wiow; with the unerstaning an agreement that he woul yiel possession whenever require for the purpose of assigning ower an making partition. The bill then sets out the levy an sale, as the property of Moses, an the purchase by, an conveyance to the appellant, Blakeney, by the sheriff, Boren, of all the right, title an interest of Moses. An totheallege en, that the title to the lan in controversy may be quiete an veste in the proper owner thereof, an partition be mae, conclues with a prayer that the court will ecree a vali an sufficient title in law an equity to the heirs at law, upon conition that they assign ower to the wiow, an convey to Blakeney one-sixth part of the resiue, or pay him an equivalent in money, if actual partition be impracticable.
