Of the latter class, is the English case of Greene vs. Pleger, (3 Hare’s Rep. 165,) where the case mae by the bill, was that Bernar Angle, a bankrupt, for the purpose of swinling his creitors, secretly put money in the hans of his brother, John Angle, on the security of two promissory notes 8 execute by Pleger, who knew that the money was the assets of the bankrupt: that when John Angle was summone to atten, as a witness, on the fiat against his brother, Bernar, he refuse to atten an abscone to Boulogne. The two promissory notes payable to John Angle, were taken from his possession by the messenger uner the fiat, an elivere to the complainant, who was the official an creitors’ assignee of the bankrupt: an the notes not being enorse, the complainant coul not recover upon them at law against Pleger. Pleger answere amitting his liability to John Angle, but ignore altogether the case of the complainant, not amitting that the money, as allege, was a part of the assets of the bankrupt, an submitte that if the court shoul be of opinion that the complainants were entitle to the notes, or the beneficial interest in them, that then he ought to be consiere a stakeholer an be allowe his costs. Uner an English statute, John Angle was serve at Boulogne with a subpoena to appear an answer the bill. Afterwars the vice chancellor mae an orer that the service of a notice of motion upon John Angle at Boulogne, shoul be goo service. The notice was accoringly serve, an the motion then mae, (foune upon affiavits as against John Angle) that Pleger shoul pay the money into court. John Angie i not appear, an the motion came on to be hear on the affiavits as against him, an upon the answer of Pleger to the bill alreay in. The Vice Chancellor in granting this motion, sai: “The efenant Pleger amits his liability to John Angle, an ignores only the question of right as between the plaintiff an John Angle. If John Angle were not a party to this suit, the plaintiffs woul have to join issue with Pleger upon their right as against John Angle, an woul be boun to prove that right as against Pleger. But the latter being a party, it is with him, an him only, that the plaintiffs have to litigate that right: an a ecree in the plaintiffs’ favor against John Angle will be a sufficient protection to Pleger. That it is with John Angle, the plaintiffs have to litigate that question is clear from the consieration, that an amission by John Angle in his answer, of the plaintiff’s right as against himself, woul entitle the plaintiff to a ecree accoring to the prayer of the bill. At the same time it is clear that John Angles’ answer woul not, technically speaking, be evience against Pleger. So, if the bill were taken pro confesso against John Angle, or if the plaintiffs’ rights, as against John Angle, were prove by evience not receivable against Pleger. The consequence of both John Angle an Pleger being parties to the suit is, that a ecree in the plaintiffs’ favor will ecie the case between the co-efenants. (Chamley vs. Lor Dunsancy, 2 Sch. & Lef. 718. Farquharson vs. Seton, 5 Russ, per Lor Elon,) I might refer to analogous cases, in which a isclaimer by one efenant has enable the plaintiff to sustain his suit against another efenant; the principle being, that after a ecree foune upon the isclaimer, the court will not permit the isclaiming party to open the question anew, (Leathes vs. Newitt, 3 Ea. & Go. 848. Mounsey vs. Burnham, 1 Hare 21.”) After showing him that the case before him was unlike the case of Doubless vs. Flint, (1 Myln. & Cr. 502,) the Vice Chancellor then conclues with the remark: “I want no evience but what his answer gives me, an I take nothing from him but what he amits he has no right to hol as against John Angle. Against John Angle the case is establishe, for the present purpose at least, by the affiavits, to the l'eception of which he coul not object.”
The affiavits, by which this motion was supporte, being taken, upon the hearing of the motion, as equivalent to the answer of John Angle, confessing the complainants’ equity upon the final hearing, it will be seen that this latter case iffers from the Massachusetts case, just cite, mainly in the fact, that the answer of the real litigant efenant, was offere to be rea by the complainant in the bill, instea of by the co-efenant, as in the Massachusetts case; an that, in the one case, the answer rea enie the equity of the bill, while in the English case it is taken as confessing it. But the same principle governs both cases. That it is to say, in neither was the answer rea in evience against the co-efenant. In the Massachusetts case it was not against him, because he set up no right of his own, an the answer was against the complainant an in favor of the responing efenant, in whose right he mae his efence. So, in the English case, it was not against the co-efenant, Pleger, as the Yice Chancellor labors to show by several illustrations, among others the case of a isclaiming efenant, while he is-. tinctly recognizes the rule, that the answer of one efenant cannot be rea in evience against another; an conclues by repeating the iea, which he ha been enforcing throughout: “I want no evience against Pleger, but what his answer gives me, an I take nothing from him but what he amits he has no right to hol as against John Angle.”
In both cases, however, the ecree for an against the complainants, respectively, operate for the protection of the efenants, respectively, whose interest was balance between the real litigating parties as woul be the complainant’s attitue in a bill of interpleaer.
We have have use this case of Green vs. Pleger by way of illustration, an have set it out. at large, not only because it is apposite, but also because Mr. Dahiel, in his work on Chancery Pleaing an Practice, (Vol. 2,p. 982,) has, upon the single founation of this case, built what he seems to consier an exception to the general rule, an has expresse his iea of it in terms so vague an general as to be calculate to mislea, as well by those means as by giving to the case more prominence an importance than it eserves. The passage in his work to which we allue is this: “In cases, however, where the rights of the plaintiff, as against one efenant, are only prevente from being-complete by some question between the plaintiff an a secon efenant, it seems that the plaintiff is permitte to rea the answer of such secon efenant for the purpose of completing his claim against the first;” an it was cite by this court as one of the authorities for amitting an exception to the general rule in the case of Whiting & Slark vs. Beebe et al. (7 Eng. R. 561:) the other authorities cite being Fiel vs. Hollan, Osborne vs. The Bank of the U. States, an Morse vs. Royal, 12 Ves. R. 355; which latter was a case where Green, a part of whose answer was receive as evience, was a efenant in the ouble capacity of executor of one ecease party, an as resiuary legatee of another, between the estates of which ecease parties there was a complication of interest; an Lor Erskine allowe so much of his answer to be rea, relating to his capacity of executor as was not in favor of his interest as a resiuary legatee. An the same authorities ha been before cite in the case of Barraque & wife vs. Siter, Price & Co., 4 Eng. R. 545, where it was sai that the rule of exclusion i not apply to cases where the efenant claims through him, whose answer is offere in evience. But holing, as we must now o, after a more careful an thorough examination of the question, in which we have closely scrutinize these authorities, that the answer of one efenant cannot be rea in evience against his co-efenant, unless he refers to such answer as correct, or is so connecte with the answering party as to be boun, uner the orinary rules of law, by his confessions, eclarations or amissions, it is proper for us to remark that the octrine of those cases upon this point must be so moifie as to conform to the views now expresse.
In reference to that exception to the general rule of evience, that the amissions of one person cannot be given in evience against another, which is foune upon an arises out of the connection of interest between the person making the amission an him against whom it is offere — -as that of joint ownership or liability, or that of the erivation of title of one several owner from another — there is this essential ifference between a joint interest an a erivative interest, that is always of controling import upon a question of amissibility, that is to say, the joint interest to be affecte by the amission must be a subsisting, one, at the time the amission was mae; whereas in the other case, the erivative interest to be affecte by the amission was mae. must have been acquire after the amission was mae. Whether the party making the amission an the party against whom it is offere, be connecte by a joint ownership or liability, or by the transmission of a several title, from the former to the latter, the interest of the party making the amission must be a subsisting one at the time of the amission. If at the time of making it he has parte with his interest, his amissions are not legal evience against him to whom it has passe. Upon this point the authorities are clear an numerous, an without exception or qualification in the application of the rule to venors an assignors. Inee the Supreme Court of New York, in the cases of Beach vs. Wise, 1 Hill’s R. 612, an Starke vs. Boswell, 6 Hill R. 495, have gone beyon this, an hel that the amission of a former owner of personal property, or of a chose in action, even if mae before he parte with his title, are not evience against his venee. This woul, seem, however, to be an invasion upon establishe principles of evience.
Applying these principles to the answer of Moses Ferguson, it is entirely clear that it was not amissible as evience against his co-efenant Blakeney.
The result is, thatthe complainants have no evience in the recor to prove their material allegation, that they are the wiow an heirs at law of Joseph Ferguson, .ecease, unerwhom they claim to erive title to the lan in controversy. Upon this groun then as well as that alreay consiere as to costs, this ecree must be reverse, an as the recor oes not furnish the materials upon which we can foun another ecree, which woul reach all the merits of this case, we shall orer the bill to be ismisse without prejuice to the rights of the complainants, an at their costs; that the appellant, Blakeney, may at once have the benefit of his writ of possession that has alreay been affirme to Mm by this court.

Mr. Justice Walker,
elivere the opinion of the Court.
Louisa H. Allen, by her next frien, file her bill for a ivorce an for alimony against her husban, Abraham Allen; to which he file his answer enying the allegations therein, an set forth by way of cross bill, a complaint, in which he allege a breach of the marriage contract, on the part of the complainant, which she was calle upon to answer, an for a ecree in his favor.
For all substantial purposes the answer is a cross bill, an uner our practice in chancery, must be so consiere. It appears that at the instance of the complainant, the court ha orere the efenant to pay the next frien, for the temporary support of the complainant, a sum of money at state perios, which orer the efenant, for several grouns set forth in his motion, move the court to set asie; one of the reasons for setting asie the orer was, that the next frien was insolvent. The court refuse to vacate the orer, but orere that the next frien give security for costs on or before the secon ay of the next term of the court, or that the suit shoul be ismisse. At the next term of the court, the next frien file his written statement, in which he ecline to comply with the orer of court, an expresse a willingness that the suit shoul be ismisse. To this the efenant objecte an offere to waive the necessity for giving security in obeience to the orer of court. But the court isregare his objection an ismisse both the original an the cross bill, to which the efenant excepte an appeale to this court.
There can be no oubt uner the state of case, but that the court erre in ismissing the suit. The efenant i not move the court to ismiss the suit; nor i he consent that it shoul be one; an uner the circumstances ofthe case, even if the complainant ha formally move the court to o so, the statute expressly eclares that, after a cross bill is file, the complainant shall not, without the consent of the efenant, ismiss the suit. Dig. ch. 28, sec. 41. But in this case the suit was not ismisse at the instance of either party, but by orer of court. We will not say that a state of case might not arise, where, by the acts of the parties in the prosecution of a suit, or in failing or refusing to comply with the orers of the court, that the court might not orer the suit to be ismisse; but uner the state of casé here presente, we are satisfie that the court erre in ismissing the suit against the objection of the efenant.
The orer an ecision of the court ismissing the suit must be reverse an set asie, an the cause remane with instructions to reinstate the case upon the ocket, that the same may be hear upon its merits.

Mr. Justice Walker
elivere the opinion of the Court.
This is an action of ebt brought by Lambeth against Leach an Simmons upon a writing obligatory, execute by them to the plaintiff.
The efenant, Simmons pleae infancy, an the other efenant, nil ebet, payment an set-off' Upon the first two pleas issue was taken: to the thir, the plaintiff emurre, upon the groun that there was not such mutual inebteness between the plaintiff an the efenant, set forth in the plea, as to constitute a vali set-off uner the statute; in this, that the contract sue upon was execute by Simmons an Leach, an that pleae in set-off was in favor of Leach alone. The Circuit Court sustaine the emurrer to the plea; an the correctness of its ecision upon this point, is the sole question presente for our consieration.
The statute, Set-off, sec. 1, Dig. page 937, provies: “ That when two or more persons are mutually inebte to each other, &c., an one of them commences an action against the other, one ebt may be set-off against the other, although they may be of a ifferent nature.” Being remeial this statute shoul be construe liberally, so as to accomplish the object intene by its enactment, which was, by setting off one ebt against another, to prevent cross actions, elay an unnecessary expense. The plaintiff contens that the term “mutually inebte,” means only such ebts, or emans as exist, an are ue from all of the plaintiffs to all of the efenants: an in suppoi’t of this position, refers to one of the earlier ecisions of this court, Trammell vs. Harrell, 4 Ark. Rep. 602. In that case, it is worthy of remark, that the sufficiency of the plea of set-off was not presente upon emurrer, nor was exception taken to the evience upon the trial of the issue forme upon it, nor oes it appear whether the question was irectly presente by assignment of errors, or argue by counsel. The court, however, proceee to consier the question, an hel that a ebt or eman, to be a set-off, must be ue from the sole plaintiff, or plaintiffs, to the sole efenant or efenants. The chief justice, issenting, hel that, although a eman, not ue from all of the plaintiffs to the efenant or efenants, coul not be pleae as a set-off, yet as regare’the inebteness of the plaintiffs to one or more of the efenants, the rule was ifferent; an that a ebt or eman, ue from the plaintiff or plaintiffs to any one, or all of the efenants, was a mutual subsisting inebteness within the spirit an meaning of the statute, an might be pleae as a set-off against the plaintiff’s eman.
This construction of the statute, in our opinion, is best calculate to give effect to it, an accors with the other acts, which make all contracts joint an several, whether so or not in terms, by which the plaintiff may, at his election, sue one or all of the fenants. Á payment by one efenant is, in effect, a payment by all. The efenants may plea separately, an any efence to the merits of the action enures to the benefit of all: an if the plaintiff is inebte to one of several efenants, an such efenant shoul choose to pay an ischarge the ebt of himself an his co-efenant out of it, it is, in effect, the payment an satisfaction of both, an no goo reason seems to exist why he shoul not be permitte to o so. Such efence in no wise affects the rights of the co-efenant, or of the plaintiff: not of the efenant, because so far from increasing his liability, it lessens it by ischarging a ebt, for the whole of which he was boun to the plaintiff; nor oes it prejuice the rights of the plaintiff, because, if in truth he owes the efenants or either of them, he shoul not, in goo conscience, be permitte to coerce payment from them, or one of them (which is in effect from both), without at the same time paying that which he owes them, an to compel this, an prevent litigation an unnecessary costs an elay, the statute of set-off was passe.
The rule lai own in Trammell vs. Harrell, although subsequently ahere to in Gray vs. Bagett, Fiel vs. Watkins an Wooruff vs. The State, seems never to have been fully acquiesce in: an in Sillivant & Thorn vs. Rearon, 5 Ark. 155, it was not only qualifie an explaine, but an express intimation was there given, that a more liberal construction of the statute shoul be aopte.
The question is again presente for our consieration, an uner circumstances which clearly show, that unless a more liberal construction is given to the statute than that in Trammell vs. Harrell, it will, in many instances, fail to accomplish the en for which it was enacte. In this case Simmons, one of the joint an several obligors, was a minor, pleae his minority an was ischarge. So that in fact, Leach, the other efenant, was the only legally boun efenant. It is true that the plaintiff sue him jointly with Simmons, but he was alone absolutely boun for the ebt. Leach pleae a subsisting ebt ue from the plaintiff to him, an there certainly can be no goo reason why he shoul not be permitte to o so. It is clearly a case within the spirit an intent of the statute, which is merely remeial an as a moification of the rule, as lai own in Trammell vs. Harrell, will in no. wise affect the title to property, but will at the same time give effect to the statute in accorance with its obvious intent, we feel less reluctant to o so, an to aopt that hel in the issenting opinion of the chief justice, which we think sustaine, as well by reason an a fair construction of the statute, as the ecisions of other courts. Thus in Kentucky, Dunn vs. West, 5 B. Mon. 367, one of several efenants was allowe to set-off his separate eman against the plaintiff, who sue upon a joint an several contract. An in Powell vs. Hoge, 8 B. Mon. 443, in a suit upon a joint bon against two efenants, the ecision in Dunn vs. West was approve. In commenting upon the statute an the effect of the plea, the court of appeals sai, “The plaintiff cannot be enjoine by the ischarge of his own liability. There is no other person jointly intereste with him in the ebt. An as it is a voluntary assumption of the payment of the whole ebt by one efenant, the other efenants jointly boun with him have no cause of complaint.” This is the view taken of the'question in the issenting opinion in Trammell vs. Harrell, in the correctness of which we fully concur. ,
Jugmentjre verse an the cause remane for further proceeings.

case_name: Central Bank of Georgia vs. Veasey
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court.
The action was ebt, upon jugment renere in another State. The allegation in the eclaration, setting out the jugment, is that the plaintiff, on &c., at a superior court, hel in the county of Talbot, in the State of Georgia, to wit, &c., by the consiera] tion an jugment of sai court, recovere against the efen' ant the sum of one hunre an twenty ollars, for her ebt, as also the further sum of twenty-one ollars an thirty-three cents for her amages, which she ha sustaine by reason of the etention of sai ebt, together with the further sum of ten ollars an fifty cents for her costs in an about sai suit in that behalf expene, whereof the efenant was convict prout patet per recorura, fyc,. The transcript prouce to the court below, upon the issue to the plea of nul tiel recor, shows that, in an action of assumpsit, before the superior court of Talbot county, Georgia, the efenant confesse jugment to the plaintiff for the sum of one hunre an twenty ollars, principal, with interest an costs of suit, an the plaintiff’s attorney signe jugment as follows: “Whereupon, it is consiere by the court that the plaintiff o recover of the efenant the sum of one hunre an twenty ollars, for its principal ebt, an the further sum of twenty-one ollars an thirty-three cents, for its interest, an the further sum of ten ollars an fifty cents, for costs of suit in this behalf expene,” &c. In the authentication of the jugment, the juge, who certifies to the attestation of the clerk, styles himself thus: “I, Alfre Iverson, Juge of the Superior Courts of the Chatahoochee circuit, in sai State, in which circuit is sai county of Talbot,” ec. The court below rejecte the transcript offere in evience, an gave jugment for the efenant.
We think there is no substantial variance between the jugment escribe in the eclaration an that isclose in the transcript. The original recovery, though informal, is, in effect, the same as that escribe by the pleaer in this suit. It is true the cases cite for the plaintiff, among which are, The State Bank vs. Gray, 7 Eng. 760. State Bank vs. Magness, 6 ib. 343, an The State Bank vs. Sherrill, ib. 334, cannot be sai to apply, because in those cases, the recital of the recor was only inucement to the main fact intene to be establishe by it, that is, the institution of a former suit upon the same cause of action, to rebut the presumption arising from lapse of time; an the case of Aams vs. The State for the use of Wallace, at July term, 1853, was ecie upon a like reason. But here the jugment sue upon is necessarily the founation of the action, an it must be concee that a misescription of it, in any material matter, woul be a fatal variance. Yet in such cases the pleaer is not require to escribe the recovery in haec verba, or accoring to its-tenor; but may set it out accoring to its legal effect. The rate of interest allowe by law, is the measure of amages for the breach of a contract to pay money, an whether the action be in form, assumpsit or ebt, the amages, in the shape of interest, follow as a legal consequence upon the ascertainment of the ebt. The jugment is correctly escribe, as to the parties, the' court by whom renere, its ates an amounts, an the eclaration woul therefore seem to be a compliance with the reason-for the rule of pleaing, that a contract must be accurately escribe in orer to ientify the cause of action, for the protection’ of the efenant an as a security against further litigation.
The cause of the rejection, not necessarily appearing, it may be possible that the Circuit Court exclue the transcript offere-in evience, upon the groun that it was not sufficiently authenticate; an so this court might have to hol, were it not for the ecision in Butler vs. Owen, 2 Eng. 369, that where a juge in his attestation, is escribe as juge of the court, it is a sufficient authentication uner the act of Congress, without saying.that he-is the juge, or sole juge; an we are not incline to epart from the preceent there establishe in any ease, where, as in the present instance, there is nothing on the face of the recor auce, from which it coul be inferre that the court was compose of more than one juge or-magistrate.
Reverse an remane.-

case_name: In the matter of the Will of Cornelius
text_content:
Mr. Chief Justice Watkins
elivere the opinion of the Court,
It appears from the recor in this case that on the 14th of February, 1852, the clerk of the Hempstaa Probate Court, in vacation, grante letters of aministration to Jester Cornelius upon the estate of William Cornelius, ecease, an that after-wars, the last will an testament of the ecease was foun, an that it was amitte to probate, an allowe as such by the clerk in vacation, on the 12th of April. At the July term, 1852, of the Probate Court, the clerk prouce the will, together with the proofs taken before him in support of the same. Jester Cornelius, who was one of the executors name in the will, appeare an resiste the probate, filing various exceptions thereto. The exceptions being consiere, were overrule by the court, which proceee to ajuge that the probate of the will in question, as taken an mae before the clerk in vacation, be approve an confirme; that the letters of aministration grante to the contestant be revoke, an letters testamentary issue, or in lieu thereof, letters of aministration with the will annexe, in case the executors name shoul refuse to act. Jester Cornelius excepte to this ecision an appeale to the Circuit Court, which being of opinion that there was no error appearing in the jugement of the Probate Court, affirme the same; an from the ecision of the Circuit Court he has appeale to this court.
"Waiving the enquiry suggeste, whether any question was technically well reserve by the bill of exceptions taken by the appellant to the jugment of the Probate Court, an which the Circuit Court, uner the statute, woul have to etermine, in orer to ascertain whether the Probate Court ha erre in relation to any material question of law or fact, before proceeing to try the matter enovo; an allowing to the appellant the full benefit of every objection he may have esigne to make to the probate of the will, as it appears upon the recor, another enquiry, an one of more general concern presents itself; an that is, whether the appellant ha any right to be hear before the Probate Court, in opposition to the probate of the will, or any right to appeal from its ecision, whereby that coul be mae available as a moe of testing the valiity or invaliity of the suppose will.
While that portion of the statute of wills, which prescribes the requisites of a vali will, an the formalities attening its execution, once unerstoo an familiar to the mins of the people 'at large, ought to remain unchange, unless for some urgent reason ■of public policy, there are some other provisions relating to the proof an establishment of wills, ifficult to harmonize as a system, an which woul seem to nee a careful revision. The ■authors of the revise coe of 1839, in framing this title, eviently intene to aopt the leaing features of the New York Statute of 1836, while they have retaine some of the provisions of the Territorial Statute of wills, with such omissions an changes as they thought proper to make.
In the first place wills of realty an personalty are put on the ■same footing, an however proper this may be, an in accorance with the aministration law, making lans assets an, uner some circumstances, a primary fun in the hans of the aministrator for the payment of ebts, it might be ifficult to etermine, upon the whole statute, what effect is intene to be given to the probate of a will as evience, prima facie or conclusive, as a muniment of title, or upon creitors, legatees, or fieirs, who may, upon various contingencies, be intereste in the estate. It is mae the uty of the clerk in vacation, as well as cf the.Probate Coui’t, when informe of the existence of a will, to issue process to compel its prouction in orer that it may be probate. The clerk is require to take proof of any will, an grant a certificate of probate, or a certificate of rejection; a juicial function, falling so clearly within the principle ajuge in Kenney ex parte, 6 Eng. 598, holing that a master in chancery cannot issue a writ of injunction, an Scoggin vs. Taylor, 13 Ark. 380, that no power coul be conferre upon the same officer to issue a writ of ne exeat, that if these cases are ahere to, so much of the statute woul be unconstitutional, were it not for the further provision, that the act of the clerk, in pursuance of the power conferre on him by the statute, is “subject to the rejection of the court;” by which we unerstan it to be the uty of the Probate Court, in all cases, to confirm or set asie the proceeings ha before the clerk, whose authority is temporarily execute for the immeiate preservation of the estate, an who acts ministerially in certifying the evience, an preparing the subject matter for the ajuication of the court in term time.
The constitution inicates the court of probate as the proper forum, where provision shoul be mae by law, for the etermination of all controversies respecting the valiity of wills, with the right of appeal as in other cases. No goo reason is perceive why this shoul not be so : an in this country, where all courts are statutory, there is no founation for jealousy between common law an chancery or ecclesiastical jurisiction, nor is-there any substantial reason, in the suppose superiority of the lane interest, for excluing the salutary jurisiction of chancery, in cases proper for its interposition, by making the valiity of wills affecting real estate triable only at law.
